Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
prostate cancer
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Robot-assisted laparoscopic radical prostatectomy, bilateral 
pelvic lymph node dissection

 
History of Present Illness:
___ male with intermediate risk, large volume, prostate cancer.
 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Hypercholesterolemia and prediabetes.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:  None.

ALLERGIES:  No known drug allergies
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
 Negative for history of cancers.

 
Physical Exam:
WDWN, NAD, AVSS
Abdomen soft, non-distended, appropriately tender along incision 
sites
Incisions C/D/I
JP drain has been removed. 
Foley in place, secured to medial thigh. 
Bilateral lower extremities w/out edema, pitting or pain to deep 
palpation of calves

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 08:06AM BLOOD WBC-10.4* RBC-4.01* Hgb-12.7* Hct-36.9* 
MCV-92 MCH-31.7 MCHC-34.4 RDW-12.1 RDWSD-40.8 Plt ___
___ 08:06AM BLOOD Glucose-120* UreaN-23* Creat-1.4* Na-140 
K-4.6 Cl-104 HCO3-23 AnGap-13
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the Urology Service after undergoing 
robotic assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy. No concerning 
intra-operative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for full details.  The patient received ___ 
antibiotic prophylaxis.  At the end of the procedure the patient 
was extubated and transported to the PACU for further recovery 
before being transferred to the floor.  He was transferred from 
the PACU in stable condition. On POD0, pain was well controlled 
on PCA, hydrated with intravenous fluids for urine output 
>30cc/hour, provided with pneumoboots and incentive spirometry 
for prophylaxis, and he ambulated once. On POD1, the patient was 
restarted on home medications, basic metabolic panel and 
complete blood count were checked, pain control was transitioned 
from PCA to oral analgesics, diet was advanced to a clears/toast 
and crackers diet for breakfast and lunch.  Diet was advanced to 
regular after lunch and with further ambulation, the JP drain 
was removed.  Foley catheter care and leg bag teaching was 
provided by nursing. The remainder of the hospital course was 
unremarkable. The patient was discharged in stable condition, 
eating well, ambulating independently, and with pain control on 
oral analgesics. On exam, incision was clean, dry, and intact, 
with no evidence of hematoma collection or infection. The 
patient was given explicit instructions to follow-up in one week 
for post-operative evaluation and trial of voiding.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Lisinopril 2.5 mg PO DAILY 
2. Atorvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild  
2.  Bacitracin Ointment 1 Appl TP TID  
3.  Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H Duration: 2 Doses 
Take at 7AM and 7PM on date of void trial, foley removal 
RX *ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg ONE TAB by mouth twice a day Disp 
#*2 Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg ONE capsule(s) by mouth 
twice a day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0 
5.  Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain - Mild 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg ONE TAB by mouth Q8HRS Disp #*30 Tablet 
Refills:*0 
6.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ONE TAB by mouth Q4HRS Disp #*5 Tablet 
Refills:*0 
7.  Atorvastatin 20 mg PO QPM  
8.  Lisinopril 2.5 mg PO DAILY  
9.PAIN PILL LOG
keep track of pain pills and narcotics used on the provided Pain 
Pill Log (orange sheet) over the week and return the log sheet 
at your follow up appointment. 

Remember to also bring a pad/diaper, and the narcotic 
prescription bottle with you to follow up.

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PROSTATE CANCER

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
***please keep track of pain pills and narcotics used on the 
provided Pain Pill Log (orange sheet) over the week and return 
the log sheet at your follow up appointment. Remember to also 
bring a pad/diaper, and the narcotic prescription bottle with 
you to follow up..

-Please also reference the additional handout provided by your 
urologist with instructions and information about your surgery 
and post-operative plan of care.

-Please also reference the instructions provided by nursing on 
Foley catheter care, hygiene and waste elimination. 

-ALWAYS follow-up with your referring provider ___ your PCP 
to discuss and review your post-operative course and 
medications.  Any NEW medications should also be reviewed with 
your pharmacist.

-Resume your pre-admission medications except as noted AND you 
note that you NO longer need to take medications that shrink 
your prostate (Hytrin, Avodart, Flomax, etc.)

-You may take ibuprofen and the prescribed narcotic together for 
pain control. FIRST, use Tylenol and Ibuprofen.  Add the 
prescribed narcotic (examples: Oxycodone, Dilaudid, 
Hydromorphone) for break through pain that is >4 on the pain 
scale.

-The maximum dose of Tylenol (ACETAMINOPHEN) is 3- 4 grams (from 
ALL sources) PER DAY.

-Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. If you develop 
stomach pain or note black stool, stop the Ibuprofen.  Ibuprofen 
works best when taken around the clock.

-For your safety and the safety of others; PLEASE DO NOT drive, 
operate dangerous machinery, or consume alcohol while taking 
narcotic pain medications. 

-Do NOT drive while Foley catheter is in place.

-AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds (or 
3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high 
intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until 
you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up. Generally about 
FOUR weeks. Light household chores are generally ok.  Do not 
vacuum. 

-No DRIVING for THREE WEEKS or until you are cleared by your 
Urologist

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery

-You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener ___ a 
gentle laxative. These are  over-the-counter medications that 
may be health care spending account reimbursable. 

-Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid 
post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of 
narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or 
diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative.

-Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to 
further minimize your risk of constipation. 

-You may shower 2 days after surgery, but do not tub bathe, 
swim, soak, or scrub incision for 2 weeks

-If you had a drain removed from your abdomen, bandage strips 
called steristrips have been applied to close the wound. Allow 
these bandage strips to fall off on their own ___ days).  
PLEASE REMOVE any remaining dressings w/ gauze within 2 days of 
discharge.  You may get the steristrips wet.

-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your 
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

-Follow up in 1 week for wound check and Foley removal. DO NOT 
allow anyone that is outside of the urology team remove your 
Foley for any reason.

-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time; the leg bag is only 
for short-term when leaving the house, etc.

-Take prescribed antibiotic for Foley catheter removal as 
directed

-resume regular home diet and remember to drink plenty of fluids 
to keep hydrated and to minimize risk of constipation. For the 
first few days at home, you should eat SMALL PORTIONS.  Avoid 
high fat, bulky or fried foods. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___
target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 61-year-old male who was admitted to the Urology Service for a robot-assisted laparoscopic radical prostatectomy and bilateral pelvic lymph node dissection due to intermediate-risk prostate cancer. He has a past medical history of hypercholesterolemia and prediabetes, and no known drug allergies. His social and family histories are unremarkable. 

During his hospital stay, the patient's pain was well-controlled, and he was able to ambulate independently. He was discharged with a Foley catheter in place and instructions to follow up with his urologist in one week for post-operative evaluation and trial of voiding. 

At discharge, the patient was prescribed several medications, including acetaminophen, bacitracin ointment, ciprofloxacin, docusate sodium, ibuprofen, and oxyCODONE. He was also advised to keep track of his pain pills and narcotics used on the provided Pain Pill Log and to return the log sheet at his follow-up appointment. ||endoftext||

None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ female with history of CAD, atrial fibrillation, COPD, and 
CHF admitted with cough and shortness of breath.
.
Her symptoms began 4 days ago with a minimally productive cough. 
 She also reported associated shortness of breath but only when 
coughing.  No SOB at rest.  She reports feeling chills but 
denies fevers, abdominal pain, chest pain, lower extremity edema 
or weight gain.  Of note, she was admitted to ___ with PNA/COPD 
exacerbation in ___ and discharged with augmentin, doxycycline 
and a steroid taper.  The patient reports completing the full 
course of medication.  As mentioned, she reported 4 days of 
cough, wheezing and shortness off breath.  She took her home 
inhalers but they were not providing relief of her symptoms.  
Given that she went to her PCP's office where she was found to 
be hypoxic.  She was referred to the emergency department for 
further evaluation.
.
On arrival to the ED, vital signs pertinent for temp of 100.7, 
HR 75, BP 120/46, SaO2 95% on 2L NC.  Patient received 
azithromycin, solumedrol 125mg and nebulizers x 4 with 
improvement in symptoms.  CXR revealed possible RLL PNA so she 
was given a dose of ceftriaxone.  She did not receive vancomycin 
for HCAP.  Labs were pertinent for normal WBC and lactate.  INR 
was 2.4.  Blood cultures are pending.
.
On arrival to the floor, vitals signs were T- 97.9, BP 124/60, 
HR 72, RR 20, SaO2 95% on 3L.  The patient appeared comfortable 
at rest with minimal boughts of cough.  She denied chest pain.  
Also denied weight gain, lower extremity edema, PND, orthopnea, 
abdominal pain, headache, dizziness, lightheadedness or syncope. 
 No sick contacts or recent travel.
.

vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent 
change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. Denied 
arthralgias or myalgias.

who presents with cough and shortness of breath
.  
#  Cough- Patient was recently admitted with similar symptoms at 
___ and was discharged with a course of augmentin and 
doxycycline for CAP, which she completed.  However, prior to 
admission, she developed cough associated with shortness of 
breath so she presented to ___.   In the ED, she was febrile 
with possible early pneumonia on CXR, so she received a dose of 
ceftriaxone.  Given that her WBC was normal, and cough was 
non-productive, the patient was not initially treated for HCAP.  
In addition, she has presented like this in the past and was 
treated for a COPD exacerbation.  On admission, she was started 
on azithromycin, prednisone 60mg daily and nebulizers.  Her 
symptoms improved and oxygen requirement was decreasing.  
However, she developed a fever on ___ so she was started on 
vancomycin and cefepime for HCAP, given recent hospital 
discharge.  She was weaned off oxygen and worked well with 
physical therapy.  Urine legionella was negative.  Blood and 
urine cultures were negative.  Sputum culture was contaminated 
with normal respiratory flora.  The patient completed an 8 day 
course of antibiotics- vancomycin 1gm q48hours, Cefepime 1g q24 
hours via ___ line.  She is being discharged on a prednisone 
taper starting at 30mg daily.  On discharge, cough, shortness of 
breath and oxygen requirement had resolved.  She was able to 
ambulate with no shortness of breath.  The patient was afebrile 
from ___ until discharge, had a normal WBC count and looked 
well.  
.  
#  Fever- Likely secondary to pneumonia.  She lacked other 
symptoms of influenza (myalgias, etc).  Patient's cultures were 
negative.  UA was negative for UTI.  
.
#  COPD- Patient improved with azithromycin, nebulizers and 
steroids.  She was weaned off oxygen and is being discharged on 
a prednisone taper, starting at 30mg daily for 14 additional 
days of therapy
.  
#  Atrial fibrillation- Continued home amiodarone and 
metoprolol.  Heart rate was regular and was well-controlled.  
Her INR trended up to 4.3 so she was cut down from 2mg 3x/week 
to 0.5 or 1.0mg daily (pending INR) given that she is on 
antibiotics and amiodarone.  As mentioned, her INR peaked at 4.3 
but then trended down.  We resumed her at 2mg daily on ___ 
when INR was 1.7.  Subsequent trend was 1.7 -> 1.5 -> 1.6.  She 
received 2mg of coumadin on ___.  We have 
instructed her to resume her prior regimen on discharge meaning 
she will take 2mg on ___ and 1mg on ___.  We also asked the 
patient to have an INR check on ___ and to please fax the 
results to her PCP for instruction on management of coumadin 
dosing.  
.  
#  Diastolic CHF- The patient has a known history of chronic 
diastolic heart failure.  On admission, there were no signs of 
fluid overload on exam.  Her oxygen requirement was attributed 
to pneumonia and COPD exerbation.  Given her elevated creatinine 
on admission, her lasix and lisinopril were initially held.  Her 
creatinine improved so we resumed her lisinopril at 20mg daily.  
By discharge, we resumed home dose of lisinopril.  Once 
creatinine stabilized, home dose of lasix was resumed and 
patient's creatinine remained stable.  She was discharged on 
home dose of lasix 20mg daily and has ___ with Dr. ___ 
on ___.
.
#  CAD- The patient did not present with chest pain.  Her EKGs 
were consistent with prior.  She was continued on her home 
statin and beta-blocker.  
.
#  Hypertension- As mentioned above, her lisinopril was 
initially held given ___ but was resumed at home dose by 
discharge.  She was continued on the remainder of her home 
medications- imdur 30mg daily, metoprolol 50mg BID and 
nifedipine 60mg daily.  BP's were remained stable. 
.
#  Numbness- On the last day of admission, patient revealed to 
us that she had been experiencing numbness in her fingertips 
(all of them).  Exam did not demonstrate any sensory or motor 
deficit as patient has ___ strength in all 4 extremities with 
intact sensation bilaterally.  She is not a diabetic.  Other 
possible etiologies include b12 deficiency, radiculopathy, or 
vasculitis.  Given that her symptoms are in both hands with only 
the DIP joint affected, a cervical radiculopathy is unlikely.  
She has no other systemic symptoms suggestive of vasculitis 
(skin changes, fever, chills) and her labwork is benign.  No 
indication for imaging as remainder of neurological exam is 
intact, including gait.  This also could be due to a medication 
as she received IV antibiotics.  B12 level checked and pending 
at the time of discharge, but, given description of symptoms, 
will likely not be the etiology behind this numbness.  We ask 
that the patient's PCP ___ on this issue when she sees the 
patient on ___.
.
# Prophylaxis:  DVT ppx with coumadin, bowel regimen senna, 
colace, pain management with tylenol
.  
# Code: Full (confirmed)  
.  
# Emergency Contact:  Daughter ___ ___

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 91-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of cough and fever. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation, and congestive heart failure. She was previously admitted to the hospital with a similar condition and was discharged with a course of antibiotics, which she completed. However, her symptoms persisted, and she presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath. On admission, she was febrile with possible early pneumonia on chest X-ray, and she received a dose of ceftriaxone. Her white blood cell count was normal, and her cough was non-productive, so she was not initially treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia. She was started on azithromycin, prednisone, and nebulizers, and her symptoms improved. ||endoftext||

had slowly downtrending crit related to possible GIB. Mildly

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is an ___ y/o M with extensive vascular history who 
presented with chest pain and anemia. Transferred to MICU due to 
concern of demand ischemia in setting of LGIB.  

#Chest Pain - The patient has an extensive coronary history. His 
present episode of chest pain ocurred in the setting of 
tachycardia to the 160s (reported by EMS) and a hematocrit below 
his baseline. Given pt's EKG and clinical picture, the elevated 
troponin was most likely demand ischemia. He was given packed 
RBCs to increase oxygen supply for increased demand.   A CHF 
exacerbation despite an elevated BNP, but unclear likely given 
clear lungs and no fluid overload on CXR.  Other etiologies 
including PE was considered but his INR was supratherepeutic and 
pt was not hypoxic. Cardiology was consulted and did not believe 
that this was ACS and did not recommend coronary angiography.

# Anemia - The patient has a long history of anemia and has 
known history of gastric erosions, but no ulcers, and 
diverticuli. CT Abdomen this month has no evidence of 
malignancy. Pt is presently on iron supplementation. Guaiac (+) 
stool in ED and on the floor. Pt was transfused several units of 
RBCs (followed by lasix) to maintain a goal of hct>30 for demand 
ischemia. 
 
# A. Fib - CHADS2 score of 4. The patient presented in afib with 
a rate in the 110s, and hemodynamically stable. Pt may have had 
an episode of NSVT with EMS before arriving to ED since he had 
SVT during last admission. No SVT episodes during ICU course. Pt 
was continued on metoprolol with rates maintained below 100, 
until the patient developed the GI bleed.  Metoprolol was held 
given blood pressures in 90/50 and his heart rate was well 
controlled without it.  Given his GI bleed, his coumadin and 
metoprolol were held at the time of discharge.

#. C.diff colitis- The patient was found to have C. diff colitis 
and started on metronidazole on ___.  He will need to 
complete 14 days of metronidazole.
 
# PVD - Patient with PVD leading to ulcerations. Patient with 
stent placed recently and it was of high priority that he 
continued anti-platelet and AC with plavix and warfarin at 
present. With pt's GI bleed, vascular team was amenable to 
discontinuing Plavix. Wound care team followed pt throughout 
course.

# Acute on Chronic Kidney Disease - Cr elevated to 2.0 on 
admission. Also with BUN elevation to suggest pre-renal state. 
___ also be due to renal vein congestion in the setting of CHF. 
After receiving blood products, his Cr improved and was 1.4 at 
the time of discharge.

# sCHF/CAD - Worsening EF thought to be due to progressive CAD. 
It was imperative to give blood/fluid slowly and diurese as 
needed. CXR and lungs presently clear with absent JVD on my 
exam. Pt's home torsemide was held.  The statin and ACE 
inhibitor were restarted by the time of discharge.  The patient 
should follow up with his cardiology within ___ weeks after 
discharge to assess the need to restart his torsemide.
 
# Delirium - Had difficulty with sundowning on prior admission. 
Seen by ___ consult and was started on zyprexa PRN agitation at 
night.

# DMII: Pt's home metformin was hekd and BG were monitored four 
times a day.  He was discharge on an Insulin sliding scale.

Transitional issues:

torsemide
- F/u with his PCP ___ 1 week of discharge from rehab
- F/u with his cardiology within ___ weeks of discharge from the 
hospital

Discharge Condition:

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for 
chest pain.  We don't believe you had a heart attack, but the 
chest pain was likely related to lower oxygen to your heart.  
You are now chest pain free after receiving blood.  

We also found that you had a bleed within your gastrointestional 
system.  You underwent endoscopy, in otherword we looked with a 
camera at your gastrointestion system, which did not find the 
source of your bleeding.  We have stopped your plavix and 
currently stopping your coumadin after discharge.  We have also 
stopped your torsemide and metoprolol given lower blood 
pressure.  You should follow up with your cardiology and 
determine if you should restart the torsemide, metoprolol, and 
coumadin.  

We also found that you had an infection of your colon caused by 
a bacteria, clostridium difficle.  You will need to take 
antibiotics to treat this infection.

Finally, it is important that you rebuild your strength after 
discharge at the rehab extended care facility.

We are stopping your torsemide and metoprolol given your recent 
GI bleed.  Please talk with your cardiology about restarting 
metoprolol, torsemide and coumadin within ___ weeks of 
discharge.  Also, please see your primary care doctor within 1 
week of discharge from rehab.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 77-year-old male who presented with chest pain and anemia. He has a extensive past medical history, including coronary artery disease, ischemic cardiomyopathy, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and peripheral vascular disease. He was recently admitted with hypotension and was found to have a reduction in left ventricular ejection fraction to 20%. He was also diagnosed with gastritis and duodenal ulcer.

The patient's diagnosis on admission was demand ischemia, and he was given packed red blood cells to increase oxygen supply. He was also treated for possible gastrointestinal bleeding and sepsis. His medications at discharge included warfarin, metoprolol, and iron supplementation.

The patient underwent an endoscopy and was found to have moderate gastritis and duodenal ulcer. He also had a positive stool test for Clostridium difficile.

The patient's physical examination on admission showed an irregularly irregular heartbeat, normal S1 and S2 heart sounds, and a II/VI systolic murmur. His lungs were clear to auscultation, and his abdomen was soft and non-tender. His extremities showed poor pulses bilaterally with eschar over an ulcer on the right.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated troponin levels, anemia, and abnormal liver function tests. His chest X-ray showed no acute cardiopulmonary process.

The patient's hospital course was complicated by demand ischemia, anemia, and possible gastrointestinal bleeding. He was treated with packed red blood cells, antibiotics, and iron supplementation. He was also continued on warfarin and metoprolol. ||endoftext||

probes to bone in RLE. CRP 74. Initially pt admitted with plan 
for OR debridement, possible hardware extraction and bone bx. 
Per Podiatry on ___ there was concern re wound healing if 
hardware were to be extracted so decision made to avoid surgery. 
Bone bx performed at bedside on ___. Subsequently, on further 
discussion with ID consultants, it was decided that OR bone bx 
would allow for more precise culture dx.  Patient underwent 
exploratory procedure by podiatry on R foot ___ were unable 
to find or recover heardware, but were able to obtain bone 
sample. Discharged on Vancomycin 1500mg q 12hrs, ertapenem 1g q 
24hrs through ___, as well as PO Vanc for C.diff  
prophylaxis. Patient's weight bearing status is touchdown on R 
toes on discharge. Should have ongoing wound care with wound 
vac, to be changed ___. 

# DM: Continued Lantus/SSI

# Afib:  Continued sotalol/metoprolol and eliquis. Per 
Cardiology consultation, pt was felt to have 1 risk factor on 
RCRI. 

# HTN: Continued Valsartan and Lasix

# Thrombocytopenia: 
Likely ___ cirrhosis. PLTs were stable

# Stage III CKD

# Chronic dCHF: 
Mild AI. BNP slightly elevated but clinically no significant 
evidence of volume overload. Continued home Lasix. 

# Cirrhosis: 
MELD ~12. ___ B. Currently compensated. Case discussed 
with pt's Hepatologist, no indication for inpatient consult. Pt 
was continued on Rifaximin.

===================

through ___. NOTE: may be contacted by ID about changing 
vanc dosing based on trough. ___ be contacted by ID also about

results.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

Thank you for choosing to receive your care at ___. You were 
admitted for an infection in the bone of your R food. You were 
started on antibiotic therapy to treat this infection. You 
underwent exploratory surgery on the foot, which confirmed the 
infection but was unable to remove any hardware present in your 
foot. We took a sample of the infected bone, which may help us 
tailor your antibiotics moving forward. In the meantime, while 
those results are coming back, you should continue to take IV 
antibiotics at a rehab facility.

below, and attend the follow up appointments listed below.

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 56-year-old male who presented with ankle swelling and drainage. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, colon cancer, cirrhosis, and atrial fibrillation. He was previously admitted to another hospital for the same condition and was discharged home with plans to follow up in clinic. However, he developed increased swelling and low-grade fever, and was referred to the current hospital for admission.

The patient's allergies include erythromycin base. He has a history of MRSA infection and was previously treated with vancomycin and doxycycline. He was prescribed lasix to increase his dosage due to swelling, and also took a leftover prescription of dicloxacillin at home.

The patient's diagnosis is mixed bacterial flora, including Staphylococcus aureus, which is resistant to oxacillin, erythromycin, and other antibiotics. He underwent bedside bone biopsy, which showed fibro-purulent exudate with associated fragments of necrotic bone.

The patient underwent imaging studies, including X-ray and CT scans, which showed chronic changes in the ankle without evidence of osteomyelitis. However, the CT scan did show findings worrisome for calcaneal ulcer with associated phlegmon.

The patient's medications at discharge include lasix and other antibiotics. ||endoftext||

IMAGING:

___ CT head without contrast
1.  Left temporal bone fracture spares the otic capsule but 
extends 
posteriorly to involve the left occipital bone.   Underlying 
left occipital epidural hematoma containing several foci of air. 

2.  Bilateral subdural hematomas (left greater than right) and 
anterior 
parafalcine subdural hemorrhage. 
3.  Bilateral subarachnoid hemorrhage. 
4.  Left temporal and probable anterior inferior left frontal 
contusions. 
5.  3 mm right-sided shift of normally midline structures. 

___ CT chest, abdomen, pelvis with contrast
1.  Hemoperitoneum adjacent to the posterior and inferior edge 
of the liver with high-density stranding in the gallbladder 
fossa and the porta hepatis.  Although hypoattenuating linear 
streak artifact from the right arm limits evaluation, linear 
hypodensity in the periphery of segment IVb is suspicious for a 
laceration.  The study can be repeated with the right arm up if 
more detail is desired. 
2.  Two small subcentimeter hypodensities in the periphery of 
the inferior edge of the spleen with adjacent small amount of 
blood are suspicious for small lacerations. 
3.  Acute right anterolateral ___ through 7th rib fractures. 
4.  Mild compression deformities of T11 and T12 vertebral bodies 
are likely chronic. 

___ CT head without contrast
1.  Left occipital epidural hematoma underlying the calvarial 
fracture is 
stable in size.  Small, left greater than right subdural 
hematomas are stable in size. 
2.  Left greater than right subarachnoid hemorrhage has 
increased in extent.  
There is no associated increase in mass effect. 
3.  Complex, comminuted left temporal bone fracture, which 
extends into the tegmen tympani and middle ear cavity.  Middle 
and inner ear structures may be better assessed by dedicated 
temporal bone CT.  The fracture also extends into and widens the 
temporal/occipital and occipital/parietal sutures. 

___ Echocardiogram
The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is mild symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. Left 
ventricular systolic function is hyperdynamic (EF>75%). There is 
a mild resting left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Right 
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The 
aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. The ascending 
aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear 
structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic 
stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are 
structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. 
Physiologic mitral regurgitation is seen (within normal limits). 
There is no pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Hyperdynamic left ventricular systolic function with 
mild resting outflow tract obstruction. No significant valvular 
disease.  

___ ECG
Marked sinus bradycardia competing with a junctional escape. No 
previous 
tracing available for comparison.  
  
  Intervals Axes 
Rate PR QRS QT/QTc P QRS T 
44 124 96 490/462 54 21 56 
 
___ KUB
Multiple distended loops of small bowel are present, 
particularly 
in the mid abdomen, with maximal transverse ___ of up to 
5.4 cm.  Air is also observed throughout non-distended loops of 
colon.  On the decubitus view, multiple air-fluid levels are 
seen in both large and small bowel.  Observed findings could 
potentially represent an ileus, but short-term followup 
radiographs are recommended to exclude early or partial 
small-bowel obstruction.  Tip of nasogastric tube terminates in 
the proximal stomach, but a side port could potentially be above 
the GE junction, and a dedicated chest x-ray may be helpful to 
better determine the location of the side port if warranted 
clinically. 

___ LUE films
SHOULDER:  There are no signs for acute fractures or 
dislocations.  There are degenerative changes of the AC and 
glenohumeral joints.  There are healed left fourth and fifth rib 
fractures. 
  
LEFT HUMERUS:  No acute fractures or dislocations are seen.  
Mineralization is normal. 
  
LEFT FOREARM:  There is a fracture plate in the distal radius 
shaft.  There are no signs for acute fractures.  There is a 
corticated density adjacent to the lateral aspect of the distal 
humeral epicondyle.  This may represent sequela of old trauma or 
a supracondylar spur.  A lucency is seen at the base of the 
spur.  There is no elbow joint effusion.  There is spurring 
about the olecranon at the triceps tendon attachment. 
  
LEFT WRIST:  There are no acute fractures or dislocations.  
There are severe degenerative changes of the first CMC, 
triscaphe, and radiocarpal joints. Distal radioulnar joint 
demonstrates spurring.  Peripheral IV catheter is identified.  
There is a well-corticated density at the radial aspect of the 
wrist joint. 
  
___ ___ Doppler Study
Left basilic vein thrombus.  The basilic vein is a superficial 
vein.

___ Renal U/S
Limited views of the bilateral kidneys demonstrate the right 
kidney measures 
12 cm, and the left kidney measures 12.3 cm.  There is no 
evidence of 
hydronephrosis or large renal mass bilaterally.  No perinephric 
fluid 
collections are present.  There is no evidence of renal stones 
bilaterally.  
Renal echogenicity and corticomedullary architecture is within 
normal limits.  
  
  
Due to the limited nature of this study secondary to patient 
motion, 
acceleration times and peak systolic velocities of the main 
renal arteries are not well evaluated, however there is 
demonstration of bilateral renal vascular flow with diastolic 
flow. Resistive indices on the right range from 0.47 to 0.56 and 
on the left range from 0.61 to 0.7.  The main renal arteries are 
patent bilaterally. The renal veins are patent bilaterally.   
Prior CT shows left renal artery stent. 
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
Motion limited study. Arterial flow to both kidneys, as above.  
  
___ CT head without contrast
1. Multiple new hypodense areas is scattered throughout the 
brain concerning for embolic infarcts, possibly subacute. 
Recommend MRI for further evaluation. 
2. Expected evolution of subarachnoid hemorrhage which is now 
less dense 
compared to the prior study. Stable left occipital epidural 
hematoma and 
parafalcine subdural hematoma. No new hemorrhage.  

___ MRI brain w/o contrast
1. Combination of right watershed and right MCA territory 
infarcts, the latter both cortical and basal ganglia in 
distribution.  Considered in conjunction with diminished flow in 
right ICA, findings are most consistent with severe proximal 
stenosis likely due to unstable atherosclerotic plaque. 
2. Stable extra-axial hemorrhage as described above. 
3. Left frontal and temporal lobe contusions. 
4. Mastoid air cell and middle ear cavity fluid, consistent with 
known 
temporal bone fracture. 

___ EEG
EEG is recorded from 19:20 on ___ through 7 AM on ___. 
CONTINUOUS EEG: Background is slow and disorganized, with no 
posterior 
dominant rhythm or anterior-posterior gradient of frequencies. 
Predominant background activity is moderate voltage polymorphic 
theta and delta activity. There is continuous focal slowing over 
the left hemisphere, higher voltage polymorphic delta activity, 
most prominent in the left parasagittal region. 
SLEEP: No normal sleep architecture is present. 
PUSHBUTTON ACTIVATIONS: There are no pushbutton activations. 
SPIKE DETECTION PROGRAMS: There are frequent automated spike 
detections, 
predominantly for electrode and movement artifact. There are no 
epileptiform discharges. 
SEIZURE DETECTION PROGRAMS: There is one automated seizure for 
electrode and movement artifact. There are no electrographic 
seizures. 
QUANTITATIVE EEG: Trend analysis is performed with Persyst Magic 
Marker 
software. Panels include automated seizure detection, rhythmic 
run detection and display, color spectral density array, 
absolute and relative asymmetry indices, asymmetry spectrogram, 
amplitude integrated EEG, burst suppression ratio, envelope 
trend, and alpha delta ratios. Segments showing abnormal trends 
are reviewed, and show diffuse delta activity, more prominent on 
the left. 
CARDIAC MONITOR: Shows a generally regular rhythm with an 
average rate of 
60-70 bpm. 
IMPRESSION: This is an abnormal continuous ICU monitoring study 
because of moderate diffuse background slowing, much worse on 
the left. These findings are indicative of moderate diffuse 
cerebral dysfunction, as well as focal cerebral dysfunction in 
the left hemisphere, and are consistent with the multiple 
regions of brain injury from trauma and multiple infarcts. No 
epileptiform discharges or electrographic seizures are present. 

___ CXR
In comparison with study of ___, the patient has taken a much 
better inspiration.  Although the cardiac silhouette remains 
mildly enlarged and there is tortuosity of the aorta.  The 
pulmonary vascularity has substantially improved with only mild 
elevation of pulmonary venous pressure. 
The nasogastric tube is not well visualized.  No evidence of 
acute focal 
pneumonia. 

___ MRA neck w/ and w/o contrast
Marked irregularity and multifocal narrowing of the right 
internal carotid artery as well as the right vertebral artery 
likely related to dissection.  Possible dissection flap noted in 
the distal cervical ICA on the fat-saturated T1-weighted images. 
  
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___:  Urine output low, bolused IVF, CK elevated. Hct slowly 
downtrending  
  
___: intermittently agitated through day, ?related to bladder 
spasms - started oxybutinin. NGT placed with greenish/brown 
gastric contents. abdomen also somewhat distended, likely ileus, 
held off TF for today. SBP parameters liberalized to <160 per 
neurosurgery. A-line pulled out due to agitation, but BPs 
correlating well with cuff. Nicardipine switched to labetalol 
gtt for SBP 180/70 with HR 110. febrile to 102.1, pancultured. 
QTc prolonged to 410, pRN haldol switched to ativan.  
___: Pt persistently hypertensive,restarted labetalol gtt.  
Pt w/purulent sputum, culture sent. Pt febrile. CXR done. 
started vanc/zosyn, foley d/c.  
___: Slightly hypertensive, but controlled with hydralazine. 
20mg IV Lasix given for moderate pulmonary edema and generalized 
edema. In ___, continues to be hypertensive that is not 
controlled with PO/IV meds. Started IV Labetalol, and increased 
IV Hydralazine. Not controlled, so labetalol gtt was re-started. 
 
___: still intermittently agitated but improving. labetalol gtt 
off. vomited x 1 mostly tube feeds, KUB showed dilated loops of 
bowel. ACS aware. TF turned off, NGT to suction. Lasix 20mg x 2 
given with good diuresis -1L/day  
___: Antibiotics stopped. Had L upper extremity Xrays for 
decreased movement on right side-- no fractures. Upper extremity 
duplex U/S-->basilic vein thrombosis(superficial), No e/o DVT. 
Started amlodipine, ramipril. Weaned sedation. Lasix 20mg x1 
given with good diuresis -3.5L over 24 hrs. Arterial line 
placed. Labetolol gtt needed for BP control.  
___: Continued HTN. Cards was consulted and recommended 
chlorthalidone (no further cardiac workup recommended). PO 
labetalol was discontinued. ACS mentioned they would do a PEG on 
___. Had head CT done for AMS, showed possible subacute embolic 
infarcts (?MRI needed). SAH that is less dense comparted to 
prior stud. Stable L occipital epidural hematoma and parafalcine 
subdural hematoma. No new hemorrhage. Spoke with neurosurgery, 
who recommended a neurology consult for stroke workup. Ordered a 
MRI/MRA of head.  
___: , AC contraindicated. PEG placement deferred until 
tomorrow. chlorthalidone dose decreased 50->25mg as pt diuresed 
>3L. BPs elevated overnight, hydralazine PO increased to 30mg 
q6h  
___: Stopped Chlorthalidone. Lisinopril dose increased. MRA and 
lipid panel as per neurology recs. MRA suggestive of Rt ICA and 
vertebral artery dissection. Vascular team aware- no 
intervention recommended. EEG- no evidence of seizures, dilantin 
stopped. S/p PEG- remained intubated overnight with plan to 
extubate next am. Flexiseal placed for loose BM.  
 
___: Pt extubated, ) Unable to clear C-spine at this time. He 
will start TF via PEG on ___ per ACS.  
___: TF started via PEG. Transfer to floor today.  
ASSESSMENT:  
___ y/o M s/p fall, +LOC, GCS ___, intubated, found to have Left 
occipital epidural hematoma, Bilateral subdural and subarachnoid 
 
hemorrhages, left greater than right, rib fractures and liver 
laceration.  
Neurologic: 
Mr. ___ was admitted to ___ s/p fall from approximately 
20ft. His original CT scan showed a left temporal bone fracture, 
bilateral subdural and sub arachnoid hemorrhages (small) a left 
occipital epidural hematoma. His repeat head CT stable. Upon 
admission he was intubated and sedated, though he had a reported 
GCS of >8 in the field. On ___ the patient was extubated. 
Following extubation, he was increasingly agitated and started 
on PRN haldol for his agitation. On ___ the patient had a repeat 
head CT to evaluate for his diminishing mental status. 
Immediately following extubation he had been agitated though he 
would not open his eyes, he was moving all four extremities 
spastically, and he verbalized unintelligible speech. By ___ he 
would no longer verbalize at all, though he would open his eyes, 
he also rarely moved his extremities. The CT scan revealed 
possible subacute embolic infarcts. Neurology work-up including 
multiple imaging of cerebral vasculature revealed a large 
filling defect of R ICA extending to skull base He was started 
on ASA 325mg per neuro recs. Vascular surgery consulted re R ICA 
occlusion and advised that there no indication for CEA at this 
time. On ___ and ___ the patient appeared much more alert than 
previous exams. He would open his eyes spontaneously and was 
oriented to person and place (with some receptive language 
delay.

Cardiovascular:  
The patient was hypertensive throughout his hospital stay. He 
had a goal SBP<160 which was attained with a labetalol drip 
which was transitioned to PO labetalol once he was tolerating 
PO.

Pulmonary:  
He was intubated upon admission to ensure airway protection. He 
was weaned to CPAP and then successfully extubated before his 
transfer to the floor.

GI/FEN:  
He was made NPO upon arrival because of his inability to 
coordinate swallowing around the ET tube. Electrolytes were 
repleted as necessary, IV fluids were stopped once he was 
tolerating gtube feeds. a PEG was placed ___ and he started PEG 
tube feeds on ___. Which he tolerated.

MSK:  
He presented with right ___ rib fractures, he worked with ___ and 
OT to transition his care.

Endocrine:  
In the ICU he was maintained on an insulin sliding scale with a 
goal blood glucose between 150 and 100.

Mr. ___ was transferred to the inpatient ward on ___.  He 
was continued on tube feedings via his PEG tube, which he 
continued to tolerate well.  A speech and swallow evaluation was 
conducted on the day of discharge, ___.  Due to inability to 
follow commands, a true swallow evaluation could not be 
completed.  He had little to no swallow reflex to the one or two

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 57-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital after a traumatic brain injury sustained from a 20-foot fall from scaffolding. He was intubated in the field and transported to the hospital by medflight. On admission, the patient was found to have a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of unknown prior to intubation. He had abrasions on his right chest wall and upper abdomen.

The patient has a history of hypertension, a benign tumor between his rectum and spinal cord, and multiple falls, including several concussions. He has no known allergies or adverse drug reactions.

The patient underwent a PEG tube placement procedure during his hospital stay. His laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell counts, with a peak of 17.6*10^9/L, and decreased hemoglobin and hematocrit levels. His blood chemistry results showed elevated creatinine and urea nitrogen levels, with a peak of 1.6 mg/dL and 33 mg/dL, respectively.

Imaging studies revealed a left temporal bone fracture, bilateral subdural hematomas, and an anterior parafalcine subdural hemorrhage. The patient also had a left occipital epidural hematoma, bilateral subarachnoid hemorrhage, and left temporal and probable anterior inferior left frontal contusions.

The patient's echocardiogram showed mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size, hyperdynamic left ventricular systolic function, and a mild resting left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. His electrocardiogram showed marked sinus bradycardia competing with a junctional escape.

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of traumatic brain injury and multiple injuries, including a left temporal bone fracture, bilateral subdural hematomas, and an anterior parafalcine subdural hemorrhage. ||endoftext||

will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough 
discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and 
expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the 
office or return to the hospital, and all questions were

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- weight bearing as tolerated right lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take lovenox daily for 2 weeks post operation

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get splint wet

Physical Therapy:
- weight bearing as tolerated, RLE
- ROMAT R hip, knee, ankle
Treatments Frequency:
- staples will be removed at follow up appointment
- multipodus boot to LLE
 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 38-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a right tibia fracture after being struck by a car. He has a history of neurologic conditions, including optic atrophy, neuropathic foot pain, and cerebellar ataxia, as well as a history of gastritis and duodenal ulcer. He is allergic to penicillins, acetaminophen, and amitriptyline. 

The patient underwent an open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of the right tibia fracture and was discharged with a diagnosis of a displaced segmental fracture of the shaft of the right tibia. He was prescribed medications including bisacodyl, docusate sodium, enoxaparin sodium, oxyCODONE, senna, aspirin, and metFORMIN. 

At the time of discharge, the patient's pain was well-controlled, and his incisions were clean and dry. He was advised to follow up with his surgeon and to take his medications as prescribed. He was also instructed to avoid drinking alcohol, driving, or operating machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers and to take a stool softener to prevent constipation. ||endoftext||

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

WHY DID I COME TO THE HOSPITAL?
===========================
-You were admitted because you had bleeding from your left 
thigh.

WHAT HAPPENED WHEN I WAS ADMITTED?
================================
-While you were admitted, our Vascular Surgeons operated on your 
left thigh and drained the collection there. 
-We gave you IV antibiotics and switched you to oral 
antibiotics.

WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?
=======================================
-Continue to take all of your medications and keep all of your 
appointments as listed below. 
-Importantly, continue taking your antibiotic (Bactrim for your 
left thigh infection). You will need to take this twice a day 
(one in morning, one in evening). 
-Stop taking your atenolol and lisinopril for now. We stopped 
this because your blood pressures were on the lower side. 

Sincerely,
Your ___ Team

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 75-year-old female who was admitted with a chief complaint of left thigh bleeding. She has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, COPD, and prior DVT. She was previously treated with Lovenox and was admitted to the hospital with an arterial bleed into her thigh, which required embolization of the left medial femoral circumflex artery. The patient's bleeding resolved with the application of Surgicel and direct pressure, but she experienced recurrent bleeding when she got up to use the bathroom. A CT scan revealed a fluid collection with surrounding stranding, consistent with an abscess. The patient was treated with antibiotics and was advised to remain non-weightbearing. She was also prescribed medications including acetaminophen, furosemide, levothyroxine, and valacyclovir.

The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension, hypothyroidism, COPD, and prior DVT. She also has a history of breast cancer, asthma, and ocular herpes. Her social history is significant for a motor vehicle accident in which she believes part of her skull was removed.

The patient's physical examination revealed a firm hematoma in her left upper thigh, as well as a chronic appearing wound with no active bleeding. Her vital signs were stable, and her laboratory results showed a decrease in her hemoglobin level. The patient was advised to remain non-weightbearing and to follow up with her primary care physician for further evaluation and treatment. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Key Information for Outside Providers: 
___ is a ___ year old female with history of ESRD on HD, 
peripheral vascular disease status post RLE BKA, admitted 
___ with sepsis secondary to MRSA bacteremia, now status 
post removal and replacement of her tunneled HD line able to be 
discharged home with planned course of vancomycin to be 
continued at HD

# MRSA Sepsis secondary to
# Acute blood stream infection 
# Suspected Acute bacterial Endocarditis 
# L lateral heel ulcer 
Patient with history of MRSA line infection ___ who 
presented with MRSA bacteremia presumed ___ line infection. 
Patient's TTE was concerning for possible vegetation on 
tricuspid valve.  She was seen by ID consult service who 
initially recommended TEE, but patient declined this and was 
able to verbalize her understanding.  Source of bacteremia felt 
to be line-related, although ID also recommended MRI of L heel, 
where she had an unhealed ulcer that was debrided by podiatry.  
Given need for IV contrast, patient declined study due to 
chronic risks associated with MRI contrast in patients who are 
ESRD.  Patient had HD catheter removed on ___, then had a 
line replaced on ___.  Patient treated with IV vancomcyin 
with clinical improvement.  Last positive blood cultures were 
drawn on ___. Because endocarditis and/or osteomyelitis 
could not be definitively ruled out, ID consult service 
recommended completion of 6-week course of Vancomycin, dosed at 
HD.  

# Difficult access 
___ initially tried to place a new line on the left side, to 
preserve the right-sided vasculature for a future AV graft. 
Unfortunately, a L IJ and L subclavian line was unable to be 
placed due to sclerosis and or thrombosis of the L IJ and L 
subclavian, likely secondary to multiple access attempts. The 
patient refused femoral access and was able to verbalize 
understanding of clinical situation.  Per discussion with Renal 
and ___, the decision was made to place R IJ line as above. 

# Behavioral Issues 
Patient often refused medications during this admission. In 
speaking to the patient, she believes that many medications 
make her sick. In speaking to her HCP, her brother ___ 
___, he reports that she often refuses medications at home as 
well.  Inpatient psychiatry consult team saw patient for 
assessment regarding capacity to make medical decisions 
relating to medications and inpatient managemetn.  She was felt 
to not pose a danger to herself, and in discussions with team 
was able to demonstrate understanding of her decisions and 
their impact on her health.  She was recommended for outpatient 
follow up with psychiatry and counseling. Of note, per review 
of prior records, does have history of concussion as child. 
Evaluated by Cognitive Neurology in ___. Found to have 
significantly low IQ and learning deficits, although masked by 
verbal fluency. Her ability to handle new and complex info is 
impaired.  During this admission extra time was spent 
counseling patient to ensure she understood clinical situation, 
team recommendations and risk/benefit as it related to her 
clinical state.

# Gastroparesis
Initial presentation notable for nausea and vomiting. No 
evidence of acute abnormality on CT A/P and abdominal exam 
reassuring.  Felt to represent gastroparesis flare.  Treated 
with supportive care with resolution of symptoms.  She was able 
to tolerate a regular diet. 

# ESRD: On HD TThSa. Pt declined sevelamer/nephrocaps as she 
reported they worsen her chronic symptoms of nausea. 

# Hyperphosphatemia: Pt declined phosphate binders this 
admission. 

# Mild Intermittent Asthma
Continued home flovent. 

# DM type 2
Held glipizide while inpatient, restarted upon discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

Why were you admitted to the hospital?
======================================
You were admitted to ___ because of fevers, chills, and 
vomiting caused by a bloodstream infection.

What did you receive in the hospital?
=====================================
You were treated with an intravenous antibiotic called 
vancomycin. We also removed your tunneled dialysis catheter, as 
we felt this was the cause of your infection. A temporary 
dialysis catheter was placed so that you could continue to 
receive dialysis while we treated your infection. This was 
eventually replaced with a permanent dialysis catheter.

You were seen by podiatry while you were here. They looked at 
the wound on your left heel, they cleaned the wound and provided 
us with recommendations to keep it clean. 

What should you do when you leave the hospital?

She has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD) with gastroparesis, neuropathy, and peripheral vascular disease (PVD) following a right lower extremity (RLE) below-knee amputation (BKA). She has multiple allergies, including penicillins, cephalosporins, aztreonam, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and Reglan. She was admitted to the hospital with MRSA bacteremia and line infection, treated with vancomycin. During her hospital stay, she underwent tunneled HD catheter removal and temporary HD catheter placement. She was also treated for a cold and had a chronic foot ulcer on her left heel. At discharge, her vital signs were stable, and she was prescribed medications for her condition. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, he underwent a deceased donor liver transplant from 
a ___ yo DBD. Piggyback, PV-PV, CHA-CHA, BD-BD with internal 
biliary stent (No extra vessels, 740 cellsaver, 5 PRBC).  
Surgeon was Dr. ___. Please refer to the operative 
note for details.  Postop, he transferred to the SICU intubated, 
and was taken back to the OR on POD 1 for concern for IVC 
obstruction. There was no evidence of obstruction, the diaphragm 
was plicated to prevent the liver from falling over the IVC and 
obstructing flow. He was transferred to the SICU and then 
eventually the floor for post-operative care. 
.
He was kept intubated and sedated immediately post-operatively. 
Sedation was complicated by intermittent agitation that required 
treatment with antipsychotic medication. He was extubated on 
___, and then was intermittently confused, requiring 
scheduled seroquel for management of his agitation at the time 
of transfer to the regular hospital floor. The Seroquel was 
weaned to off, and mental status was markedly improved. Patient 
did very well with medication teaching.
.
He developed afib with RVR while in the SICU - this did not 
respond to to metoprolol IV push or amiodarone loading. The 
patient was given a loading dose of digoxin and transitioned to 
propanolol with satisfactory rate control but remained in atrial 
fibrillation at the time of transfer to the floor. He remained 
hemodynamically stable with the exception of a brief pressor 
requirement immediately post op. 
Surface echo was performed on ___ per cardiology 
recommendation for Afib follow up. This echo showed a new 
moderate loculated pericardial effusion. Repeat echo two days 
later showed large/increased pericardial effusion with s/o 
tamponade. On ___, thoracic performed a pericardial window 
with drain placement with 200cc drained. A drain was left in the 
pericardial space. Fluid was sent for culture and was negative. 
Right atrial collapse was no longer present. Biventricular 
function remained preserved. Postop CXR was stable without 
pneumothorax. Postop ekg demonstrated aflutter with rate in ___. 
Cardiology recommended continuation of digoxin and propranolol 
with repeat TTE on ___ that demonstrated trace pericardial 
effusion. The drain was removed on ___. The propranolol was 
discontinued on ___. Digoxin was continued for rate control..
Pulmonary: He had a brief acute ventilator dependent respiratory 
failure immediately post-operatively. He was given furosemide 
for presumed volume overload, and he successfully extubated on 
___. He was weaned to room air with intermittent nasal cannula 
requirement at the time of transfer to the floor.
.
GI: Initially, he was kept NPO with a NG tube. Trickle tube 
feeds were started. During an episode of agitation, pt 
self-discontinued the NGT. Clear liquids were started then 
advanced to regular diet, which he tolerated. LFTs continued to 
decrease. On ___, the sub-hepatic drain became bilious despite 
stable LFTs. An ERCP was done noting bile anastomosis site 
extravasation and a ___ stent was placed. He tolerated this 
procedure well and was given Cipro that was to continue until

decreased ___ and ___.

Discharge Instructions:
Please call the transplant clinic at ___ for fever > 
101, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, inability 
to tolerate food, fluids or medications, yellowing of skin or 
eyes, increased abdominal pain, incisional redness, drainage or 
bleeding, dizziness or weakness, decreased urine output or dark, 
cloudy urine, swelling of abdomen or ankles, or any other 
concerning symptoms.

Bring your pill box and list of current medications to every 
clinic visit.

You will have labwork drawn every ___ and ___ as 
arranged by the transplant clinic, with results to the 
transplant clinic (Fax ___ . CBC, Chem 10, AST, ALT, 
Alk Phos, T Bili, Trough Tacro level.

*** On the days you have your labs drawn, do not take your Tacro 
until your labs are drawn. Bring your Tacro with you so you may 
take your medication as soon as your labwork has been drawn.

Follow your medication card, keep it updated with any dosage 
changes, and always bring your card with you to any clinic or 
hospital visits.

You may shower. Allow the water to run over your incision and 
pat area dry. No rubbing, no lotions or powder near the 
incision. You may leave the incision open to the air. 
No tub baths or swimming
.
Drain and record the pigtail drain output twice daily and as 
needed so that the drain is never more than ½ full. Call the 
office if the drain output increases by more than 100 cc from 
the previous day,  becomes bloody or develops a foul odor.
Change the drain dressing once daily or after your shower. Do 
not allow the drain to hang freely at any time. Inspect the site 
for redness, drainage or bleeding. Make sure there is a stitch 
at the drain site.
.
No driving if taking narcotic pain medications and not until 
cleared by your surgeon.
.
Avoid direct sun exposure. Wear protective clothing and a hat, 
and always wear sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher when you go 
outdoors.
.
Drink enough fluids to keep your urine light in color. Your 
appetite will return with time. Eat small frequent meals, and 
you may supplement with things like carnation instant breakfast 
or Ensure.
.
Check your blood pressure at home. Report consistently elevated 
values to the transplant clinic
.
Do not increase, decrease, stop or start medications without 
consultation with the transplant clinic at ___. There 
are significant drug interactions with anti-rejection 
medications which must be considered in medication management 
following transplant.
.
Consult transplant binder, and there is always someone on call 
at the transplant clinic with any questions that may arise

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 59-year-old male who was admitted for a liver transplant due to HCC/ETOH cirrhosis. He has a past medical history of EtOH cirrhosis, skin cancer, and has undergone TIPS and RFA procedures. He has no known allergies or adverse reactions. The patient underwent a deceased donor liver transplant and was intubated post-operatively due to respiratory failure. He was later extubated and transferred to the floor for post-operative care. During his hospital stay, he developed atrial fibrillation, which was treated with digoxin and propranolol. He also developed a pericardial effusion, which was drained and treated with antibiotics. The patient's laboratory results showed normal liver function tests, and he was prescribed immunosuppressive medications, including Cellcept, myfortic, and tacrolimus. He was discharged with a drain in the mid abdominal collection and was advised to follow up with his healthcare provider for further treatment. ||endoftext||

The patient's medications at discharge included none, as her amitriptyline was stopped. ||endoftext||

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted due to worsening fatigue. After some testing, 
it was determined that this was due to worsening of your atrial 
fibrillation. For that reason, we treated you with a 
cardioversion to get you back into a normal sinus rhythm. We 
also started a medication called amiodarone to help keep you in 
a normal rhythm. It will be important to follow up with your 
cardiologist for management of this medication. We also 
decreased your metoprolol to 50mg, stopped your digoxin, and 
decreased your simvastatin to 20mg. We decreased your lasix to 
40mg per day. Please stop taking your glipizide and lisinopril 
until you see your primary care doctor to ensure you kidney 
function is ok. It was a pleasure taking care of you.

Best of luck,
Your ___ medical team

He has a history of coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus type 2. He has also had recurrent deep vein thrombosis and has been on warfarin. His past medical history is significant for a previous myocardial infarction, stent placement, and cardiac catheterization. He has been experiencing worsening fatigue and was admitted to the hospital for diuresis.

The patient's physical exam revealed mild jugular venous distension, bilateral lower extremity edema, and bibasilar crackles. His laboratory results showed elevated troponin levels, brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), and creatinine levels. His electrocardiogram (EKG) showed atrial fibrillation and normal axis.

The patient underwent a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), which showed severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction, moderate mitral regurgitation, and mild-moderate aortic regurgitation. He was started on digoxin and furosemide during his hospital stay.

At discharge, the patient's vital signs were stable, and his physical exam revealed no acute distress. He was prescribed medications including aspirin, digoxin, and furosemide. His laboratory results showed improvement in his troponin and BNP levels, and his creatinine level was stable. ||endoftext||

Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for 
evaluation of  recurrent abdominal pain and nausea/vomiting and 
underwent laparoscopic converted to open cholecystectomy. You 
are recovering well and are now ready for discharge. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

General Surgery:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

The patient states that today he got back together with his 
long-term girlfriend/wife who brought him a family sized bottle 
of Listerine in the mall and then layed on bench and became 
unresponsive.  He states that they began to fight and then she 
beat him about the head and chest with his own cane.  She left 
and at a time distant to the assault he passed out on a park 
bench.  He states that he drank more of the listerine, "being 
the bigger man."  

 

EMS arrived and finger stick was found to be in the 150's. In 
the ER he opened his eyes and was able to communicate 
appropriately despite slurred speech. He adamantly claimed that 
he only drank listerine, and no other drugs.  Initial vitals 
were 99.1 100 144/78 20 100%. 

.

Plan was for CIWA and observation until sober re-evaluation.  
However after several hours in observation he began to withdraw 
and score on CIWA for tremulousness and tachycardia.  Given his 
seizure history and requirement of 6mg Ativan over an hour he 
was transferred to the ___.

.

 

On arrival here, he is alert, interactive and asking for pain 
meds

.

Of note Mr ___ has had multiple recent admissions as 
follows:

- ___ ICU w/ d/c AMA on ___ for presumed isopropyl alcohol 
intoxication and admission from ___ to ___ for presumed 
aspiration pneumonia on cefpodoxime/azithromycin 

- ___ ___ for fevers, CP, and productive cough cough.  

.  

- ___ ICU from ___ to ___. Patient was visiting his wife 
___ in the ICU when he was noted to become unresponsive.

- Durring his hospitalization ___ he called his ___ PCP and 
complained of not getting enough pain meds, he then told his PCP 
___ "if he didnt give him more pain meds he would put him in as 
much pain as he (___) was already in."  This resulted in the 
patient being banned from ___ clinic, patient relations 
involvement and an agreement by which Mr. ___ is not 
allowed to get any outpatient prescriptions from ___.

___ 06:15AM BLOOD Osmolal-___ with complicated social situation and multiple ___ 
admission for ingestions of alcohol and its related denatured 
counterparts.

.

Listerine Ingestion: 

Per the ingredient list Listerine is 40% etoh and also includes 
a salicylate.  Mr ___ ETOH level on admission to the ICU 
was 85 while his salicylate level was negative.  It is likely 
that ETOH was driving all of his assorted issues.  This likely 
explained his lowish anion gap metabolic acidosis on admission.  
Using the formula that ETOH is corrected for in the osmolar gap 
by dividing by 3.8, his osmolar gap is accounted for by his ETOH 
level, making coingestion with isopropanol or ethylene glycol 
much less likely.  He scored only once on CIWA, over 18 hours 
ago, and currently has normal vital signs.  We will plan for 
discharge. 

- Per prior agreement he will not be discharged with 
prescriptions for any medications
.
Hypoxia:
Suspect medication induced hypoventilion c/b splinting leading 
to increased CO2 and thus increased CO2 admixture via the 
alveolar gas equation, stably in the low 90's overnight while 
asleep. Resolved morning of discharge.
.
Pain control:
This patient is a terrible candidate for opiates, and refuses 
nsaids, we used low dose tylenol and would not give opiates in 
any situation if possible.  Despite sleeping easily, he 
continued to request fioricet/fioranol for his migraines when he 
awakened, but this medication was not in his medication discarge 
list.  He was given tylenol.
.
Rib Pain:
No hct drop to raise c/f splenic rupture, no fractured ribs, no 
ptx
.
Multiple Psychiatric diagnoses:
Patient was continued on his home regimen, he should continue 
with his home supply at home.
.
?Seizure d/o history:
.
Doctor ___ recent note calls into question his seizure 
history; however, the patient comes in with a positive 
barbiturate level.   Given his lack of seizure disorders and 
previous plans, we will discharge him without a prescription for 
phenobarb.

.

Dicharge planning:

Please refer to the below note from Chief Resident ___ 
regarding his rules for discharge.
.  
" After discussion with the patient and his consulting services, 
we will not provide prescriptions for any of his reported home 
medication including clonazepam, carbamazepine, amitriptyline, 
olanzapine or mirtazapine. At this time, the risk of significant 
toxicity including death, in the setting of his ongoing 
substance abuse is greater the risk of any potential withdrawal 
symptoms.
.
After discussion with neurology we will provide the patient with 
a short duration of phenobarbital with planned Neurology Access 
Clinic follow up."

He has a history of substance abuse, including alcohol and polysubstance abuse, as well as a mood disorder with multiple suicide attempts and a possible diagnosis of PTSD, bipolar disorder, and anti-social personality disorder. He has also had multiple admissions for ingestions of alcohol and its related denatured counterparts.

The patient's past medical history includes a subdural hematoma, hepatitis C virus infection, seizure disorder, and chronic lower back pain. He has also had multiple recent admissions, including one for presumed isopropyl alcohol intoxication and another for presumed aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's physical exam was notable for his ability to communicate appropriately despite slurred speech. He was alert and interactive, and his vital signs were stable. He was diagnosed with ethanol withdrawal and was treated with CIWA and observation until sober re-evaluation.

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of ethanol withdrawal and was advised to continue his home regimen, including his home supply of medications. He was also advised to avoid using Listerine and other denatured alcohols. ||endoftext||

Discharge Instructions:
Medications:
Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
post procedure pain or discomfort.

What activities you can and cannot do:
When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs.
You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
rinse and pat dry)
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area that is draining, as needed
No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal).
After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity.
After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
walked as you can tolerate.
No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications

What to report to office:
Changes in vision (loss of vision, blurring, double vision, 
half vision)
Slurring of speech or difficulty finding correct words to use
Severe headache or worsening headache not controlled by pain 
medication
A sudden change in the ability to move or use your arm or leg 
or the ability to feel your arm or leg
Trouble swallowing, breathing, or talking
Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities 
Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or 
green drainage from incisions
Bleeding from groin puncture site

*SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING 
(Groin puncture site)
Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm pressure 
to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call our office. If 
bleeding does not stop, call ___ for transfer to closest 
Emergency Room!

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the GYN service with concern for PID 
vs. tubo-ovarian abscess vs. chronic appendicitis based on 2 
pelvic ultrasounds and a pelvic MRI which was consistent with 
her presentation of intermittent RLQ pain and increased WBC 
count despite being afebrile.  The decision was then made to go 
to the operating room where a laparoscopic appendectomy was 
performed as well as lysis of adhesions.  Please see operative 
report for full details.  Post-operatively she was admitted to 
the GYN service.  Her post-operative course was uncomplicated.  
She was able to tolerate a regular diet, ambulate, void after 
her foley catheter was removed and control her pain with oral 
medications.  She received 36 hours of IV gentamicin and 
clindamycin and remained afebrile for her entire hospital stay.  
Her white blood cell count came down to 8.7 on post-op day 2.

flagyl and doxycycline and told to follow-up with her primary 
gynecologist in ___ in 3 weeks for a post-operative check.

Discharge Instructions:
Call your doctor for:  
* fever > 100.4  
* severe abdominal pain  
* difficulty urinating  
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr  
* abnormal vaginal discharge  
* redness or drainage from incision  
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication  

General instructions:  
* Take your medications as prescribed.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.  
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs  
* No strenuous activity, nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no 
douching, no sex), no heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 6 
weeks.  
**if no cervix p LSC hyst, nothing in vagina for 3 months  
* You may eat a regular diet.  

Incision care:  
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.  
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.  
* If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
visit.
  
To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___
 
Followup Instructions:
___
