Reports:

Chest x-ray ___
Moderate to severe pulmonary edema.  Retrocardiac opacity may 
represent atelectasis and/or consolidation. 

ECG: NSR, normal axis, no ST changes, nl QRS and PR intervals.

TTE ___
The left atrium is mildly dilated. Left ventricular wall 
thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic function are 
normal (LVEF >55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, 
ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets 
(3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No 
aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened. Mild to moderate (___) mitral regurgitation 
is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. 
There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There 
is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. 

 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a ___ F with history of schistosomiasis cirrhosis 
c/b diuretic refractory ascites, portal hypertension and 
encephalopathy currently on transplant list, IDDM, HTN and HLD 
who was directly admitted from home for acute renal failure.
  
# Acute Renal Failure: Baseline Cr < 1.5. Admitted with 
creatinine of 2.0, FeNa on admission 0.28% indicating pre-renal 
state. No evidence of infection on admission without fevers, 
chills, nausea, vomiting, suprapubic tenderness or dysuria, UA 
with epis and does not indicate UTI. Patient received albumin 
1g/kg (62.5grams) on HD 1 and morning after creatinine improved 
to 1.7. On HD 2 H/H was low so instead of albumin patient was 
volume challenged with 1 unit PRBCs and 25grams of albumin (1 
unit PRBCs=25 grams albumin). Diagnostic paracentesis ruled out 
SBP. Creatinine worsened after initial volume challenge and did 
not respond to second round of 1g/kg albumin. After failed 
improvement diagnosis of hepatorenal synrome was made and 
midodrine/octreotide were started and uptitrated without 
improvement in creatinine.  Cr steadily continued to rise, 
patient became oliguric and was volume overloaded.  The renal 
team was consulted.  Initially, plan was for pt to have HD line 
placed in ___ and start dialysis.  However, given active bleeding 
(see below), she was trasferred to SICU and started on CVVH.
       
# Cirrhosis: Chronic, related to schistosomiasis complicated by 
diuretic refractory ascites, chronic renal failure, portal 
hypertension, thrombocytopenia, prior SBP and encephalopathy. 
MELD 20 on admission with Childs Class C. Without evidence of 
encephalopathy, hepatic decompensation or asterixis on 
admission. Continued Rifaximin 550mg PO BID and Lactulose TID 
for HE prophylaxis. Continued Ciprofloxacin for SBP prophylaxis. 
Diagnostic paracentesis was performed and ruled out SBP. No GI 
endoscopy in our system but patient being evaluated for 
transplant, cannot be on transplant list without endoscopy so 
presumably completed somewhere. MELD rose to >30 in setting of 
hepatorenal syndrome and patient was listed for ABO incompatible 
liver. As HRS progressed, MELD score was at 40 on transfer to 
the SICU.

# Pulmonary edema: Pt w/ pulm edema on CXR on ___ and mildly 
symptomatic. Initially, pt subjectively some SOB, but O2 low to 
mid ___ on RA.  After 2 days, developed O2 requirement.  
Overload most likely in the setting of rapidly deteriorating 
renal function.  Less likely cirrhosis induced cardiomyopathy.  
Last TTE ___ with normal EF.  Repeat TTE with still normal EF 
but new moderate PA systolic HTN. Attempted to diurese with 
Lasix 20 iv then 80, put out very small amt of urine, 
incontinent.   In setting of rapidly progressive HRS, pt became 
oliguric and was unable to mobilize fluid.  Plan was made for 
dialysis as above.

# Hard palate bleed:  On ___ at ~6am, pt developed bleed right 
hard palate.  This was likely ___ mild oral trauma in the 
setting of coagulopathy--INR 3.6, platelets 75.  Initially, 
attempted to stop by applying pressure, unsuccessful.  Per 
discussion with ENT and OMFS, attempted to stop the bleed with 
afrin soaked gauze, topical thrombin, silver nitrate, 
aminocaproic acid.  Also transfused with platelets, FFP, and 
RBCs (as hct was 22 down from 25 at last check). Held continuous 
pressure for ~3 hours.  As soon as pressure was released, active 
bleeding was visualized.  Tamponaded bleed for ~10 minutes, but 
again continued to have uncontrollable bleed and was transferred 
to SICU on the transplant surgery service for elective 
intubation and packing.  The lesion was cauterized and the 
bleeding was controlled.  She was initially successfully 
extubated at transferred to the floor. 

# Hyponatremia: Hypervolumic hyponatremia from cirrhosis. Did 
not diurese patient given ___. Albumin and PRBCs given for 
intravascular volume and patient kept on 1.5L fluid restricted 
diet. She remained hyponatremic so fluid restricted further to 
1.2L with improvement in Na.
    
# Acute anemia: Patient with chronic anemia related to cirrhosis 
though with acute drop on HD 2. Unclear etiology without GIB 
during admission. Unknown if patient has varices without 
endoscopy in our system and is not on beta-blocker so presumably 
none on prior endoscopy. Possible hct drop was in setting of 
volume challenge overnight and dilutional effect though WBC and 
platelets unchanged. She was transfused 1 unit PRBCs both for 
anemia and volume challenge. Hct remained stable following 
transfusion.
     
# DM: Insulin Dependent, Type II. Hyperglycemic during admissin. 
Continued Glargine 12 units qHS and HISS
    
# HLD: Chronic, stable, continue zetia 
   
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
- Continue holding diuretics
- Recommend tracking down endoscopy report, unknown where 
completed

ICU Course ___ to ___, date of death)
Ms ___ was transferred to the surgical ICU the morning of 
___ after developing worsening melena. She had an EGD the day 
prior for the purpose of Dobhoff feeding tube placement, and 
during that EGD a duodenal polyp was noted and biopsied. Of 
note, she had an INR of 2.5 and fibrinogen of 59 prior to the 
procedure so snare removal of the polyp was deferred. The 
evening following the EGD, she had several episodes of melena 
thus prompting transfer to the ICU to facilitate repeat emergent 
EGD. The EGD ___ showed a lot of old blood around the polyp, but 
no active bleed from the stalk. 
The first few days in the SICU she remained HD stable, but 
continued to have melena with an unstable hematocrit. We 
transfused RBC, FFP, platelets and cryo to goal Hct of 30 and 
correct her coagulopathy. We were unable to completely correct 
her, and she began having significant oral bleeding. By ___, 
she was coughing blood, had an increased oxygen requirement. She 
remained encephalopathic and was not protecting her airway 
sufficiently so she was intubated. After intubation she had a 
pressor requirement which remained until time of death. She was 
started on broad spectrum antibiotics (vanc/zosyn/mica) and a CT 
torso showed severe pneumonia with very little residual aerated 
lung volume. 
On ___ she was begun on CVVH for acidosis and had increased 
pressor requirement with the addition of vasopressin. We 
continued to transfuse RBC/FFP/cryo to maintain blood levels.
On ___ she had increased pressor requirement and markedly 
increased oral bleeding. It was estimated she bleed 600cc 
periorally this day. Transfusions continued and she remained on 
high dose levo/vaso, though her pressor requirement was slightly 
less than the day prior. A family meeting was held. It was 
decided she would not want to be on full life support for more 
than 5 days. As it had been 3 days to this point, we decided to 
make a final decision ___ unless she acutely worsened.
On ___, the day of her death, she acutely worsened during the 
day. She became hypotensive despite increasing her pressor 
doses. Melena and oral bleeding increased and she grew 
increasingly tachycardic. She was not responding hemodynamically 
to significant product transfusion, and her ventilator settings 
were increased with more oxygen needed. Another family meeting 
was held and we discussed that she was decompensating rapidly 
and likely had an unsurvivable condition. The family present was 
receptive and understanding. She was transitioned to comfort 
care at 7pm, though the endotracheal tube was left in to prevent 
aspirating blood which we felt would cause her too much 
discomfort. She was started on a morphine drip. Her heart rate 
and blood pressure gradually declined and asystole occured at 
9:28pm. She was declared at 9:30pm. The family declined an 
autopsy. 
 
Medications on Admission:
- Ciprofloxacin 250 mg daily.  
- Ezetimibe 10 mg Tablet PO DAILY  
- Insulin glargine Twelve (12) units SC QHS
- Humalog 100 unit/mL sliding scale
- Lactulose 10 gram/15 mL 30 ML PO TID 
- Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet PO Q12H 
- Rifaximin 550 mg Tablet PO BID 
- Calcium 500 + D (D3) Oral  
- Omega 3 Fish Oil Oral 
 
Discharge Medications:
Expired
 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Expired
 
Discharge Condition:
Expired
 
Discharge Instructions:
N/A
 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 69-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for acute renal failure. She has a history of schistosomiasis cirrhosis, portal hypertension, and encephalopathy, and is currently on the transplant list. She was recently discharged from another hospital where she was admitted for abdominal distension, and was directly admitted to this hospital for acute renal failure. The patient's past medical history includes schistosomiasis complicated by cirrhosis and ascites, hypertension, IDDM, dyslipidemia, and nephrolithiasis.

The patient's allergies include aspirin. She has a history of bleeding, including a recent episode of hematochezia and melena, and has been diagnosed with hepatorenal syndrome. She has also been diagnosed with pulmonary edema and has required oxygen therapy.

The patient's medications at discharge include midodrine and octreotide for hepatorenal syndrome, and rifaximin and lactulose for prophylaxis against hepatic encephalopathy and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.

The patient underwent several procedures during her hospital stay, including a diagnostic paracentesis, which ruled out spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, and an EGD with feeding tube placement and duodenal polyp biopsy. She also underwent a TTE, which showed mild to moderate mitral regurgitation and moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes, including ALT, AST, and LDH, as well as elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase. Her creatinine level was elevated at 2.0 mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level was elevated at 28 mg/dL. Her albumin level was low at 3.7 g/dL, and her calcium level was elevated at 9.8 mg/dL.

Overall, the patient's hospital course was complicated by her underlying liver disease and acute renal failure, and she required multiple interventions to manage her symptoms and stabilize her condition. ||endoftext||

Extended Care
 
Facility:
___

Recurrent pelvic abscess, retained anal sphincter, and J-pouch 
anastomosis.  Now ___ s/p Transperineal completion proctectomy 
and gracilis flap reconstruction

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Plastic Surgery Discharge Instructions
-refrain from sitting longer than 15minutes spaced at least 4 
hours apart.
-Use cusions and comforters to pad your surgical site as 
possible to avoid undue pressure to that area.

Colorectal Surgery Discharge Instructions
You were admitted to the hospital after a transperineal 
completion proctectomy and gracilis flap reconstruction for 
surgical management of your recurrent pelvic abscess, retained 
anal sphincter, and J-pouch anastomosis. You have recovered from 
this procedure well and you are now ready to go to a 
rehabilitation facility. You have tolerated a regular diet, have 
good ostomy output and your pain is controlled with pain 
medications by mouth. You may go to a rehabilitation facility 
and then home to finish your recovery.

Please monitor the appearance of the ostomy and stoma and care 
for it as instructed by the wound/ostomy nurses. ___ stoma 
(intestine that protrudes outside of your abdomen) should be 
beefy red or pink, it may ooze small amounts of blood at times 
when touched and this should subside with time. The skin around 
the ostomy site should be kept clean and intact. Monitor the 
skin around the stoma for bulging or signs of infection listed 
above. Please care for the ostomy as you have been instructed by 
the wound/ostomy nurses. 

If you have any of the following symptoms please call the office 
for advice or go to the emergency room if severe: increasing 
abdominal distension, increasing abdominal pain, nausea, 
vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids, prolonged loose 
stool, or extended constipation.

You have an incision along your perineum which is closed with 
sutures. This incision can be left open to air or covered with a 
dry sterile gauze dressing.  Additionally you have a long 
incision on your medial thigh from the gracilis flap by the 
plastic surgery team.  This can be left open to air. Please 
monitor the incision for signs and symptoms of infection 
including: increasing redness at the incision, opening of the 
incision, increased pain at the incision line, draining of 
white/green/yellow/foul smelling drainage, or if you develop a 
fever. Please call the office if you develop these symptoms or 
go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe. You may 
shower, let the warm water run over the incision line and pat 
the area dry with a towel, do not rub.
No heavy lifting for at least 6 weeks after surgery unless 
instructed otherwise by Dr. ___ Dr. ___. You may 
gradually increase your activity as tolerated but avoid heavy 
exercise.  You will be prescribed a small amount of the pain 
medication oxycodone and oxycontin. Please take this medication 
exactly as prescribed. You may take Tylenol as recommended for 
pain. Please do not take more than 4000mg of Tylenol daily. Do 
not drink alcohol while taking narcotic pain medication or 
Tylenol. Please do not drive a car while taking narcotic pain 
medication.

You are being discharged on the antibiotic linezolid, which you 
will take until ___.  Please take this by mouth as 
directed on your prescription.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. Good luck!
 
Followup Instructions:
___

She was prescribed several medications at discharge, including Levothyroxine, Ranitidine, Linezolid, Gabapentin, OxycoDONE, OxyCODONE SR, and Acetaminophen. The patient was discharged to a rehabilitation facility for continued monitoring of her surgical wounds and physical therapy. ||endoftext||

___ man with DM type 1 and end-stage renal disease presents for

#. End-stage renal disease: 
Recent symptoms were most likely due to increasing uremia in the 
setting of end-stage diabetic nephropathy. Infection was thought 
unlikely given this patient's lack of fevers, symptoms of upper 
respiratory infection (cough, dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain) or 
GI infection (diarrhea, hematochezia). On admission, patient's 
labs were notable for BUN 97, Cr 14.8, and phosphate 6.4; on 
discharge these improved to BUN 44, Cr 9.4, and phosphate 5.2; 
the patient noted a marked improvement in his symptoms and 
overall well-being.
.

and Hepatitis B (hep B core Ab, surface Ab, surface Ag, Hep C 
Ab), indicating lack of Hep C infection and either 
non-vaccination for Hep B or loss of immunity. Patient was 
advised to check his vaccination status with his PCP with

decreasing to baseline after conclusion of each session. This

pt. report), and is expected to improve as patient gets used to 
the procedure. 500cc of ultrafiltrate was withdrawn during the 
first 2 sessions. Patient's home regimen of furosemide 40mg was 
continued; his carvedilol dose was increased to 6.25mg BID, and 
Losartan, which had been previously stopped due to declining 
renal function, was re-started at 50mg qD per the recommendation 
of the Renal service.
.

and low ferritin stores noted during workup in ___. Now 
treated with Epoetin alfa; last dose received "several days

Phosphate improving to 5.2 on discharge. Renal team stated that

meanwhile, Sevelamer was continued TID with meals.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the ___ for initiation of hemodialysis 
for treatment of your nausea, vomiting, and other recent 
symptoms related to your chronic kidney disease. On admission, 
your vital signs were normal and stable, with the exception of 
very high blood pressure (213/109); your lab values on admission 
were notable for anemia and elevated blood urea nitrogen, 
creatinine, and phosphate, which are all signs of impaired 
kidney function.  Your hemodialysis sessions went well; we also 
re-started you on a blood pressure medication Losartan and 
increased your Carvedilol. Your blood pressure slowly normalized 
to your normal value (systolic blood pressure 145).
.

tuberculosis. This is done for all patients who start 
hemodialysis at facilities where there are many other end-stage 
renal disease patients. This was negative for tuberculosis. You 
also had your hepatitis serologies checked and your Hepatitis B 
tests were all negative. This means you either have never been 
immunized or your immunity has worn off. Please discuss with Dr. 
___ the ___ B vaccine series or getting a Hep B 
booster.

instruction given to you by your prescribing physicians.

He has a history of type 1 diabetes, chronic renal insufficiency, and end-stage renal disease. He has a radiocephalic AV fistula in his right arm and is on the kidney/pancreatic transplant list. He was admitted for initiation of hemodialysis and was found to have end-stage renal disease with increasing uremia. His laboratory results showed elevated blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, and phosphate levels, which improved with dialysis. He was also found to have anemia, which was treated with Epoetin alfa. His diabetes is well-controlled on his home insulin regimen. He was advised to follow up with his primary care physician and was started on thrice-weekly hemodialysis sessions. His medications at discharge included carvedilol, furosemide, losartan, and sevelamer. ||endoftext||

History of Present Illness: 
The patient is an ___ year old female with a history of actively 
treated C. diff colitis, pneumobilia, CAD, hypertension, and 
hyperlipidemia who presented to the ED from her nursing home 
with diarrhea, worsening mental status, and low blood pressure.  
Per nursing home records, she had been having loose stools for 
the last 4 days.  She was being actively treated for C. diff 
colitis with Flagyl 500 mg PO TID, receiving her last dose on 
___ evening. She then began having low BPs, cold lower 
extremities, weakness, and poor appetite.
.
She initially developed C diff after a right hip fracture s/p 
right hip hemiarthroplasty on ___, which was complicated by 
a UTI and pneumonia.  She was on antibiotics for the pneumonia 
and subsequently developed C diff colitis.  She was admitted to 
___ from ___ to ___ for treatment of her C diff, and 
improved rapidly after IV fluids, Vancomycin PO, and Flagyl IV.  
She was discharged on a course of Flagyl PO.  Her current course 
of Flagyl was started on ___.  It is unclear if she has 
needed additional courses between her last admission and today.
.  
In the ED, initial vitals were: T 102.8, BP 135/77, HR 140, RR 
29, SpO2 92% on 2L NC.  Initial labs were notable for WBC 54.0 
(0% bands, 2% metas, 1% myelos), Hct 48.0, INR 1.8, creatinine 
1.2 (recent baseline 0.4-0.6), and Lactate 5.6.  Her UA showed 
WBC 6, many bacteria, small leuk esterase, and negative nitrite. 
 CXR was markedly suboptimal showing low lung volumes, bibasilar 
opacities likely atelectasis, moderately enlarged heart 
unchanged, and large hiatus hernia.  
.
CT abdomen showed a large stable hiatal hernia, pneumobilia, and 
diffuse colonic wall edema and stranding.  Surgery consult was 
called and did not feel that there were any acute surgical 
issues.  The pneumobilia was noted to be present on prior CTA 
chest from ___, though not commented upon in the radiology 
report.  Surgical consult felt that this may be postsurgical 
from prior cholecystectomy or sphinterotomy.
.
IV access was obtained with 18g x2 and 20g x1 peripherals IVs.  
She was treated with Vancomycin 1000 mg IV (not PO), Flagyl 500 
mg IV, and Levofloxacin 750 mg IV.  Because of her Lactate 5.6 
and tachycardia, she was given a total of 8L IV fluids in the 
ED, with her lactate decreasing to 2.0 afterwards.  Given the 
severity of her infection and continued tachycardia despite IV 
fluids, she was admitted to the ICU for further management.  
Vitals prior to transfer were T 103 rectally, HR 124, BP 114/58, 
RR 22, and SpO2 96% on 2L.
.
On arrival to the ICU, she was fatigued but easily rousable and 
conversant.  She was oriented to person, "hospital", and ___. 
 She reported fever, abdominal discomfort, and generally feeling 
unwell, but was unable to describe her symptoms further.  She 
reports having diarrhea for the last 2 weeks.  She denied any 
chest pain, cough, or nausea.  She did note some shortness of 
breath and was breathing somewhat rapidly.
.

or skin changes.

4. Stable T11 old compression fracture. 

CXR ___: Bilateral lower lobe collapse is stable on the right, 
worse on the left, now accompanied by increasing moderate left 
pleural effusion. Pulmonary edema is cleared. Large cardiac 
silhouette is unchanged. Left PIC line ends in the region of the 
azygos insertion in the SVC. No pneumothorax. Clinical service 
notified by telephone at the time of dictation.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman, with a history of actively treated C. diff 
colitis, pneumobilia, CAD, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, who 
was admitted to the ICU for severe sepsis secondary to C. diff 
colitis, c/b aspiration, tachycardia, parotitis, hypernatremia 
and a possible GI bleed.

# C diff Colitis: The patient presented with profuse diarrhea.  
Of note, she has a history of C. diff colitis diagnosed in 
___, for which she was actively being treated with 
Flagyl prior to admission.  Upon presentation to the ICU, she 
had a markedly high white count, and her C. diff toxin tests 
returned positive.  A CT scan on ___ revealed inflammation of 
the colon, but no perforation of the bowel.  She was treated 
aggressively, at first with Flagyl 500 mg IV q8h, vancomycin 500 
mg PO q6h and vancomycin 500 PR q6h (retention enema), to which 
tigecycline 100 mg IV, followed by 50 mg IV BID was added on 
___, per advice of the Infectious Disease team.  She was 
evaluated by surgery, but deemed to be a poor surgical candidate 
for colon resection.  Despite aggressive treatment, her WBC rose 
to a peak of 73.4, and remained elevated in the ___ thereafter.  
Her diarrhea continued, but lessened in volume.  Additionally, 
her abdomen became less tender over the course of her stay.
     She can continue her IV tigecycline and Flagyl at her 
nursing home, as she was prior to her hospital admission.

# Severe Sepsis: Upon admission, the patient showed evidence of 
organ dysfunction (kidneys andliver) with a source of infection 
(C. diff), meeting the criteria for severe sepsis.  She received 
IV fluid boluses to make up for her GI losses with diarrhea and 
to maintain good urine output.  Although initially hypotensive, 
she responded well to IVF and was subsequently normotensive for 
the rest of her admission.  Her liver enzymes showed improvement 
of perfusion, her INR responded to Vitamin K 5 mg x1, and her 
kidney function improved.  She was given IVF to maintain good 
urine output, and antibiotics for her source of infection.

# Aspiration: The patient had an acute episode of tachypnea on 
the afternoon of ___, which occurred after having some ice 
chips.  She subsequently had a Speech and Swallow evaluation, 
which determined that she would need to remain NPO, as she is at 
high risk for more aspiration.  If she and her family decide to 
pursue comfort feeding, it would be very appropriate for her.

# Sinus Tachycardia: Confirmed to be sinus tachycardia on 
EKG,likely multifactorial due to sepsis, volume depletion, 
withdrawal of beta blockers, anxiety and pain.  The patient was 
monitored on telemetry.  Her tachycardia was treated with fluid 
boluses and metoprolol.  It responded well to metoprolol 
succinate 50 mg PO BID.

# Parotitis: Patient developed tenderness and swelling in her 
right parotid on ___, which was treated with warm compresses.

#Hypernatremia: Most likely iatrogenic secondary to NS fluid 
boluses, with some element of her being unable to take in free 
water.  Sodium was corrected by giving free water IVF.

# GI bleed: The patient had melanotic stool on ___, with a 
stable hematocrit.  She was monitored for further signs of 
bleeding.  This likely occurred secondary to her colitis.

# Urinary Tract Infection: On admission, She had a mildly 
positive UA in the ED with WBC 6, many bacteria, small leuk 
esterase, and negative nitrite.  She denies any current urinary 
symptoms.  She received Levofloxacin 750 mg IV.  Culture was 
positive for Enterococcus, but the infectious disease team 
believed this may have been a contaminant.  A repeat urine 
culture is pending.

# Depression: She continued her home doses of Citalopram and 
Bupropion. 

# Goals of care: The ICU attending and team met with the 
patient's family to discuss goals of care.  They elected to 
transfer the patient back to the nursing home so that she can be 
more comfortable and happy.  They will continue antibiotics, and 
make further decisions about care as they arise.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
Spine Surgery without Fusion

Surgery
 Your dressing was removed the second day after surgery. 
 Your incision is closed with staples. You will need staple 
removal. Please keep your incision dry until staple removal.
 Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
 Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple 
removal.
 Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
 We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
 You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
 No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
 No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 

Medications
 ***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
 You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
 It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
 Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
 Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
 New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| Mrs. [Name], a 60-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital for lumbar stenosis. She had undergone an L3-L4 laminectomy for lumbar stenosis in the past and had developed pain down her right leg over the last year. She underwent an elective L2-3 and L4-5 laminectomies plus right L4-5 microdiscectomy, which was uneventful initially. However, she developed right lower extremity weakness and new radicular pain, and a small hematoma collection was found, which required re-exploration. She was discharged with paresthesias in her right lower extremity and weakness in her right hip flexor and knee flexors and extensors.

The patient has a history of diabetes, cutaneous candidiasis, hip pain, vitamin D deficiency, hepatic steatosis, hypothyroidism, sleep apnea, and hypertension. She has allergies to penicillins, cephalosporins, codeine, Lipitor, econazole, nitrate, peppers, Flagyl, ProAir HFA, sage, nystatin, and Victoza.

The patient's diagnosis is lumbar stenosis, and she underwent procedures including L2-3 and L4-5 laminectomies and right L4-5 microdiscectomy. She was prescribed medications including acetaminophen, bisacodyl, diazepam, docusate sodium, gabapentin, glucagon, heparin, insulin, milk of magnesia, oxyCODONE, polyethylene glycol, senna, artificial tears, atenolol, levothyroxine, pravastatin, and vitamin D.

The patient was discharged to extended care and was instructed to follow up with her neurosurgeon. She was advised to avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, or other strenuous exercise until her follow-up appointment and to take pain medications as directed. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 41-year-old male who presented with acute chest pain at rest. He has a history of polycythemia diagnosed two years ago, with a hematocrit of 56, and has been undergoing phlebotomy every two weeks. He has no known allergies or adverse reactions. The patient's presenting symptoms included chest pain that radiated to his throat, making it difficult to take a deep breath. He was found to have mild ST elevations in II, III, and aVF and dynamic TWI in V3-V6, and was given medication to manage his pain. In the cath lab, he was found to have clean coronaries and normal left ventricular function. The patient's diagnosis was no angiographically apparent flow-limiting coronary artery disease, normal ventricular function, elevated left-sided filling pressure, and no aortic stenosis. He was prescribed medications at discharge, including plavix, ASA, and morphine. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with PMH of DM2, HCV, pancreatic cancer, presenting with 
worsening calf pain and abdominal pain after starting 
gemcitabine/abraxane three days ago.

#Abdominal pain: Patient had worsening pressure-like abdominal 
pain on admission. The most likely cause of the patient's pain 
is his increasing ascites from his pancreatic cancer. He had a 
soft but distended abdomen on physical exam. Ascites was seen on 
bedside ultrasound in the ED but they were unable to find a 
pocket to tap. The patient had never had a paracentesis before 
but he was scheduled for one as an outpatient next ___. 
Though the patient denied subjective fevers, there was concern 
for an infectious process as the patient was febrile to 100.8 
when he arrived to the floor. There is also concern for a 
biliary process as his bilirubin is 2.1 up from 1.0 three days 
ago, but he has no right upper quadrant tenderness on exam. His 
pain could be an adverse effect of his gemcitabine/abraxane, 
which he began three days prior to admission. 

The patient's abdominal ultrasound on ___ showed a known 
portal venous thrombosis. The patient had a diagnostic and 
therapeutic paracentesis on ___ where one liter of fluid was 
removed. His abdomen felt somewhat better after. 

#Fever/healthcare-associated pneumonia: Though the patient 
denied subjective fevers, the patient was febrile to 100.8 when 
he arrived to the floor. Infection or aspiration could not be 
ruled out on his CXR in the ED. Atelectasis was also a possible 
cause. There was also concern for an intra-abdominal cause of 
his fever given his increasing abdominal pain, but he had no 
localizing findings on physical exam. The patient's flu swab was 
negative. A urine culture was negative. Blood cultrues were 
drawn and pending at the time of discharge.

Of note, the patient had elevated WBCs in his ascites from his 
paracentesis. The patient had one dose of empiric ceftriaxone in 
the ED. Given the patient's CXR findings, we started the patient 
on levofloxacin ___ to cover community-acquired pneumonia 
with some HCAP coverage given that the patient has had recent 
chemotherapy. We did not give further coverage for his elevated 
ascites WBC given our low suspicion for intra-abdominal 
infection. The patient was discharged on a 5-day course of 
levofloxacin.

#DVT/Calf pain: On admission the patient complained of chronic 
calf pain that had gotten worse in the prior three days. This 
could have been be an adverse effect of his 
gemcitabine/abraxane, which he began three days prior to 
admission. He had no swelling on exam. There was concern for 
DVT, especially given the patient's malignancy. The patient had 
LENIs on admission that showed bilateral DVTs. He was started on 
a heparin drip and converted to lovenox on ___. The patient 
was discharged with a prescription for lovenox and received 
lovenox training with a ___ interpreter present prior to 
discharge on ___. Of note, the patient already injects his 
insulin and filgrastim at home.

#Anemia: The patient's Hb was 7.1 on admission, down from 8.3 on 
___. There was low suspicion for active bleeding. Hemolysis 
was possible given elevated bilirubin. Anemia could also be 
related to his gemcitabine/abraxane. His haptoglobin was 211 
which suggested that he did not have gemcitabine-induced 
hemolysis. The patient was transfused 1 unit of pRBCs on two 
separate occasions, ___ and ___.

#Hyponatremia: Sodium is 126 on admission, down from 132 on 
___. Possibly due to generalized fluid overload. The 
patient's urine sodium was 77 and osmolality was 635, which 
suggested that he was volume replete. The patient's serum sodium 
remained 127 at discharge.

#Pancreatic cancer: Patient initially on FOLFIRINOX 
chemotherapy, but CA ___ doubling time has significantly 
increased in the weeks prior to admission and there had been 
evidence of progression on imaging and clinically with abdominal 
distension, so the patient was recently started on 
gemcitabine/abraxane by Dr. ___ (C1D1 ___. On the day of 
discharge the patient had a chest CT at the request of Dr. 
___ further staging. During this admission we continued 
the patient's home filgrastim and creon. We continued his home 
supportive medications of oxycodone, ondansetron, and 
prochlorperazine, and loperamide PRN. We also continued his home 
protonix. He was discharged with a follow-up appointment with 
Dr. ___ in the process of being arranged.

#T2DM: The patient has been followed by ___. His chemotherapy 
course has been complicated in the past by hyperglycemia 
requiring adjustments in his insulin regimen. The patient was 
continued on his home lantus 10U QHS and his metformin was held 
and replaced with an insulin sliding scale. He did have some 
hyperglycemia during this admission requiring an extra dose of 
insulin. He was discharged back on his home antidiabetic 
regimen.

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 58-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with calf pain and abdominal pain. He has a past medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hepatitis C, and pancreatic cancer, which was recently diagnosed and treated with gemcitabine/abraxane. The patient's symptoms worsened over the past three days, and he was referred to the emergency department by his primary care physician. In the emergency department, the patient's vital signs were stable, and he was diagnosed with ascites and a thrombus in the main and right portal veins. He underwent a diagnostic and therapeutic paracentesis, which yielded 1.0 L of straw-colored ascitic fluid. The patient was also found to have a pancreatic mass and moderate volume ascites. He was treated with IV morphine sulfate, IV fluids, and IV ceftriaxone. The patient's medications at discharge included gemcitabine/abraxane, and he was scheduled to follow up with his oncologist for further treatment. ||endoftext||

Discharge Diagnosis:
Frozen Preliminary: Medulloblastoma 
Right cerebellar mass 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
Brain Tumor

Surgery
You underwent surgery to remove a brain lesion from your 
brain. 

Frozen preliminary was: Medulloblastoma
Please keep your incision dry until your staples are removed. 
You may shower at this time but keep your incision dry.
It is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to 
cover it when outside. 
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
You may experience headaches and incisional pain. 
You may also experience some post-operative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 
You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
Feeling more tired or restlessness is also common.
Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
Nausea and/or vomiting
Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
Seizures
Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

 
Followup Instructions:
___
target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 28-year-old male who was admitted to the Neurosurgery service with a chief complaint of headache, neck pain, and numbness in his left fingers. He had a history of knee surgery and wisdom teeth removal. He was allergic to amoxicillin. The patient presented with a progressively worsening headache, neck pain, and numbness in his left fingers over the last three weeks. He was transferred to the hospital from another emergency room and was found to have a right cerebellar mass on CT head. The patient underwent a suboccipital craniotomy for tumor resection and was diagnosed with a possible medulloblastoma, hemangioblastoma, or metastasis. At discharge, the patient was comfortable, oriented, and had normal neurological function. He was prescribed medications for pain control and was scheduled for follow-up appointments. ||endoftext||

age: 43. gender: F.

History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ yo F with a history of triple negative BRCA1+ 
breast cancer diagnosed in ___. She underwent bilateral 
mastectomy and chemotherapy at that time. She has been generally 
lost to follow-up but was hospitalized recently for shortness of 
breath and found to have recurrence of her cancer.  
 Body imaging showed extensive probable metastases in the thorax 
with adenopathy and numerous pulmonary nodules as well as some 
left lung segment collapse. She did not have large pleural or 
pericardial effusions. The abdomen was benign including the 
liver. Bone scan, however, showed numerous abnormalities 
suggesting skeletal metastases. Widespread skeletal involvement 
is somewhat uncommon in triple-negative cancers, but the bone 
scan compared to prior scans does show a marked change. Her 
tumor marker is mildly elevated. She has some hoarseness, which 
likely reflects left recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement given 
the high concentration of disease in her left upper chest.  

 She now comes in because reports that she has had a severe 
headache and nausea for the past 48 hours. She reports that she 
has been waking up with a headaches every morning this week; 
however, this headache has persisted since yesterday and has not 
resolved. She reports she has been feeling nauseous and has not 
been able to each much. Reports that today she "vomited up 
bile." She denies dizziness, lightheadedness, or syncope. 
Reports that she has had difficulty seeing out of her L eye and 
"can only see half a word" when she reads.  

 In the ED, she had a head CT that showed:  
 There are multiple intracranial metastatic lesions. A lesion in 
the right occipital lobe best seen on series 602 B image 31 
measures approximately 3.1 x 3.1 cm and is complicated by a 
small amount of intralesional hemorrhage. There is associated 
vasogenic edema. Additional lesions are seen, for example and 
extra-axial lesion on series 2, image 23 abutting the inner 
table of the frontal bone in a left para falcine location. A 
small hyperdense lesion at the left parietal vertex is seen on 
series 2, image 25. A lesion abutting the  
 frontal lobe is seen on series 2, image 13 measuring 
approximately 1.4 x 3.7 cm. There is no midline shift or 
downward herniation though there is asymmetric effacement of 
right cerebral sulci compared to the left.  
 She was evaluated by neurosurgery who recommended Keppra, 
Dexamethasone, keeping SBP<140, and MRI scan.  
 
 On arrival to the floor, patient is tired, but otherwise well 
appearing.  
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: A 10 point ROS was performed and was 
otherwise negative.  
 
Past Medical History:
PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY  
She initially presented in early ___ with a multicentric 
high-grade triple-negative left breast cancer. The largest focus 
of invasive cancer was 5 cm. There was no lymphovascular 
invasion and her four sentinel lymph nodes sampled at the time 
of mastectomy in ___ were negative. The contralateral 
prophylactic right mastectomy was negative pathologically.  
 BRCA testing showed a BRCA1 mutation.  
 Thus, she had an advanced left breast cancer which was 
multifocal but no lymph node spread while the right breast was 
negative. Following recovery from her mastectomy and her 
bilateral ___ flap reconstructions, a port was inserted and she 
began dose-dense cyclophosphamide and doxorubicin in early ___. She received four doses of dose-dense cyclophosphamide and 
doxorubicin followed by weekly paclitaxel. Dr. ___ was 
consulted, but did not feel that she required post mastectomy 
radiation therapy based on free margins, the absence of 
lymphovascular invasion and the absence of nodal involvement.  
 Following her chemotherapy there was no additional systemic 
therapy given because of her triple-negative status. We did 
strongly encourage her to have a prophylactic bilateral BSO, but 
she opted to defer that following completion of her other 
therapy. In fact, this was never done and she had a long 
interval where she did not ___ for routine followup here.  
 She was recently seen for shortness of breath. Re-staging 
showed recurrent disease.

HCV, no prior treatment  
h/o liver failure due to Acetaminophen toxicity  
h/o eating disorder

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ old woman with multicentric 
high-grade triple-negative BRCA1+ left breast cancer dx in ___, 
s/p bilateral mastectomy and treatment with cyclophosphamide, 
doxorubicin, and paclitaxel in ___, who presented with 
headache. CT of her head demonstrated multiple intracranial 
lesions concerning for metastasis, with hemorrhage in a R 
occipital lesion. Radiation-oncology, Neuro-oncology, and 
Neurosurgery were consulted. No role for surgery, althogh the 
patient was started on dexamethasone and levetiracetam. Repeat 
NCHCT without acute changes. She had an MRI which showed

with hemorrhagic component, consistent with intracranial 
metastatic disease. The largest of these lesions is extra-axial 
in in the left frontal lobe measuring up to 42 x 30 mm. The 
patient had an LP, with cytology pending prior to discharge to 
evaluate for leptomeningeal spread. She will follow-up with

Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for 
shortness of breath and headache. Unfortunately, a CT scan of 
your head showed that you had cancer that spread to your brain. 
An MRI also showed spread of your cancer to the brain. 
Radiation-Oncology, Neurosurgery, and Neuro-Oncology all 
evaluated you in the hospital. A lumbar puncture (LP) was 
performed to determine if there was any cancer in the fluid 
around your brain. Currently we are planning for your radiation 
as an outpatient and it is very important that you follow-up 
with Radiation-Oncology and Neuro-Oncology.

We started you on a medication called dexamethasone which helps 
with swelling and can treat nausea. Please continue to take this 
twice per day as prescribed. 

It was a pleasure taking care of you,
Your ___ Team

She has a history of triple-negative breast cancer diagnosed in the past, which has recurred. She underwent bilateral mastectomy and chemotherapy, but did not receive post-mastectomy radiation therapy. She was recently seen for shortness of breath and was found to have extensive metastatic disease in her thorax, abdomen, and bones. 

The patient's past medical history includes HCV, liver failure due to Acetaminophen toxicity, and an eating disorder. She has a family history of colon cancer and dementia. 

On admission, the patient's physical examination was normal, except for bronchial breath sounds on the left and mild tenderness in the left upper quadrant of her abdomen. 

The patient's laboratory results showed mild elevation of her tumor marker, and her imaging studies showed multiple intracranial metastatic lesions with hemorrhage. 

The patient was treated with Keppra, Dexamethasone, and was recommended to have an MRI scan. She was also advised to keep her blood pressure below 140 mmHg. 

At discharge, the patient's vital signs were stable, and her physical examination was normal, except for a left-sided peripheral vision defect and weakness in her upper extremities. ||endoftext||

CT Abd/Pel notable for

measuring 14.3 x 6.1 x 6.1 cm, slightly larger since ___, consistent with walled-off necrosis.  There is a large 
amount of air within the necrotic pancreas which is likely

approximately 5 mm

artery.

pseudoaneurysm.

post

and no 
retrograde flow to the area of the pseudoaneurysm. 

Superior mesenteric arteriogram demonstrates no active 
extravasation. 
  
Overall Imression:  
  
Pseudoaneurysm arising from a branch of the dorsal pancreatic 
artery 
successfully treated with coil embolization. 
  
RECOMMENDATION(S):  If the patient develops further bleeding, 
repeat 
angiography can be considered, to evaluate for refilling of the 
pseudoaneurysm. Additional angiography can also be performed of 
the 
gastroduodenal artery, which was slightly irregular in 
appearance, but did not have active extravasation on today's 
study.

without evidence of recurrent blood accumulation in cyst sac

who was admitted for scheduled EUS and cystgastrostomy. He was

sepsis after the procedure and was discovered during this 
admission to have pseudoaneurysm of the dorsal pancreatic artery 
for which he underwent coiling this admission

triglycerides WNL.

He has a history of severe pancreatitis, walled-off necrosis, splenic vein thrombosis, hypertension, and seasonal allergies. He is allergic to amoxicillin and sulfa. The patient's chief complaint is admission for observation following cystgastrostomy. During the procedure, an Axios stent was placed, and two double pigtail stents were placed through the Axios stent. The patient's past medical history includes severe pancreatitis, walled-off necrosis, splenic vein thrombosis, hypertension, and GERD. He has no family history of pancreatitis. The patient's physical exam was normal, with no acute distress. Laboratory results showed elevated lipase and amylase levels. Imaging studies revealed a 20 cm area of walled-off pancreatic necrosis and a pseudoaneurysm arising from a branch of the dorsal pancreatic artery, which was successfully treated with coil embolization. The patient was prescribed cipro and flagyl for 7 more days and was discharged to home. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:

1. Co-management by Renal Transplant team.

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1.  The foley was removed on POD#2 and the patient was 
voiding independently thereafter. The surgical dressing was 
changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean 
and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient 
was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout 
the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of 
discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling 
well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The 
patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity with posterior precautions. 
Walker or two crutches at all times for 6 weeks.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills.  

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not 
drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking 
these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets 
and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause 
constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take 
a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent this side 
effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of 
medication so that it can be refilled.  These medications cannot 
be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic 
or mailed to your house.  Please allow an extra 2 days if you 
would like your medication mailed to your home.

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.

6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five 
(5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at 
least four (4) weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues 
to be non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be 
removed will be taken out by the visiting nurse (___) or rehab 
facility two 
weeks after your surgery.

7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in four (4) weeks.

8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
motrin, etc).

9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  ___ 
STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.

10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed by the visiting 
nurse or rehab facility in two (2) weeks.

11. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at two weeks after 
surgery.

12. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated with walker or 2 
crutches at all times for six weeks.  Posterior precautions. No 
strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. 
 Mobilize frequently.

ROM - posterior precautions
Mobilize frequently

||startoftext|| The patient is a 56-year-old male who was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service with a chief complaint of right hip pain. He had a history of atrial fibrillation, pericardial effusion, liver-kidney transplant, hypercholesterolemia, anxiety, hypertension, emphysema, obstructive sleep-disordered breathing, and tobacco addiction. He was allergic to Rofecoxib.

The patient underwent a right total hip replacement procedure and tolerated the surgery well. His postoperative course was uneventful, with controlled pain, stable vital signs, and acceptable hematocrit. He was discharged to rehab with instructions to follow up with his primary physician.

The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including enoxaparin, docusate sodium, bisacodyl, magnesium hydroxide, senna, multivitamin, calcium carbonate, cholecalciferol, albuterol, amlodipine, mycophenolate mofetil, atorvastatin, metoprolol tartrate, gabapentin, omeprazole, flecainide, paroxetine, tiotropium bromide, sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim, nicotine, tacrolimus, acetaminophen, oxycodone, and lidocaine.

The patient's discharge diagnosis was right hip osteonecrosis, and his discharge condition was stable with clear mental status, alert and interactive level of consciousness, and ambulatory status with assistance or aid. ||endoftext||

You were admitted to the hospital because you had several fevers

||startoftext|| The patient is a 65-year-old female who was admitted due to fever. She has a history of locally advanced pancreatic cancer on palliative chemotherapy and was recently admitted to another hospital for cellulitis of the right lower extremity. She completed her antibiotics as an outpatient and had clinical improvement with improvement in functional status. The patient started on paclitaxel/gemcitabine on a previous day and had an episode of diarrhea, which resolved with Imodium. She was found to have a white blood cell count of 18k and was advised to come to the emergency department.

The patient's past medical history includes pancreatic cancer stage III, depression, gastroesophageal reflux, and skin cancers. She has a family history of myocardial infarction in her mother and sister, as well as a brother with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator and a history of arrhythmia.

The patient's physical examination revealed a pleasant and comfortable patient with no significant rashes or ecchymoses. Her laboratory results showed mild elevation in alkaline phosphatase and a white blood cell count of 17.9. Imaging studies showed a known pancreatic head mass and cholelithiasis without sonographic evidence of acute cholecystitis.

The patient was diagnosed with fever and was treated with Vanc/Cefepime. She was also prescribed medications at discharge, including Vanc/Cefepime and antibiotics. ||endoftext||

diagnostic paracentesis completed showing no signs of SBP, 
followed by ___ guided therapeutic paracentesis. Abdominal pain 
controlled initially with oxycodone as needed, and then 
transitioned to tramadol. Her hospital course was then notable

in the setting of her variceal bleed as well as for her 
enterococcal UTI. She is discharged with instructions for blood

hepatologist.

ceftriaxone. Ceftriaxone was continued for 7 day course. Repeat 
blood counts remained stable and she was asymptomatic with

resumed on furosemide and spironolactone.

hypotension concerning for infection. Patient received empiric 
IV vancomycin (___-), which was continued for a 7 day course 
for complicated UTI (last day ___.

given worsening BPs. Complicated by ascites, varices, 
encepholpathy, abdominal pain. No history of SBP. On 
lactulose/rifaxmin at home although unclear compliance. Diarrhea 
at baseline. Recent cold, no reversal of sleep/wake. Not 
encepholopathic. Actively drinking; therefore not a transplant 
candidate. Patient was continued on lactulose, rifaximin.  
Patient underwent thepareutic paracentesis in the ICU with 
removal of 3L. The Lasix/sprinolactone in the setting of her 
recent active GI bleeding and hypotension, resumed later on the 
hospital course, along with lactuose and rifaximin.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 45-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with hematemesis. She has a history of EtOH abuse and cirrhosis, and has undergone several paracenteses and EGDs in the past. She was actively drinking and presented to the emergency department with six episodes of hematemesis, as well as worsening abdominal pain, acute reaccumulation of ascites, and poor appetite. 

Upon admission, her physical exam revealed a pale and distended abdomen, and she was started on octreotide and pantoprazole. She was transferred to the MICU and intubated for an emergent EGD. 

Her past medical history includes EtOH abuse, EtOH cirrhosis, hypertension, and a history of liver disease. She has also had several admissions for decompensation due to ascites and has undergone several paracenteses and EGDs. 

Her discharge medications include octreotide, pantoprazole, and lactulose. ||endoftext||

She has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and depression, and has had multiple ulcerations and debridements in the past. She presented to the emergency department with a one-week history of increasing redness and pain in her left heel, which had worsened the day before her admission. She was treated with IV antibiotics and a culture of the wound was taken. The culture grew coagulase-negative Staphylococcus aureus and diptheroids, and she was started on Vancomycin and PO cipro and flagyl pending culture data. She was also treated with wet-to-dry dressing changes and remained afebrile with stable vital signs throughout her admission. She was discharged home on PO Bactrim and instructed to perform daily wet-to-dry dressing changes and follow up with her doctor in a week.

The patient's medications on admission included Lisinopril, Metformin, Oxybutynin Chloride, Percocet, Simvastatin, Spironolactone, Trazodone, and Multivitamin. Her discharge medications included Sulfamethoxazole-Trimethoprim, Budesonide-Formoterol, Lisinopril, Metformin, Simvastatin, Spironolactone, Trazodone, Fexofenadine, Multivitamin, Vitamin E, Ferrous Sulfate, and Oxybutynin Chloride.

The patient's discharge diagnosis was left heel ulcer and cellulitis, and her discharge condition was clear and coherent mental status, alert and interactive level of consciousness, and ambulatory-independent activity status. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 53-year-old male who was admitted with acute kidney injury on chronic kidney disease. He has a history of renal transplant in 2007 for IgA nephropathy and has been non-adherent to his terazosin medication for the past three months. He presented with a two-week history of severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which resolved before admission. His creatinine level was elevated at 4.7, and he was found to have a potassium level of 5.2. He was given kayexelate and maintained a good urine output. The patient's past medical history includes IgA nephropathy, chronic MRSA osteomyelitis, multiple skin cancers, hypertension, enlarged prostate, restless leg syndrome, GERD, gout, hypertriglyceridemia, and anxiety. He was diagnosed with interval progression of severe hydronephrosis of the transplant kidney and cortical thinning. He was treated with a Cudet foley catheter, kayexelate, and hydralazine, and was discharged with a foley in place and urology follow-up. He was also restarted on terazosin and lasix was stopped. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of NASH cirrhosis (MELD 31, Child Class C) and previous decompensations, including portal hypertension, variceal bleeds, diuretic refractory ascites, and SBP. She presented with abdominal pain, worsening distension, and nausea, which was secondary to volume overload. She had a history of E. coli bacteremia, which was treated with IV meropenem and then narrowed to cipro based on sensitivities. The patient also had a chronic rash on her abdomen and lower back, which was itchy.

The patient's past medical history includes stage II-III lower esophageal variceal bleeds, hyperlipidemia, and chronic R pleural effusion. She had a liver biopsy that showed stage 4 fibrosis.

The patient's physical exam showed a large distension with e/o fluid on percussion, minimal tenderness, and umbilical hernia. Her vital signs were stable, and she had no signs of confusion, melena, BRBPR, or N/V.

The patient's laboratory results showed mild anemia, mild hyponatremia, and mild jaundice. Her liver function tests were mildly elevated, and her albumin level was low.

The patient's diagnosis was decompensated NASH cirrhosis with symptomatic large volume ascites, E. coli bacteremia, and portal hypertension. She was treated with diuretics, antibiotics, and vitamin D repletion.

The patient's medications at discharge included cipro 500mg BID for 14 days, followed by cipro 500mg daily for SBP prophylaxis indefinitely. She was also prescribed vitamin D repletion and was advised to follow up with her dermatologist for her psoriasis. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with h/o HTN, diabetes, and asthma presents with cough, sore 
throat and sensation throat swelling x1 day. 

# Airway swelling: Patient given decadron, diphenhydramine and 
famotidine at OSH for concern of angioedema and upper airway 
swelling, transferred here for ENT and anesthesia evaluation 
should intubation be required. Receieved nebulized racemic 
epinephrine in the ED here. Upon arrival to the MICU the patient 
was subjectively improved. The etiology of his angioedema was 
unclear, but there was concern for contribution of symptoms from 
ACEi. As a result, his ACEi was discontinued while in the MICU, 
and was not restarted upon discharge. He was treated with 
steroids, benadryl, and famotidine. ENT evaulation on the 
morning of discharge revealed resolution of edema and he was 
discharged home from the MICU. 

# Cough/Rhinorrhea: Patient's complaints of cough and rhinorrhea 
recently were most likely due to URI. CXR was without evidence 
of PNA. He was treated with saline nasal spray while in the 
MICU.

steroids and epinephrine. Appears to be sinus tachycardia on 
monitor. Troponin from the ED was negative.

# Asthma: Upon arrival to the MICU he was noted to have diffuse 
wheezes on exam. He was given Albuterol nebulizers as needed.

# Diabetes: No active issues. He was discharged on his home dose 
of metformin. 

# HTN: Lisinopril was discontinued upon arrival to the MICU. His 
blood pressure remained within the normal range. He was not 
restarted on any additional anti-hypertensive medications prior 
to discharge.

antihypertensive medication, given discontinuation of

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

 It was a pleasure taking care of you during your 
hospitalization.  You were admitted because of swelling in your 
throat (angioedema) that was causing difficulty breathing.  You 
were admitted to the Medical Intensive Care Unit so we could 
closely monitor your breathing.  You did very well overnight and 
were treated with steroids, benadryl, and famotidine 
(anti-histamines) which helped to reduce the swelling.  We think 
this swelling was a side effect of your lisinopril.  You should 
not take lisinopril or other medicines in this class (ACE 
inhibitors) ever again as the swelling could happen again 
causing difficulty breathing.  You will need to talk to your PCP 
about starting ___ different blood pressure medicine.  You should 
also talk to your PCP about seeing an Allergy specialist to 
determine if there is another reason for the swelling you had.
  You were also wheezing when you were admitted.  This was 
because of your asthma.  You improved after a treatment with 
albuterol.  Your asthma can be better controlled if you take 
your Flovent inhaler every day - this helps control asthma 
symptoms.  We will give you a prescription for an albuterol 
inhaler that you should only use when you are having symptoms 
from your asthma.

___
target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 49-year-old male who presented to the hospital with a chief complaint of throat swelling. He has a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension. He was taking lisinopril for hypertension, but it was discontinued during his hospital stay due to concerns about its potential contribution to his angioedema. The patient's symptoms included a sensation of throat swelling, rhinorrhea, and a cough productive of whitish sputum. He was treated with steroids, benadryl, and famotidine, and his angioedema resolved. He was also diagnosed with asthma and treated with albuterol nebulizers as needed. The patient was discharged home with a diagnosis of angioedema and asthma, and was prescribed medications including diphenhydramine, famotidine, prednisone, albuterol inhaler, fluticasone propionate, and metformin. ||endoftext||

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
It has been a privilege to take care of you ___ 
___.
.
You were hospitalized because your heart was beating very slowly 
because of an abnormality in the electrical wiring system of 
your heart; you have a condition known as complete heart block.
.
You underwent an emergency procedure to implant a pacemaker into 
your chest that provides your heart with a regular electrical 
current to ensure that it beats at the correct rhythm. You 
tolerated the procedure well and the pacemaker is functioning 
correctly. This pacemaker will hopefully help to prevent 
recurrence of the fatigue that you have been experiencing.
.
You should avoid raising your arms above your head, and should 
also avoid heavy lifting, for the next several weeks.  Do not 
remove the steri-strips over the site where the pacemaker was 
placed.

Implantation of a pacemaker is surgical procedure, which is why 
you will require antibiotics to prevent infections. The 
following is your antibiotic regimen:
# START: Clindamycin 300 mg every 6h for 1 day
.
Otherwise, your heart regimen is unchanged. Your current heart 
regimen is the following:
# CONTINUE: Torsemide 60 mg twice daily
# CONTINUE: Lisinopril 10 mg daily
# CONTINUE: Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg sublingual tablet as needed for 
CP
**Take up to 3 tablets 5 minutes apart then call ___ if pain 
does not resolve.**
# CONTINUE: Cholestyramine 4 gram packet daily
# CONTINUE: Ezetimibe 10 mg daily
.
We decreased the dose of your Gabapentin to 300mg daily. This 
dose is based on your kidney function levels.  You can discuss 
the dosing with your primary care doctor next week.

Please continue to take all of your other medications as 
previously prescribed. 
.
Please attend the follow-up appointments detailed below.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 57-year-old female who presented to the emergency department with symptoms of syncope and was found to have a high-grade multi-level AV block with a heart rate of 40 beats per minute. She has a history of bradycardia, diastolic congestive heart failure, and chronic kidney disease. She was admitted to the hospital and underwent a pacemaker placement procedure, which was successful. At the time of discharge, she was hemodynamically stable with a heart rate of 40 beats per minute. She was prescribed several medications, including Torsemide, Lisinopril, Cholestyramine, Ezetimibe, ASA, Albuterol Sulfate Nebs, ADVAIR DISKUS, SINGULAIR, Fexofenadine, LORATADINE, and TRAZODON. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have fracture of the left hip, and was admitted to the 
orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the 
operating room on ___ for ORIF with TFN, which the patient 
tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please see the 
separately dictated operative report. 

After the procedure the patient was taken from the OR to the 
PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory recovery from 
anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was 
initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and 
progressed to a regular diet and oral medications. The patient 
was given ___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per 
routine. The patient's home medications were continued 
throughout this hospitalization. The ___ hospital course 
was otherwise unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
weight bearing as tolerated in the left lower extremity, and 
will be discharged on Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis. The patient 
will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough 
discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and 
expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the 
office or return to the hospital, and all questions were 
answered. The patient was also given written instructions 
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

tablet,extended
release 24 hr. 1 (One) tablet(s) by mouth daily -  (Prescribed 
by
Other Provider)

by mouth daily -  (Prescribed by Other Provider)

weekly -  (Dose adjustment - no new Rx)

Extended Care

___

left intertrochanteric hip fracture 

 
Discharge Condition:
AVSS
NAD
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

LLE: Incision well approximated. Dressing clean and dry. Fires 
FHL, ___, TA, GCS. SILT ___ n distributions. Toes WWP 
distally.

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:
- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- weight bearing as tolerated and range of motion as tolerated 
in left lower extremity 

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

PAIN MEDICATIONS INSTRUCTIONS:
1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock.
2)  Add your prescribed narcotics as needed for increased pain. 
Start weaning the narcotic medication once you get home. 

This is an example on how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.

3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please continue home Xarelto daily

WOUND CARE:
- Your incision is covered with a dry dressing. Please change 
the dressing daily. If there is no drainage, you may leave your 
incision open to the air. If you are continuing to have 
drainage, you may place a dry dressing over the incision as 
needed.
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.

THIS PATIENT IS EXPECTED TO REQUIRE <30 DAYS OF REHAB

Physical Therapy:
weight bearing as tolerated and range of motion as tolerated in 
left lower extremity 

Activity:  Out of bed w/ assist 
Ambulate twice daily if patient able
 Right lower extremity:  Full weight bearing
 Left lower extremity:  Full weight bearing
Encourage turning, deep breathing and coughing qhour when awake. 
 

Treatments Frequency:
Any staples or superficial sutures you have are to remain in 
place for at least 2 weeks postoperatively.  Incision may be 
left open to air unless actively draining.  If draining, you may 
apply a gauze dressing secured with paper tape.  You may shower 
and allow water to run over the wound, but please refrain from 
bathing for at least 4 weeks postoperatively.

Call your surgeon's office with any questions.  

 
Followup Instructions:
___
target: ||startoftext|| The patient is an 89-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a left intertrochanteric fracture after falling from standing and landing on her left hip. She has a history of atrial fibrillation, mild COPD, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. She is allergic to sulfa, dicloxacillin, and Bactrim. The patient underwent left hip ORIF with TFN and was discharged with a diagnosis of left intertrochanteric hip fracture. She was prescribed medications including Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis, and was instructed to take Tylenol and narcotics as needed for pain. She was also advised to continue her home medications, except for those that were adjusted during her hospital stay. The patient was discharged in stable condition, with her incision well approximated and dressing clean and dry. She was instructed to follow up with her surgeon and to take her medications as prescribed. ||endoftext||
