age: 81. gender: M.  
Name:  ___                      Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Seizures
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
endotracheal intubation
 
History of Present Illness:
___ (AKA ___ is an ___ man with
intellectual disability, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia who
presents as a transfer, intubated for generalized seizure. 

He lives in a group home with 24 hour nursing care due to severe
intellectual disability.  At baseline he is minimally verbal
(able to stutter "Go to bed" or "Go eat"), and is pushed around
in a wheelchair.  He is able to feed himself puréed food.

He had been in his usual state of health, when this morning he
was noted by his caretaker to have small area of bruising along
the lateral edge of his left eyelid, and this progressed to
include his entire left eyelid so she took him to the hospital. 
On arrival he had generalized tonic-clonic convulsions 
consisting
of leftward eye deviation, eyelid fluttering, tongue biting,
foaming at the mouth. It lasted >15 minutes and was unable to be
aborted after a total of 4 mg of lorazepam, so he was intubated
and placed on propofol.  Labs were notable for lactate of 7.9,
prolactin of 93, and anemia with hemoglobin 10.2.  Temperature
was 96.6°F.  CT of the head, C-spine, and face showed no acute
trauma or other process. CT head showed diffusely decreased 
brain
volume consistent with his history of intellectual disability. 

He was transferred to ___ for further management. LP was
attempted but unable to be performed in the ED due to severe
kyphosis. He was started on ceftriaxone, vancomycin, and
acyclovir. 

He has no history of seizure.  There was no immediate history of
trauma as he is observed around the clock, except when asleep. 
However he did present to OSH on ___ for bruises on his chest
and dehydration.  No sick contacts.

 
Past Medical History:
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia 
Intellectual developmental disorder
Dementia
Incontinence
GERD
Rosacea
Seborrheic dermatitis
Bladder spasm
History of appendectomy

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
n/c
 
Physical Exam:
===admission exam===
-General: Intubated and sedated. 
-HEENT: Ecchymoses along inferior margin of upper eyelids.
-Cardiac: RRR. 
-Pulmonary: Intubated. 
-Extremities: No cyanosis, clubbing, or edema bilaterally. 
-Skin: No rashes or other lesions noted.

NEUROLOGIC EXAM:
-Mental Status: No eye opening to voice or noxious stimulation.
Withdrew to noxious in all four extremities. 

-Cranial Nerves: PERRL 2-1.5mm, VOR-. 
-Sensorimotor: Localized withdrawal in all four extremities.

===discharge exam===

-General: Awake, alert, lying in bed listening to headphones
-HEENT: Healing ecchymosis of L upper eyelid
-Cardiac: RRR. 
-Pulmonary: No increased WOB
-Extremities: Swelling of the R hand without tenderness or 
erythema. 
-Skin: Healing incision site at ___ site on R chest. Healing 
bruises from IV on R forearm. No tenderness over pectoral 
muscles. 

NEUROLOGIC EXAM:
-Mental Status: Regards and tracks examiner. Occassionally says 
"no". Does not follow commands.

-Cranial Nerves: PERRL, EOMI grossly.
-Motor: Holds upper extremities crossed. Strong motor strength 
resisting examiner in upper extremities. Bilateral lower 
extremities withdraw locally to stimuli, without anti-gravity 
movement at hips. Increased tone in all extremities, arms held 
in flexion.
-Sensory: intact to light touch in all extremities
-Gait: non-ambulatory
 
Pertinent Results:
===pertinent labs===

___ 08:30PM BLOOD WBC-9.3 RBC-3.39* Hgb-11.0* Hct-32.4* 
MCV-96 MCH-32.4* MCHC-34.0 RDW-13.4 RDWSD-46.9* Plt ___
___ 08:30PM BLOOD ASA-NEG Ethanol-NEG Acetmnp-NEG 
Tricycl-NEG
___ 08:51PM BLOOD Lactate-1.5
___ 08:30PM URINE Color-Straw Appear-Hazy* Sp ___
___ 08:30PM URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-TR* 
Glucose-NEG Ketone-NEG Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-6.5 Leuks-SM*
___ 08:30PM URINE RBC-1 WBC-23* Bacteri-NONE Yeast-NONE 
Epi-0
___ 08:30PM URINE CastGr-5* CastHy-9*
___ 08:30PM URINE bnzodzp-NEG barbitr-NEG opiates-NEG 
cocaine-NEG amphetm-NEG oxycodn-NEG mthdone-NEG
___ 01:19PM CEREBROSPINAL FLUID (CSF) TNC-1 RBC-181* 
Polys-38 ___ Macroph-16
___ 01:18PM CEREBROSPINAL FLUID (CSF) TNC-1 RBC-550* 
Polys-37 Bands-1 ___ Monos-22 ___ Macroph-8
___ 01:18PM CEREBROSPINAL FLUID (CSF) TotProt-54* 
Glucose-57
CSF HSV PCR: negative

===imaging/other data===

XR Abdomen ___:
There is no bowel obstruction or dilated bowel loops.  Moderate 
too severe 
amount of stool within the colon, and rectosigmoid, indicate 
constipation. 

XR hand ___:
No fracture or dislocation is seen.  Mild degenerative changes 
are seen 
involving the distal interphalangeal joints of the second and 
fifth finger as well as the proximal interphalangeal joints of 
the third fourth and fifth fingers.  No bone erosion or 
periostitis is identified. No suspicious lytic or sclerotic 
lesion is identified. No soft tissue calcification or 
radio-opaque foreign bodies are detected.

MRI/MRA Head and Neck ___:
loss FLAIR and diffuse atrophy. 
2. FLAIR hyperintense deep white matter and periventricular 
lesions are 
nonspecific, but likely represent sequela of chronic small 
vessel ischemic 
disease. 
3. Moderate to severe atherosclerotic narrowing at the origin of 
the internal carotid arteries, left greater than right.  No 
additional flow limiting stenosis, thrombosis, dissection or 
aneurysm greater than 3 mm. 
4. Cutaneous lesion at the right inferior occipital scalp 
suggestive of 
sebaceous cyst.

CT TORSO ___:
1. Findings suggestive of left pectoralis muscular injury/tear 
with evolving intramuscular hematoma.  Less likely 
considerations include myonecrosis or abscess. 
2. No evidence of acute fracture. 
3. Obstruction of lingular bronchi by mucous plugging.  Diffuse 
airway wall thickening compatible with bronchitis. 
4. Thickened and hyperemic bladder wall with diverticula 
suggestive of chronic outlet obstruction, perhaps from an 
enlarged prostate.  Correlation with urinalysis, however, is 
recommended to exclude active infection. 
5. Moderate diffuse colonic stool load with a large rectal stool 
ball. 
6. Small hiatal hernia.  Fluid-filled esophagus suggests 
esophageal 
dysmotility.  Enteric tube tip in stomach. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is an ___ yo M with history of intellectual disability, 
HTN, HLD, who presented to the hospital with facial bruising and 
had first time seizure in the ED >15 minutes, and required 
Ativan, keppra, and intubation with propofol drip to resolve. He 
was found to have a UTI which likely contributed to the seizure, 
and had decreased brain volume and atrophy on MRI which lowers 
seizure threshold. He will continue on keppra for seizure 
treatment. 

#Seizure/encephalopathy
The patient was admitted to the NeuroICU on midazolam gtt and 
fentanyl. No further seizure like activity was noted. He was 
continued on Keppra 500 mg BID. He was initially continued on 
broad spectrum coverage for meningoencephalitis, though 
antibacterials were discontinued with an LP showing 1 WBC. He 
was continued on acyclovir until HSV PCR negative on ___. 
MRI showed global brain atrophy, without acute lesions or other 
structural problems. EEG showed generalized slowing in the ___ 
hz range with no seizures or epileptiform dischages. He was 
weaned to extubate on hospital day 3. Urine culture from 
admission turned positive, showed >100k CFU EColi, he was 
started on ceftriaxone, however sensitivities showed CTX 
resistance, and he was switched to IV Unasyn on ___. He was 
discharged on augmentin 875mg BID for a total 10 day course 
(ends on ___.

#Hypotension
Home BP medications were held as he had SBP90s while intubated 
on sedating medications. His SBP ran in the 100-110 range after 
extubation, so home medications continued to be held.

# Constipation
On ___ he vomited dinner, and again vomited breakfast on ___. He 
had benign abdominal exam with KUB that showed large amount of 
stool. He received Miralax, bisacodyl, lactulose, milk of 
magnesia, and fleet enema x 2 and had multiple bowel movements. 
He was able to tolerate PO prior to discharge back to nursing 
facility. He was discharged on new medications for constipation.

# Pectoralis tear: CT chest showed an incidental finding of a 
left pectoralis muscular injury/tear with evolving intramuscular 
hematoma. Patient denied pain at that site and had full range of 
motion of the shoulder. Orthopedics was consulted who 
recommended nonoperative management with rest, ice, and pain 
control. 

-----------------
Transitional Issues:
- restart anti-hypertensives as indicated
- continue augmentin through ___ (total 10 day course)
- follow up with neurology
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Donepezil 10 mg PO QHS 
2. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
3. BusPIRone 10 mg PO BID 
4. Creon 12 1 CAP PO TID W/MEALS 
5. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY 
6. amLODIPine 2.5 mg PO DAILY 
7. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Amoxicillin-Clavulanic Acid ___ mg PO BID urinary tract 
infection Duration: 9 Days 
Please take augmentin through ___  
RX *amoxicillin-pot clavulanate 875 mg-125 mg 1 tab by mouth 
twice a day Disp #*19 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  LevETIRAcetam 500 mg PO BID 
RX *levetiracetam 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp 
#*60 Tablet Refills:*5 
3.  Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY 
Hold for loose stools.  
RX *polyethylene glycol 3350 [Miralax] 17 gram/dose 17 Gram by 
mouth Daily Refills:*5 
4.  Senna 17.2 mg PO BID 
Hold for loose stools.  
RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 1 (One) Tab by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*5 
5.  Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY  
6.  BusPIRone 10 mg PO BID  
7.  Creon 12 1 CAP PO TID W/MEALS  
8.  Donepezil 10 mg PO QHS  
9.  Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H  
10. HELD- amLODIPine 2.5 mg PO DAILY  This medication was held. 
Do not restart amLODIPine until instructed by your doctor
11. HELD- Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY  This 
medication was held. Do not restart Metoprolol Succinate XL 
until instructed by your doctor

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Status Epilepticus

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the Neurology service at ___ due to a 
prolonged seizure requiring intensive care. The seizure was 
likely caused by a urinary tract infection, which we treated. We 
did not find any new abnormalities in your brain imaging.

Medication changes:
Please take keppra to prevent seizures.
Please take augmentin through ___ (to complete a 10 day 
course).

Please continue all other home medications as prescribed.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor and neurologist.

Sincerely,

Your ___ Neurology Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___
target: ||startoftext|| The patient is an 81-year-old male with a chief complaint of seizures. He has a history of intellectual disability, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He was admitted to the hospital after presenting with facial bruising and having a generalized seizure that lasted over 15 minutes. He was intubated and placed on propofol due to the severity of the seizure. Laboratory results showed lactate levels of 7.9 and prolactin levels of 93, indicating a possible encephalopathy. A CT scan of the head showed diffuse decreased brain volume consistent with his history of intellectual disability. He was started on ceftriaxone, vancomycin, and acyclovir for possible meningoencephalitis. He was also found to have a urinary tract infection, which likely contributed to the seizure. He was treated with keppra for seizure treatment and was continued on broad-spectrum antibiotics until a lumbar puncture showed only one white blood cell. He was eventually weaned off propofol and extubated. ||endoftext||

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 60-year-old male who was admitted to the neurosurgery service after falling and experiencing a loss of consciousness for approximately 10 minutes. He was found lying on the ground by his wife and friend, and he does not recall the events surrounding the fall. He was taken to the hospital and evaluated, and a CT scan revealed a left frontal punctate hemorrhage and resolving subarachnoid hemorrhage, as well as multiple facial fractures.

The patient's past medical history includes a meniscectomy in his right knee and high cholesterol. He has no allergies or adverse reactions listed. His diagnosis is a traumatic brain injury with facial fractures.

The patient underwent no surgical procedures during his hospital stay. He was prescribed several medications at discharge, including acetaminophen for pain and fever, simvastatin for cholesterol, amoxicillin-pot clavulanate for infection prophylaxis, docusate sodium for constipation, and oxycodone for pain.

The patient's physical examination was normal, with the exception of some ecchymosis and lacerations on his face and scalp. His neurological examination was also normal, with no signs of seizure activity or incontinence. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital after experiencing an asystolic arrest and complete heart block while participating in cardiac rehabilitation. He has a history of aortic stenosis, which was treated with aortic valve replacement, and conduction system disease with a combination of right bundle branch block, left anterior hemiblock, and first-degree heart block. He also has a history of mantle cell lymphoma, which is currently in remission and being treated with ibrutinib.

The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, dyslipidemia, and low testosterone, as well as a history of syncope and colon polyps. He has no history of premature coronary artery disease.

The patient's allergies include hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, lovastatin, and Arestin. He has no known adverse reactions to medications.

The patient's diagnosis is complete heart block, which was likely caused by increased vagal tone after exercise. He was treated with a pacemaker placement and was started on metoprolol XL 25mg to prevent further atrial tachycardia.

The patient's medications at discharge include metoprolol XL 25mg and antibiotics for one week. He will also require a D-stat for hemostasis and an antibiotic pouch due to his increased risk of infection.

The patient's physical exam was normal, with no acute distress, and his laboratory results were within normal limits. ||endoftext||

scarring, unchanged. New transvenous right ventricular pacer

pneumothorax or mediastinal widening. Lungs are grossly clear.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo female with history of HTN, IDDM, NiCMY, nonobstructing 
CAD, and ESRD on HD admitted after cardiac arrest with cooling 
protocol found to be hypokalemic with chronic prolonged qtc and 
polymorphic VT now extubated and s/p placement of single chamber 
ICD.
.
ACTIVE DIAGNOSES:
.
# Cardiac arrest s/p ICD placement: Pt had VT to Vfib arrest at 
dialysis center assessed as being the result of baseline 
prolonged QT interval (chronic per old EKG's obtained from ___) 
in the setting of electrolyte shifts during dialysis, most 
notably hypokalemia. Our thinking was that hypokalemia 
predisposed her to early after depolarizations with R on T 
phenomena making her more likely to have a degenerating rhythm 
due to her long QT. She had a long and eventful hospital course 
including undergoing arctic sun cooling and re-warming, 
successful extubation following prior failed attempt (she 
required re-intubation due to mucous plugging), and gradual 
recovery of her baseline mental status. She required frequent 
work with ___ and speech and swallow to resume PO intake. She was 
dialyzed in-house by the renal team who recommended she be 
dialyzed using a high K bath in the future to maintain her K 
around 5. Additionally, EP was consulted and after a significant 
amount of consideration and deliberation it was determined that 
she would benefit from a single chamber ICD which was placed 
despite concerns regarding her multiple comorbidities. She had 
evidence of significant ectopy on telemetry throughout her 
hospitalization including frequent PVC's and occasional runs of 
NSVT. She was discharged to rehab for continued recovery of her 
physical function. ICD dressing was removed on ___ and steri 
strips should stay in place until after her ICD check on 
___. 
.
# ESRD ON HD: Stable. She was maintained on her MWF dialysis 
schedule with high K buffer with goal K of 5. She did not have 
any significant arrythmias during dialysis but during one 
session she rolled onto the dialysis needle and punctured her 
graft. Doppler study was obtained which demonstrated her graft 
was intact and vascular surgery evaluated and stated it was okay 
for further dialysis. She has a large resolving hematoma 
proximal to the fistula. 
.
# Poor PO Intake/Severe Physical Deconditioning: Pt worked with 
speech and swallow almost daily to enhance her ability to take 
in nutrition by mouth. She was also seen by the nutrition 
service as it was felt she would be aided in her physical 
recovery with improved nutritional status. She was discharged to 
a rehab facility to aid in recovery of her physical functional 
status.
.
CHRONIC DIAGNOSES:
.
# Insulin dependent diabetes mellitus: Stable. She was managed 
in-house on a combination of long acting and humalog sliding 
scale. She is very sensitive to insulin and has had episodes of 
hypoglycemia. 
.
# HTN: Stable. On admission she had an unconventional 
antihypertensive regimen including significant doses of 
clonidine and hydralazine. She was gradually tapered off her 
regimen and it was replaced with carvedilol and lisinopril.
.
# CAD:  History of nonobstructive CAD but without ischemic 
changes on EKG's and without positive cardiac enzymes. She was 
treated with aspirin and atorvastatin as well as her blood 
pressure regimen above.
. 
# Chronic Diastolic Congestive Heart Failure:  History of 
non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with EF 45%. Her TSH was wnls and 
her HIV negative. She was treated with a heart failure regimen 
including carvedilol and lisinopril.
.  
# Hypothyroidism: Her TSH was wnl's on admission. Her home 
synthroid was held as her history of hypothyroidism was 
questionable and it was unclear if it played any role in her 
cardiac excitability and subsequent cardiac arrest. Following 
her recovery, her TSH was checked once again and was found to be 
3.0 and she was re-started on her home synthroid.
.
# Chronic back pain: Pt with hx of chronic low back pain on 
narcotics as a home med but was oftentimes very somnolent, 
especially when taking these medications so they were 
discontinued. She infrequently complained of pain which was 
treated conservatively with tylenol and ibuprofen. 
.
# Questionable History of Epilepsy: Pt with questionable history 
of epilepsy on keppra as a home medication. She underwent EEG 
testing for >24 hours without any epileptiform discharges and 
there was concern that prior episodes of syncope (cardiogenic or 
otherwise) had been misinterpreted as epilepsy. Her keppra was 
held given her initially cloudy mental status and she did not 
have any seizure-like activity during her lengthy admission. 
Keppra was restarted at discharge but pt should see a 
neurologist in follow up to assess if this medication is truly 
needed. 
.
# Anxiety: Pt described significant anxiety related to her 
medical condition and trivial things such as fear of the dark. 
She was seen by the psychiatry team who recommended small 
standing doses of ativan (a home med) which was attempted but 
oftentimes left her somnolent and difficult to evaluate. These 
medications were held and her mental status improved 
significantly.
.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
.
#She will need close supervision during dialysis and will need a 
high K bath to maintain K at goal of 5.
.
#She will need device clinic follow-up for her new single 
chamber ICD. Given her severe diabetes and ESRD, she is at 
increased risk of complications related to her device including 
pocket infections and should be monitored carefully.
.
#She will need to AVOID QT PROLONGING MEDICATIONS as these can 
cause a life-threatening arrythmia to occur in her given her 
underlying prolonged QT interval
.
#She will need significant rehabilitation as she is severely 
deconditioned
.
#She will need close follow up with her primary care doctor to 
tackle her ___ social and medical issues. Attempts were made to 
attempt that process by carefully clarifying her home 
medications, elements of her medical history which seemed 
questionable, and addressing her polypharmacy by eliminating 
unnecessary medications.
.
#She will likely need an outpatient social worker to help her 
cope with her multiple medical issues

Your heart stopped because of a dangerous heart rhythm called 
ventricular fibrillation. You were brought to ___ and your 
body temperature was cooled to help your heart recover. You have 
recovered well and we have placed an internal defibrillator that 
will shock you if your heart has the dangerous rhythm again. You 
will need to take antibiotics for a few days to prevent and 
infection at the site and return every 6 months to get the 
defibrillator checked. 
.
We made the following changes to your medicines:

mononitrate, keppra, iron, simvastatin, phoslo, metoclopramide,

She has a history of hypertension, diabetes, non-obstructive coronary artery disease, and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) requiring hemodialysis. She was found to be unresponsive and pulseless, but was successfully resuscitated with cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and defibrillation. She was intubated and sedated, and was started on amiodarone for arrhythmias.

The patient has a history of allergies to penicillins, amoxicillin, clindamycin, and other antibiotics. She has also had a recent viral infection and has been taking various medications, including blood pressure medications, antidiabetic medications, and antihypertensive medications.

The patient's physical examination revealed a sedated and intubated patient with low tone, elevated jugular venous pressure, and bilateral breath sounds. Her laboratory results showed elevated blood glucose, creatinine, and urea nitrogen levels, as well as abnormal liver function tests.

The patient's diagnosis is cardiac arrest due to ventricular tachycardia, and she was treated with amiodarone and other medications. She was also started on a cooling protocol to reduce her body temperature.

The patient's medications at discharge include amiodarone, propofol, and other medications to manage her arrhythmias and other medical conditions. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman w/ ESRD on dialysis, HCV cirrhosis, HTN and chronic 
diarrhea presenting with abdominal pain, fevers, nausea/vomiting 
and ongoing diarrhea. Initially, Ms. ___ was found to have a 
mildly elevated Lipase (239) and CT findings consistent with 
acute pancreatitis and was admitted for treatment and further 
evaluation.

# abdominal pain: The location, quality and time course of Ms. 
___ pain were not classic for acute pancreatitis, however, 
her mildly elevated lipase, fat stranding and reactive LN seen 
of abdominal CT were consistent w/ pancreatitis. There was no 
evident CBD dilation or evidence of stones, and the portal veins 
were open with no evidence of thrombosis. Alcohol and 
gallstones, the most common etiologies for pancreatitis were 
unlikely in this case. Triglycerides were checked and found to 
be within normal limits. The patient was treated conservatively 
for acute pancreatitis, made NPO, given narcotic pain control 
and antiemetics. Over the course of her stay her pain localized 
primarily to the left lower quadrant for which there was no 
clear explanation. She had a bimanual pelvic exam and was found 
to have no adnexal tenderness or cervical motion tenderness. An 
adenexal cyst seen incidentally on CT was on the right and could 
not explain her discomfort. Over the course of her stay, Ms. 
___ pain improved. Her diet was advanced, and she was sent 
home only on her baseline Methadone with no further medications 
for pain control. She may benefit from an outpatient MRCP for 
further evaluation of the cause of her pancreatitis.

# diarrhea: Ms. ___ reports ongoing diarrhea for >6mo. Based 
on OMR records and patient report it appears that work-up to 
date has been negative. The bowel appears normal on CT. The 
patient's diarrhea is secretory based on labs and history of 
large volume diarrhea that occurs throughout the day and night. 
The patient's TSH was found to be suppressed to 0.15 which may 
be contributing. Based on an informal recommendation from 
endocrinology her levothyroxine dose was decreased.
Inpatient work-up including stool cultures and O&P were 
negative. A second O&P is pending at the time of discharge. 
Fecal fat is also pending. Outpatient follow up with the 
patient's gastroenterologist was scheduled for further work-up.

approximately ___. At the time of admission she was afebrile.

accompanied shaking chills. Her dialysis was cut short due to

packs and her fever resolved. She had no further febrile

her pancreatitis although temperatures as high as ___ are

An adnexal cyst was seen on CT which did not appear consistent 
with an abscess. She had no focal adnexal tenderness on bimanual

stabilized prior to discharge. This will be followed up by her

also discussed with her PCP.

Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right foot ascending cellulitis
S/p right BKA

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  During your hospitalization, you had surgery to 
remove unhealthy tissue on your lower extremity.  You tolerated 
the procedure well and are now ready to be discharged from the 
hospital.   Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a 
speedy and uneventful recovery.

LOWER  EXTREMITY AMPUTATION DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS

ACTIVITY 
You should keep your amputation site elevated and straight 
whenever possible.  This will prevent swelling of the stump and 
maintain flexibility in your joint.  
It is very important that you put no weight or pressure on 
your stump with activity or at rest to allow the wound to heal 
properly. 
You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots, if 
applicable.  It will take time to learn to use a walker and 
learn to transfer into and out of a wheelchair.  

MEDICATION
Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

You will likely be prescribed narcotic pain medication on 
discharge which  can be very constipating.  If you take 
narcotics,  please also take a stool softener such as Colace.   
If constipation becomes a problem, your pharmacist can suggest 
an additional over the counter laxative. 

You should take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours, as needed for 
pain.  If this is not enough, take your prescription narcotic 
pain medication.  You should require less pain medication each 
day.  Do not take more than a daily total of 3000mg of Tylenol.  
Tylenol is used as an ingredient in some other over-the-counter 
and prescription medications.  Be aware of how much Tylenol you 
are taking in a day.

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
You may shower when you feel strong enough but no tub baths or 
pools until you have permission from your surgeon and the 
incision is fully healed.
After your shower, gently dry the incision well.   Do not rub 
the area. 

WOUND CARE:
Please keep the wound clean and dry. It is very important that 
there is no pressure on the stump.    If there is no drainage, 
you may leave the incision open to air.  
Your staples/sutures will remain in for at least 4 weeks.  At 
your followup appointment, we will see if the incision has 
healed enough to remove the staples. 
Before you can be fitted for prosthesis (a man-made limb to 
replace the limb that was removed) your incision needs to be 
fully healed. 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
Opening, bleeding or drainage or odor from your stump incision 

Redness, swelling or warmth in your stump.
Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, or worsening 
incisional/stump pain  

NO OTHER PROVIDER, EXCEPT YOUR VASCULAR SURGEON, SHOULD 
DETERMINE IF YOUR STAPLES ARE READY TO BE REMOVED FROM YOUR 
STUMP! 
  
IF THERE ARE ANY QUESTIONS, THE PROVIDER SHOULD CALL THE 
VASCULAR SURGERY OFFICE AT ___ TO DISCUSS.   THE 
STAPLES WILL BE REMOVED IN THE OFFICE AT YOUR FOLLOWUP 
APPOINTMENT WHEN IT IS DETERMINED BY THE VASCULAR SURGEON THAT 
THE WOUND HAS SUFFICIENTLY HEALED.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 41-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital for right forefoot and ascending cellulitis. He has a history of multiple percutaneous interventions for bilateral lower extremity peripheral arterial disease, including a left below-knee amputation (BKA) in the past. He was informed that he would likely need a BKA on his right leg due to non-healing ulcers and was admitted for possible one or two staged amputation.

The patient's past medical history includes diabetes mellitus type 2, end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis, hypertension, dyslipidemia, obesity, asthma, sleep apnea, cocaine dependence, peripheral arterial disease, depression, HIV, and a history of HD line sepsis and PEA arrest.

The patient's allergies include erythromycin base. He was diagnosed with right BKA and underwent the procedure without complications. He was also prescribed vancomycin with hemodialysis for his infected right foot ulcers and cellulitis.

The patient's medications on admission included a preadmission medication list, which was accurate and complete. His discharge medications included sertraline, abacavir sulfate, albuterol inhaler, alprazolam, amlodipine, aspirin, atorvastatin, calcitriol, calcium acetate, clonazepam, docusate sodium, doxepin HCl, gabapentin, glargine, labetalol, lopinavir-ritonavir, loratadine, nephrocaps, polyethylene glycol, senna, and sevelamer hydrochloride.

The patient's physical examination revealed a well-healed left BKA and a right foot with gangrene, bogginess to the bottom of the first toe, and cellulitis along the plantar surface and lateral aspect of the foot up to the level of the ankle. His wound was described as very tender. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
====================
SUMMARY STATEMENT
====================
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with PMHx High grade lymphoma 
with burkitt's features s/p cycle 6 R-EPOCH, HTN, HLD, DM, and 
gout who presents with abdominal bloating and weight loss at 
home, found to have refractory diffuse large B cell lymphoma 
confirmed on gastric biopsy, initiated on RICE therapy. His 
course was complicated by febrile neutropenia, ___, and one 
episode of hematuria. Problems addressed during his 
hospitalization are as follows:

#Recurrent Burkitts-like diffuse large B-cell lymphoma:
Patient with high grade lymphoma with Burkitt like features 
refractory to 6 cycles of EPOCH-R therapy last given ___. 
Previously had IGH/MYC rearrangement and no evidence of BCL2 or 
BCL6 rearrangements. Initially presented with weight loss and 
abdominal bloating, CT AP demonstrating gastric thickening s/p 
EGD with biopsy demonstrating high grade B-cell lymphoma (CD20, 
CD10 positive; CD5 negative; ___ ISH negative; Ki-67 
proliferation index near 100%). Subsequent FISH and cytogenetics 
demonstrating pending. Initiated ICE therapy Cycle 1 
___ with rituximab administration ___. 
Received filgrastim ___. Initiated acyclovir for 
prophylaxis. Developed ___ likely in setting of Ifosfamide 
administration (see ___ below), otherwise tolerated with no 
issues. 

#Febrile neutropenia:
Tmax ___, otherwise remained afebrile, no source of 
infection identified. No localizing symptoms other than nasal 
erythema suspicious for HSV which he has had in the past, 
however on acyclovir, improved. CXR clear, elevation in alk phos 
(most likely medication effect), PICC line without suspicion for 
infection, no evidence of cellulitis, fungal markers negative, 
blood and urine cultures negative. Completed 7 day course of IV 
cefepime, discontinued when ___>500 over 3 days.

___:
Cr elevated over several days (Cr peak 2.1; baseline 1.1-1.2). 
Etiology most likely ATN supported by urine with fragmented 
granular casts and renal tubular epithelial cells. Likely 
developed kidney injury from large volume autodiuresis (up to 
-3.5L over 24H) and medication effect causing tubular injury 
(Ifosfamide). Cr normalized with IVF to keep net fluid balance 
even. Given sodium bicarbonate for acidosis. Of note, in ___ 
developed tumor lysis syndrome at outside hospital (Cr peak 8.4, 
UA 515), renal biopsy with ATN/AIN requiring temporary dialysis. 


#Hematuria with blood clots:
Reported blood clot in urine x1, otherwise asymptomatic. UA 
unremarkable with no evidence of hematuria x2. Resolved 
spontaneously with no intervention. Possibly from ifosfamide 
administration, of note also has bladder mass on CT performed at 
___.

#Guaiac positive stool:
Intermittent melena on admission, resolved with initiation of 
PPI. Transfused PRN for Hg <7.

#Anemia:
Hg ___, likely due to lymphoma and bone marrow suppression from 
chemotherapy. Transfused PRN for Hg <7.

#HTN:
In setting of ATN and large volume autidiuresis, reduced home 
labetalol(decreased from 300 to 200 BID) and home amlodipine 
(decreased from 10 to 5 QD). Remained normotensive with this 
dose reduction.

#Gout: 
Continued home allopurinol

#DM:
Continued home NPH 7 qAM, and ISS, held home glyburide

#Moderate malnutrition:
On presentation reported 3.6% weight loss over 2 weeks. Received 
glucerna BID in between meals.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
========================
[] continue to monitor weight [weight at discharge: 68.3 kg, 
weight at admission: 71.35 kg]
[] continue to monitor hematuria, melena 
[] consider initiation of SSRI

||startoftext|| The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of abdominal bloating and weight loss. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes, and was previously diagnosed with high-grade B cell lymphoma and underwent 6 cycles of chemotherapy (EPOCH-R). He presents with diffuse gastric wall thickening around the gastroesophageal junction and an 11 mm bladder wall lesion, which is concerning for refractory high-grade lymphoma. He was transferred to the hospital for initiation of chemotherapy.

The patient's past medical history includes treatment with Cytoxan, Nitrogen Mustard, Rituximab, and other medications. He has a family history of CAD and CVA/HTN.

Upon admission, the patient's physical exam was normal, with no acute distress or abnormalities noted. His labs showed anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. He underwent imaging studies, including a TTE and CT neck without contrast, which showed normal biventricular cavity sizes with preserved regional and global systolic function, mild aortic regurgitation, and no lymphadenopathy.

At discharge, the patient's physical exam was again normal, with no acute distress or abnormalities noted. His labs showed improvement in his anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. He was prescribed medications, including mirilax and Colace, and was advised to follow up with his primary care physician.

The patient has allergies to Bactrim and has a history of anemia, gout, and hypertension. He is currently taking medications for his hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 47-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for a robotic-assisted total laparoscopic hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. She has a history of sleep apnea, hypercholesterolemia, hypokalemia, vitamin D deficiency, and a left rotator cuff tear. She also has a family history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia.

The patient's presenting symptoms included menometrorrhagia, and she underwent endometrial biopsy in the office, which revealed secretory endometrium and a likely polyp. She subsequently underwent hysteroscopy and D&C, which revealed multiple polyps and EIN arising in one of the polyps.

The patient's diagnosis is endometrial intra-epithelial neoplasia, with final pathology pending. She underwent a major surgical procedure, including robotic-assisted laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and lysis of adhesions.

At discharge, the patient was prescribed several medications, including ibuprofen, oxycodone-acetaminophen, docusate sodium, and losartan potassium. She was also advised to follow certain instructions, including taking her medications as prescribed, not driving while taking narcotics, and not combining narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.

The patient's discharge condition was good, with a clear and coherent mental status, alert and interactive level of consciousness, and ambulatory status. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| 

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) following a renal transplant. He has a neurogenic bladder, hypertension, diabetes, and a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). He was recently hospitalized for septic shock caused by ischemic colitis and Klebsiella urosepsis. He was treated with antibiotics and was discharged to a rehabilitation facility, where he developed worsening abdominal pain and diarrhea. He was transferred to the emergency department, where he was found to have a large stool burden and continued evidence of proctocolitis. He was diagnosed with partially reversible inferolateral perfusion defect and decreased left ventricular ejection fraction. He was also found to have a urinary tract infection caused by multidrug-resistant Escherichia coli (MDR E. coli).

The patient's allergies include antihistamines and glipizide. He has a history of chronic back pain, COPD, DM2, HTN, HLD, and recurrent UTIs. He has also had a colon adenomatous polyp and umbilical hernia repair.

The patient's medications at discharge include cellcept and tacro for his renal transplant, as well as antibiotics for his UTI. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 38-year-old female who presented to the hospital with a chief complaint of loss of fluids and breech presentation. She is a G1P0 at 38 weeks and 1 day gestation. Her past medical history includes hypothyroidism, prolactinoma, pituitary microadenoma, nephrolithiasis, and abnormal pap smear with +HPV. She has a history of allergies to aspirin.

The patient underwent a primary low transverse cesarean delivery due to breech presentation. Her postpartum course was complicated by preeclampsia, which was managed with nifedipine and labetalol. She also experienced an episode of non-sustained tachycardia, which was thought to be related to reflex tachycardia from nifedipine administration or insufficient oral intake.

The patient was discharged home on postpartum day 6 with a stable condition, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating independently, and pain controlled with oral medications. Her medications at discharge include docusate sodium, ibuprofen, and labetalol. ||endoftext||

History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a pleasant ___ w/ CNS B cell Lymphoma who
presents for C5 HD MTX. 
Tolerated his last cycle well and states that since then he has
had no issue. The folliculitis on his leg continues resolving 
and
is no longer bothersome. Note that he developed a severe
mucositis felt ___ methotrexate and hand cracking/dryness/rash
which derm felt was likely acral erythema secondary to
methotrexate of the hands. Betamethasone ointment was used.
Symptoms have resolved. 
He does note for the past week he has been waking up at 3 am and
experiences about for 5 minutes severe leg cramps which wake him
up. Improve with ambulating and massage. Wife notes they feel
like knots. 
He also has a lip sore which comes and goes for years during 
cold
weather and has reappeared. 
 
Past Medical History:
PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY:
His neurologic problem began in early ___ when his
personality changed.  He became withdrawn and stayed in bed for
one week.  He experienced episodes of sweating. On ___, he
woke up and noted that his right hand was not his. Later, he
experienced numbness and within 48 hours, the numbness migrated
to his right thigh and right foot, as well as to his right lip,
right shoulder and right chest later.  He thought he had a 
stroke
and he took two aspirins at a time about 3 times. He was seen in
the emergency department at ___. 
Neuroimaging there reviewed a mass in the corpus callosum
involving the right medial brain as well as the sella.  He was
transferred to the emergency department at ___.  He was
admitted to neurosurgery and gadolinium-enhanced head MRI
performed on ___ showed enhancing mass at the body of the
corpus callosum extending to the suprasellar region.  He had a
stereotaxic brain biopsy on ___ ___.  
The
frozen section showed small round blue cell tumor.  The final
pathology was B cell lymphoma.  He then started induction
high-dose methotrexate @ 3.5 grams/m2 on ___. He tolerated
treatment well and underwent C2 of induction high-dose
methotrexate @ 6 grams/m2 on ___. Few days after completion
of C2 of HD-MTX he developed he developed skin peeling on his
fingers and tongue, bilateral lower extremity edema and 
increased
agitation and insomnia in the context of taking 16 mg
dexamethasone BID instead of 4mg as prescribed. His 
dexamethasone
was held and restarted on ___ at 4mg daily. His cabergoline
was discontinued on ___ and he was started on Miracle
mouthwash mucositis. On ___ he underwent punch biopsy by 
Dr.
___ of ___, pathology was bacterial
folliculitis of the right mid shin and irritated pigmented
seborrheic keratosis of the left superior shin. As per
dermatology his bilateral distal hands xerosis and fissuring was
likely acral erythema in the setting of high-dose methotrexate.
He had dramatic response to treatment and is doing well. He was
admitted on ___ for high-dose methotrexate treatment but
unfortunately he developed the flu and treatment was held. He 
saw
Dr. ___ in clinic on ___ and reported right arm 
paresthesia
and his dexamethasone dose was increased from 2 mg daily to 4mg
twice.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with a history of CNS Lymphoma who was admitted for C5 HD 
MTX at 8 gm/m2 and also found to have new symptomatic DVT.

CNS LYMPHOMA
He tolerated C5 methotrexate per protocol well with IV and PO 
alkalanization with bicarb and leucovorin per rescue. He did 
have some mild nausea. Per neuro oncology his dexamethasone was 
tapered down to 1mg daily. Neuro oncology will arrange for a 
brain MRI to be done as an outpatient and then determine his 
future chemotherapy course base on that. Prior to discharge his 
methotrexate level was less than 0.1. 

DVT
- The patient reported leg cramping and a lower extremity 
Doppler was done which showed a DVT. He was started on lovenox. 
A LMWH level was still pending at the time of discharge which 
can be followed up as an outpatient but is expected to be fine 
as he was started on weight based dosing.

Lip Ulcer
- Likely herpes labialis (ie herpes simplex type 1). In context 
of
receiving chemotherapy, discussed with ___ and 
started
acyclovir for both treatment and for suppression.

Elevated ALT
- This has been chronically mildly elevated, potentially from 
methotrexate. Viral hepatitis serologies (Hep B & C) were 
checked and negative.

Anemia
- Likely due to anemia of chronic disease. Iron and vitamin B12 
levels were checked and were unremarkable.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.

2. LevETIRAcetam 500 mg PO BID

4. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
5. Ranitidine 150 mg PO DAILY

6. Acyclovir 400 mg PO Q8H 
RX *acyclovir 400 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every eight (8) hours 
Disp #*90 Tablet Refills:*1
7. Enoxaparin Sodium 120 mg SC DAILY 
Start: ___, First Dose: Next Routine Administration Time 
RX *enoxaparin 120 mg/0.8 mL 120 mg sc daily Disp #*30 Syringe 
Refills:*3

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
DVT
CNS Lymphoma

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for your ___ cycle of chemotherapy. Dr. ___ 
___ your dexamethasone to 1 mg daily. You tolerated this 
well. 
You were found to have a DVT and you were started on a blood 
thinner called enoxaparin (or lovenox).
SPECIAL PRECAUTIONS FOR PEOPLE WITH DEEP VEIN THROMBOSIS
Other symptoms may indicate that a clot in the leg has broken 
off and traveled to the lung, causing a pulmonary embolism. 
These may include:
* New chest pain with difficulty breathing
* A rapid heart rate and/or a feeling of passing out
This complication may be life-threatening and requires immediate 
attention. Emergency medical services are available in most 
areas of the ___ by calling 911.
Bleeding  Anticoagulants such as heparin and warfarin can have 
serious side effects and should be taken exactly as directed. If 
a dose is forgotten, the patient should call his/her healthcare 
provider or clinic for advice. 
Patients may bleed easily while taking anticoagulants. Bleeding 
may develop in many areas, such as the nose or gums, excessive 
menstrual bleeding, bleeding in the urine or feces, bleeding or 
excessive bruising in the skin, as well as vomiting material 
that is bright red or dark brown like coffee grounds. In some 
cases, bleeding can develop inside the body and not be noticed 
immediately. Bleeding inside the body can cause a person to feel 
faint, or have pain in the back or abdomen. A healthcare 
provider should be notified immediately if there is any sign of 
this problem. A healthcare provider should also be notified 
immediately if the patient on anticoagulants sustained an injury 
that could lead to bleeding inside the body.
Reduce the risk of bleeding  Some simple modifications can 
limit the risk of bleeding:
Use a soft bristle toothbrush
Shave with an electric razor rather than a blade
Take care when using scissors or knives
Avoid potentially harmful activities (eg, contact sports)
Use appropriate safety equipment (eg, helmets, padding) during 
physical activity
Do not take aspirin or other non-steroidal antiinflammatory 
agents (NSAIDS) (eg, ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, Nuprin) 
unless directed to do so by a healthcare provider. Other 
nonprescription pain medications, such as acetaminophen, may be 
a safe alternative.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 58-year-old male who was admitted for elective chemotherapy for his CNS B cell Lymphoma. He has a history of neurologic problems, including personality changes, numbness, and a mass in the corpus callosum. He has also had skin issues, including folliculitis, mucositis, and acral erythema, which have been managed with topical treatments and antibiotics. He has been experiencing severe leg cramps at night, which have been improving with ambulation and massage. He has a lip sore that comes and goes, which is likely herpes labialis.

The patient has a history of allergies to shellfish-derived products and has had adverse reactions to methotrexate, including skin peeling, bilateral lower extremity edema, and increased agitation and insomnia. He has also had hyperprolactinemia, hypercholesterolemia, and testosterone deficiency.

The patient's diagnosis is CNS B cell Lymphoma, and he has undergone several cycles of chemotherapy, including high-dose methotrexate. He has also had a stereotaxic brain biopsy and has been treated with dexamethasone, cabergoline, and Miracle mouthwash mucositis.

The patient's medications at discharge include dexamethasone, levETIRAcetam, lorazepam, ranitidine, omeprazole, acyclovir, and enoxaparin sodium. ||endoftext||

CTA Head ___:
CT ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE HEAD: 
The CT angiography of the head demonstrates normal flow in the 
distal cervical internal carotid arteries with marked narrowing 
of both supraclinoid internal carotid arteries with diminished 
flow in the both MCA trunks. Flow is visualized normally in the 
anterior cerebral arteries as well as somewhat diminished flow 
is seen in the posterior circulation. Vascular structures are 
attenuated and it is difficult to evaluate for an aneurysm. 
Extensive collateral vascular structures are seen in the region 
of basal ganglia bilaterally. The superior sagittal and 
transverse sinuses are patent. The vein ___ and ___ 
sinus are also patent. The anterior portions of both internal 
cerebral veins are not well visualized, which could be secondary 
to blood within the third ventricle and focal mass effect.  
IMPRESSION:
1. Head CT shows intraventricular hemorrhage with dilated 
lateral ventricles due to hydrocephalus.
2. CT angiography of the head demonstrates attenuated internal 
carotid
arteries and middle cerebral arteries with collateral 
lenticulostriate
arteries indicative of a moyamoya pattern which could be 
secondary to
vasculitis. The arterial structures are quite attenuated for 
evaluation of
aneurysm, although none is obviously present. Further evaluation 
with
cerebral angiography is recommended. Although no obvious 
aneurysm or
arteriovenous malformation is seen but the conventional 
angiography can
provide better information of the arterial structures.

CT Head ___:
NON-CONTRAST HEAD CT: There has been interval decrease in the 
amount of
hyperdense blood in the left lateral ventricle and third 
ventricle and fourth ventricle. There has been decrease in 
amount of hydrocephalus in the interval since ___. 
The suprasellar cistern is patent. The basal cisterns are 
slightly narrowed; however, visualized. This demonstrates 
improvement since ___, where the basal cisterns 
were obliterated. A focal area of hypodensity in the right basal 
ganglia (2:11) is noted. Linear hyperdensity in the sulci of the 
left frontoparietal region (2:17) may represent a component of 
subarachnoid hemorrhage. Bilateral ventricular shunts from a 
frontal approach are stable in place. There has been interval 
resolution of previously seen pneumocephalus. There is minimal 
subcutaneous gas (2:26). There is no sclerotic or lytic bony 
lesion to suggest malignancy. Minimal mucosal thickening in the 
posterior right ethmoid air cells are noted. 
IMPRESSION:
1. Interval decrease in intraventricular hyperdense hemorrhage 
and interval
decrease in hydrocephalus and mass effect with interval 
visualization of the basal cisterns, which were obliterated on 
prior exam.
2. Focal hypodensity in the right basal ganglia may represent a 
focal area of infarction. This was not seen on prior exam.

MRI ___
IMPRESSION: Right intraventricular hemorrhage as on the previous 
CT.  
Acute/subacute right periatrial white matter infarct as seen on 
the previous CT examination. Signal changes in the right basal 
ganglia could be due to subacute/chronic hemorrhage. Increased 
signal in the right side of the midbrain probably due to 
subacute or chronic infarct in this location. No other acute 
infarct seen. Other findings as above. 

MRA OF HEAD: ___
Head MRA demonstrates bilateral supraclinoid internal carotid 
artery flow 
signal narrowing indicative of occlusive disease. The middle 
cerebral 
arteries are not fully visualized. Similar findings were seen on 
the previous CTA examination. In the posterior circulation, 
basilar artery is well visualized but diminished flow signal is 
seen in both posterior cerebral arteries. 
IMPRESSION: The MRA appearance has not significantly changed 
since the 
previous CTA examination. Diminished flow is seen in both middle 
cerebral 
arteries secondary to supraclinoid occlusive disease. 

U/S abdomen:
___

evidence of 
cholecystitis or intra- or extra-hepatic biliary ductal 
dilatation. 
  
CT HEAD ___: s/p removal of EVDs

1. Stable appearance of right ventricular hemorrhage, with blood 
products 
layering dependently in the occipital horn of the right lateral 
ventricle. No new hemorrhage. 
2. Stable ventricular size.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital because you were unresponsive. 
You were found to have a bleed in your brain. Imaging of your 
vessels in your brain showed a condition called ___ 
Syndrome. Subsequently, you suffered a stroke that is causing 
your left sided weakness. 

You will be discharged to rehab and have been started on a 
number of medications listed below.

Please attend all followup appointments as listed below. 

GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS
WOUND CARE
You or a family member should inspect your wound every day and 
report any of the following problems to your physician. 
Keep your incision clean and dry.
You may wash your hair with a mild shampoo 24 hours after your 
sutures are removed.
Do NOT apply any lotions, ointments or other products to your 
incision.   
DO NOT DRIVE until you are seen at the first follow up 
appointment.
Do not lift objects over 10 pounds until approved by your 
physician.

DIET
Usually no special diet is prescribed after this procedure. A 
normal well balanced diet is recommended for recovery, and you 
should resume any specially prescribed diet you were eating 
before your surgery. 

MEDICATIONS
Take all of your medications as ordered.  You do not have to 
take pain medication unless it is needed.  It is important that 
you are able to cough, breathe deeply, and is comfortable enough 
to walk.   
Do not use alcohol while taking pain medication. 
Medications that may be prescribed include: 
oNarcotic pain medication such as Dilaudid (hydromorphone).  
oAn over the counter stool softener for constipation (Colace or 
Docusate). If you become constipated, try products such as 
Dulcolax, Milk of Magnesia, first, and then Magnesium Citrate or 
Fleets enema if needed). Often times, pain medication and 
anesthesia can cause constipation.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc, as this can increase your chances of bleeding. 

ACTIVITY
The first few weeks after you are discharged you may feel tired 
or fatigued. This is normal. You should become a little stronger 
every day. Activity is the most important measure you can take 
to prevent complications and to begin to feel like yourself 
again. In general:
Follow the activity instructions given to you by your doctor 
and therapist.
Increase your activity slowly; do not do too much because you 
are feeling good.
You may resume sexual activity as your tolerance allows.
If you feel light headed or fatigued after increasing 
activity, rest, decrease the amount of activity that you do, and 
begin building your tolerance to activity more slowly.
DO NOT DRIVE until you speak with your physician.
Do not lift objects over 10 pounds until approved by your 
physician.
Avoid any activity that causes you to hold your breath and 
push, for example weight lifting, lifting or moving heavy 
objects, or straining at stool.
   Do your breathing exercises every two hours.  
   Use your incentive spirometer 10 times every hour, that you 
are awake.  

WHEN TO CALL YOUR SURGEON:
With any surgery there are risks of complications. Although your 
surgery is over, there is the possibility of some of these 
complications developing. These complications include: 
infection, blood clots, or neurological changes. Call your 
Physician ___ if you Experience:

Confusion, fainting, blacking out, extreme fatigue, memory 
loss, or difficulty speaking.
Double, or blurred vision. Loss of vision, either partial or 
total.
Hallucinations
Numbness, tingling, or weakness in your extremities or face.
Stiff neck, and/or a fever of 101.5F or more.
Severe sensitivity to light. (Photophobia)
Severe headache or change in headache.
Seizure
Problems controlling your bowels or bladder.
Productive cough with yellow or green sputum.
Swelling, redness, or tenderness in your calf or thigh.

Call ___ or go to the Nearest Emergency Room if you Experience:
Sudden difficulty in breathing.
New onset of seizure or change in seizure, or seizure from 
which you wake up confused.
A seizure that lasts more than 5 minutes.

Important Instructions Regarding Emergencies and After-Hour 
Calls
If you have what you feel is a true emergency at any time, 
please present immediately to your local emergency room, where a 
doctor there will evaluate you and contact us if needed. Due to 
the complexity of neurosurgical procedures and treatment of 
neurosurgical problems, effective advice regarding emergency 
situations cannot be given over the telephone.
Should you have a situation which is not life-threatening, but 
you feel needs addressing before normal office hours or on the 
weekend, please present to the local emergency room, where the 
physician there will evaluate you and contact us if needed.

 
Followup Instructions:
___
target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 38-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital after collapsing at home. She was found to have an intraventricular hemorrhage and was intubated. The patient has a history of diabetes and was found to have a moyamoya pattern on CT angiography, which could be secondary to vasculitis. She underwent a cerebral angiogram, bilateral EVD placement, and PEG placement. The patient's physical exam revealed an unresponsive patient with fixed bilateral pupils and no corneal reflex. Her laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, blood glucose, and creatinine levels. The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, including antibiotics and anticonvulsants. ||endoftext||

Discharge Instructions: Please call your surgeon or return to 
the emergency department if you develop a fever greater than 
101.5, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, 
pain unrelieved by your pain medication, severe nausea or 
vomiting, severe abdominal bloating, inability to eat or drink, 
foul smelling or colorful drainage from your incisions, redness 
or swelling around your incisions, or any other symptoms which 
are concerning to you.

Diet: Stay on Stage III diet until your follow up appointment. 
Do not self advance
diet, do not drink out of a straw or chew gum.

Medication Instructions:
Resume your home medications, CRUSH ALL PILLS.
You will be starting some new medications:
1.  You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain 
from your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications.

minerals twice a day. No gummy vitamins.
3. You will be taking Zantac liquid ___ mg twice daily for one 
month. This medicine prevents gastric reflux.
4. You will be taking Actigall 300 mg twice daily for 6 months. 
This medicine prevents you from having problems with your 
gallbladder.
5. You should take a stool softener, Colace, twice daily for 
constipation as needed, or until you resume a normal bowel 
pattern.
6. You must not use NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
drugs) Examples are Ibuprofen, Motrin, Aleve, Nuprin and 
Naproxen. These agents will cause bleeding and ulcers in your 
digestive system.

Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate
exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises.

Wound Care:
You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. 
If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 29-year-old female who was admitted for weight reduction surgery. She has a history of morbid obesity, with a weight of 249.1 pounds and a body mass index (BMI) of 42.8. She has tried various diets and medications in the past, including Topiramate, but has not had significant weight loss. She has a family history of heart disease, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia.

The patient underwent a laparoscopic gastric bypass procedure without event and was discharged on postoperative day two. She was prescribed several medications, including Actigall, Zantac, Roxicet, Colace, Fluoxetine, Lorazepam, Levothyroxine, and Topiramate. She was also advised to follow a Stage III diet and to crush all pills.

The patient was instructed to resume her home medications, including CRUSH ALL PILLS, and to start taking new medications to treat pain, prevent gastric reflux, and prevent gallbladder problems. She was also advised to take a stool softener and to avoid using NSAIDS. She was instructed to avoid heavy lifting for six weeks and to resume moderate exercise at her discretion. ||endoftext||

She was diagnosed with Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI) and underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) procedure to treat a 90% stenosis in the proximal right coronary artery. The patient also had a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, vitamin D deficiency, esophagus, kidney stones, medullary sponge disease, and rheumatoid arthritis. She had a family history of coronary artery disease (CAD) in her mother, father, and sister.

The patient's allergies include erythromycin base, iodine, latex, sulfa, and clindamycin. She was prescribed aspirin 81mg daily, Plavix 75mg daily, pantoprazole, losartan 50mg daily, and metoprolol succinate 25mg daily at discharge.

The patient's physical examination revealed a well-developed and well-nourished female with no significant skin lesions or rashes. Her vital signs were stable, and her lungs were clear bilaterally. The patient's electrocardiogram (EKG) showed normal sinus rhythm with no acute ST changes.

The patient's pertinent results included a coronary angiogram that showed ostial stenosis in the left main coronary artery and a 90% stenosis in the proximal right coronary artery. The PCI procedure was successful in treating the stenosis, and the patient was discharged with a plan for staged PCI in the future. ||endoftext||

The patient was admitted to the HPB Surgical Service for

in patient's common bile duct. Post procedure patient's pain was 
well controlled, amylase and lipase were normal. Patient's diet

||startoftext|| The patient is a 69-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital for a planned radical pancreatoduodenectomy to clear biopsy-proven adenocarcinoma of the uncinate process of the pancreas. He presented with obstructive jaundice and weight loss. The patient has a history of myocardial infarction, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and spinal stenosis. He also has a history of coronary artery disease and has undergone percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty. The patient's past medical history is significant for a tonsillectomy as a child and a history of cancer in his mother and father.

The patient underwent exploratory laparoscopy and laparoscopic liver biopsy, which revealed metastatic disease to his liver. He was then taken to the operating room for an elective Whipple procedure, but it was aborted due to the discovery of metastatic disease. Instead, the patient underwent ERCP and a metal biliary stent was placed in his common bile duct.

The patient was discharged home in stable condition, with a diagnosis of metastatic pancreatic carcinoma and a common bile duct stricture. He was prescribed several medications, including aspirin, atenolol, docusate sodium, enalapril, furosemide, gabapentin, glargine, metformin, omeprazole, oxycoDONE, senna, and simvastatin. He was also advised to follow up with his surgeon and primary care provider as advised, and to resume all regular home medications unless specifically advised not to take a particular medication. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ is an ___ lady, speaking only ___, with 
___ gastric cancer (diagnosed ___, currently on ramucirumab

===ACUTE ISSUES=== 
#Hip fracture:  
#s/p Fall:  
Presented after a fall from standing height and found to have a 
right intertrochanteric hip fracture with varus angulation. CT 
head with subgaleal hematoma but no intracranial hemorrhage, and 
CT C spine negative for traumatic injury. Fall appears to be 
purely mechanical secondary to underlying neuropathy and 
progressive weakness with possible acute decompensation in the 
setting of pneumonia. She had no LOC, but may have an 
orthostatic component as well contributing to lightheadedness 
given poor PO intake. Troponins obtained for pre-op workup were 
slightly elevated x3 (max 0.03). Likely ___ slight ___, EKGs w/o 
e/o MI. 

The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service with 
a right hip fracture. The patient was taken to the operating 
room on ___ for right hip ORIF, which the patient tolerated 
well. For full details of the procedure please see the 
separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from 
the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory 
recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The 
patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, 
and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. 
The patient was given ___ antibiotics and 
anticoagulation per routine. The patient worked with ___ who 
determined that discharge to rehab was appropriate.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
weight-bearing as tolerated in the right lower extremity, and 
will be discharged on ___ for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will 
follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion was 
had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected 
post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or 
return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The 
patient was also given written instructions concerning 
precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care. 
The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

 
#LLL pneumonia: CXR obtained on pre-op workup showed LLL 
opacity. Unclear if she had a true clinical pneumonia given she 
so did not have symptoms of pneumonia, but fall could be due to 
weakness in the setting of infection. Did not meet criteria for 
HAP. Treated with five day course of ceftriaxone and 
azithromycin. 
 
===CHRONIC ISSUES===
#Gastric cancer: 
Diagnosed ___. Treated with 5 cycles on folfox, followed by 
taxol/ramucirumab for 5 cycles (C5 D1 and ___. Seen by 
oncologist Dr. ___ on ___ who recommended stopping 
taxol and proceeding with ramucirumab alone due to concerns that 
the taxol was causing worsening neuropathy and interfering with 
her quality of life. Of note, ramucirumab was held following her 
operation. Will need outpatient evaluation and discussion of 
goals of care to determine further treatment course. In 
addition, patient had therapeutic paracentesis while inpatient

right hip inter-trochanteric fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- weight bearing as tolerated on right lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take subcutaneous heparin daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

FOLLOW UP:
Please follow up with Dr. ___ in the ___ Trauma 
Clinic ___ days post-operation for evaluation. Please call 
___ to schedule appointment.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for and any new 
medications/refills.

Please follow up with your oncologist at your earliest 
convenience.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented to the Emergency Department on ___ with acute onset periumbilical pain.  An abdominal 
ultrasound was suggestive of a 
'moderately distended gallbladder with mural edema and dependent 
stones; early acute cholecystitis should be considered' and 
cholelithiasis; LFTs were also elevated upon admission (T. bili. 
2.9)  While in the ED, intravenous fluids, pain/ nausea 
medication and intravenous antibiotics were administered.  He 
was subsequently admitted to the Acute Care Surgical service for 
ongoing management.  

Upon admission, the patient underwent an MRCP for evaluation of 
possible choledocholithiasis given elevated LFTs.  The MRCP was 
notable for 'appearance consistent with hepatic edema, likely 
hepatitis, abnormal gallbladder with marked gallbladder wall 
edema and gallstones' without evidence of common bile duct 
stones.  Additionally, a minimally complex cyst in the lower 
pole of the left kidney was noted with follow recommended in 6 
months. 

On HD2, an ERCP was attempted, but unsuccesssful due to 
Roux-en-Y anatomy.  Post-procedure, the patient's abdominal pain 
improved and LFTs trended downward suggesting passage of stones. 
 He was subsequently taken to the operating room on HD3 where he 
underwent a laparascopic cholecytectomy; see operative note for 
details.  Post-operatively, the patient remained afebrile with 
stable vital signs; intravenous antibiotics were not resumed.  
His diet was advanced to regular and well tolerated.  
Additionally, he was voiding adequately and ambulating 
independently.  He was subsequently discharged to home on POD1 
and will follow-up in ___ clinic in 2 weeks. Of note, while in 
the PACU, a pilonidal cyst without erythema was noted, which per 
patient, is chronic.  The patient was instructed to continue 
current management of dry dressings prn with regular inspection 
of site.  Warning signs were reviewed with patient with 
perceived good understanding. He will follow-up with his primary 
care provider for ongoing management.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain due to 
inflammation of your gallbladder and elevated laboratory values 
caused by gallstones.  After likely passage of the stone/s, your 
pain improved and your laboratory values began normalizing.  You 
subsequently underwent a laparascopic cholecystectomy and 
recovered in the hospital.  You are now preparing for discharge 
to home with the following instructions:

 Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.
Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.

Additionally, please continue to apply a dry dressing to the 
cyst on your back.  Please inspect this site regularly and 
report any chills, fever, redness, increase and/ or change in 
drainage to your physician ___.  Also, please follow-up 
with your primary care provider for ongoing management.

___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 49-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with sudden onset sharp, constant periumbilical pain. He has a history of gastric bypass surgery and has experienced similar pain in the past. His past medical history includes IDDM, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hyperthyroidism, stiff man syndrome, and kidney stones. He also has a family history of diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and T-cell lymphoma.

The patient was diagnosed with acute cholecystitis and underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He was also found to have cholelithiasis and a minimally complex cyst in the lower pole of the left kidney. His laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels.

The patient was treated with intravenous fluids, pain medication, and antibiotics, and was subsequently discharged home with a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. His medications at discharge included oxycodone for pain, docusate sodium for constipation, rosuvastatin for hyperlipidemia, lisinopril for hypertension, tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia, levothyroxine for hypothyroidism, latanoprost and levobunolol for glaucoma, magnesium gluconate for constipation, vitamin B-12 for deficiency, and insulin aspart for diabetes.

The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care provider for ongoing management and to continue his current management of dry dressings for a pilonidal cyst. ||endoftext||

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure caring for you here at ___.

What happened while you were in the hospital?
- You were admitted because of chest pain, sweating, and a 
clammy feeling 
- You were given sublingual nitroglycerin to decrease the amount 
of blood going to your heart to decrease the stress on your 
heart, this improved your chest pain significantly
- An EKG was done to monitor how your heart was beating, it 
showed some concerning changes
- A troponin level was checked; this is an enzyme that is 
released from your heart cells when your heart muscle is in 
danger. The troponin level was elevated which was concerning
- Your heart was monitored throughout your stay with a telemetry 
monitor, there were no concerning events
- You were started on aspirin, heparin, ticagrelor. These 
medications are blood thinners and are meant to improve blood 
circulation in your heart vessels 
- You were started on atorvastatin which helps decrease 
cholesterol and improve heart function 
- An echo/ultrasound was done to assess your heart function 
which showed your heart is functioning well 
- A catheterization of your heart vessels was done which showed 
significant occlusion in one vessel. Two drug eluding stents 
were placed and blood flow was restored 
- Your HbA1c was checked which is used to measure your average 
blood sugar over three months. The result was 6.5, normal is 
<5.7. For the past three months, your average blood sugar as 
been 140. You were started on a new medication to improve your 
blood sugar. Please recheck your HbA1c in three months to ensure 
improvement

What to do after discharge?
- Follow up with your cardiologist to ensure everything is going 
well
- Continue taking the medications as prescribed, this is very 
important. Your new drug eluding stent will get occluded if you 
miss as little as one dose
- Follow up with your primary care doctor for diabetic 
education, including nutrition education

- Your new medications include:
1. Aspirin 81mg daily (blood thinner- you will be on this 
medication indefinitely 
2. Ticagrelor 90mg every 12 hours (blood thinner- you will be on 
this medication for at least ___ year
3. Metformin 500mg every 12 hours for the first week, then 
increase your morning dose to 1000mg followed by 500mg 12 hours 
later (diabetes), initially this may cause nausea, diarrhea and 
stomach upset- you will be on this medication for at least 3 
months pending your next HbA1c
4. Atorvastatin 80 mg every night before bed, this is replacing 
your simvastatin 20mg- you will be on this medication 
indefinitely 
5. Metoprolol Succinate 50mg, this is replacing your Atenolol 50 
mg daily- you will be on this medication indefinitely
6. Nitroglycerin .3 sublingual up to 3 times as needed for chest 
pain, call your PCP or go to the ED immediately if the chest 
pain does not resolve 

We are happy to see you feeling better. 

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team

___
