||startoftext|| The patient is a 70-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with chest pain. He has a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, pre-diabetes, hemorrhoids/anal fissure, and benign prostatic hypertrophy. He presented with substernal chest pain that started in the morning while he was lying in bed, which was associated with sweating, feeling hot and clammy, and diaphoresis. The pain lasted for about an hour and was described as severe. He denied radiation of pain, numbness/tingling in his arms, shortness of breath, and abdominal/back pain.

The patient has a past medical history of cardiac risk factors, including pre-diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia. He also has a history of dermatoheliosis, benign prostatic hypertrophy, inflammatory colon polyp, chronic sun-damaged skin, and seborrheic keratoses.

The patient's physical examination on admission showed a well-developed male in no acute distress, with a normal cardiovascular examination. His laboratory results showed elevated troponin levels, with a peak level of 0.16 ng/mL. He was started on heparin gtt and aspirin.

The patient underwent a left heart catheterization, which showed 90% occlusion in the mid and distal left anterior descending (LAD) artery, and two drug-eluting stents were placed with good revascularization.

The patient's diagnosis is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, consistent with coronary artery disease. He was prescribed medications at discharge, including aspirin, clopidogrel, and metoprolol. ||endoftext||

moderate pericardial effusion, pulsus was 4, and echo showed no 
evidence of tamponade.  A CXR had some questionable haziness and 
patient given zosyn 4.6g IV x1 and vancomycin 1g IV x1.  Two 
peripheral IVs were placed.  Creatinine was notably 4.5 (up from 
1.5) and UA was negative.  Nephrology transplant was consulted 
and requested a tacrolimus trough and urine lytes.  Hepatatology 
and transplant surgery were made aware of the admission.  Vitals 
prior to transfer were: 57 104/57 RR14 96% on 3L.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a very nice ___ gentleman admitted with 
SOB, lightheadedness, emesis, and vague visual hallucinations, 
found to be hypotensive, in acute renal failure, and with 
pericardial and bilateral pleural effusions. 

HYPOTENSION:  He was mildly fluid responsive in the ED from SBP 
of ___ to ___. Lactate was 0.9 and WBC was normal.  Urine 
lytes showed FeNa - 0.89, consistent with a pre-renal picture.  
Once in the ICU, arterial line was placed and he was given 3L NS 
with good response.  His home dilt, doxazosin, flecainide, 
methocarbamol, metoprolol, oxycontin were held in the setting of 
hypotension.  His pressures normalized quickly.  His home 
lopressor was kept on-board given his a-fib with RVR (see 
below).  Hypotension was thought to be secondary to hypovolemia. 
 Upon transfer to the floor, patient remained hemodynamically 
stable, with systolic pressures in the 100s-120s.  

AFIB WITH RVR:  Patient's home meds were initially held on 
admission given hypotension.  He developed a-fib with RVR, which 
was difficult to control.  On the floor, cardiology was 
consulted who helped titrate his regimen.  Upon transfer to the 
MICU, patient was on: dilt 60mg QID, flecanide 50mg BID, and 
metoprolol 50mg BID.  The metoprolol had been down-titrated in 
setting of obstructive pulmonary disease, and concern for 
excessive beta-blockade.  Mr. ___ will need to follow-up with 
Dr. ___ outpatient management of afib with RVR.  His 
anti-arrhythmic regimen has been adjusted and current doses 
inclued metoprolol tartrate 150mg twice daily, flecainide 100mg 
twice daily, and diltiazem SR 240mg once daily.

___:  Patient is s/p kidney transplant in ___.  Creatinine of 
4.5 up from 1.5 on ___.  Urine lytes consistent with pre-renal 
etiology.  Creatinine improved with IV fluids (down to 2.4 on 
___.  On the floor, creatinine continued to be in flux, but was 
usually fluid responsive and trended to baseline of 1.1 at time 
of discharge.

PERICARDIAL EFFUSION / PLEURAL EFFUSIONS:  Unclear etiology.  
Cardiology was consulted who recommended serial echos to 
evaluate evolution/resolution of effusion.  Daily pulsus was 
checked, usually ranging from ___.  Pericardial fluid did not 
seem to affect patient in any signficant manner; differential 
diagnosis included: malignant, infectious, and rheumatologic.  
The plan was to perform pericardiocentesis for fluid analysis 
which unfortunately did not reveal an underlying etiology. 
Patient also underwent right and left-sided thoracenteses, for 
diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.  Extensive work-up for 
autoimmune causes, infectious (including TB, by way of serum 
quantinterferon gold and pericardial fluid mycobacterial 
culture) causes, and malignant causes (pericarial tissue biopsy, 
pericardial and pleural fluid cytologies), was negative.  The 
patient will follow-up with his outpatient cardiologist for 
repeat TTE in 2 weeks.  Additionally, he will see Dr. ___ in 
infectious diseases clinic for follow-up of multiple infectious 
tests, still pending at time of discharge. Imaging at time of 
discharge shows a small pericardial effusion with no tamponade 
physiology on echocardiogram and small right-sided pleural 
effusion on CXR.

VISUAL HALLUCINATIONS/CHANGE IN MENTAL STATUS:  No focal neuro 
deficits.  Originally thought to be from medications such as 
gapapentin, muscle relaxants, and oxycodone.  These medications 
were discontinued upon admission to ICU, and they have continued 
to be held given concern of over-sedation and hypercarbic 
respiratory failure.  His mental status is back to baseline - 
AAOx3, no encephalopathy or cognitive or concentration deficits.

RIGHT UPPER EXTREMITY SWELLING: patient has known SVC and right 
subclavian vein stents.  Vascular was consulted and recommended 
for outpatient follow-up for consideration of CT venogram.

PROPHYLAXIS: subcutaneous heparin.

Discharge Instructions:

to have fluid collections around the heart and lungs. These 
collections were drained, and the fluid was sent for

believe that you are well enough to go home. Please note your

||startoftext|| The patient is a 56-year-old male who was admitted with hypotension, shortness of breath, lightheadedness, emesis, and vague visual hallucinations. He has a history of liver-kidney transplant for chronic hepatitis C cirrhosis, hypertension, emphysema, obstructive sleep-disordered breathing, atrial fibrillation, and intravenous drug use. He also has allergies to Rofecoxib.

The patient's past medical history includes hypercholesterolemia, anxiety, hypertension, emphysema, obstructive sleep-disordered breathing, atrial fibrillation, and intravenous drug use. His family history includes heart disease, emphysema, and kidney failure.

The patient's physical exam revealed a gray, sallow color, dry mucous membranes, and tender feet. His labs showed acute renal failure, elevated creatinine, and abnormal liver function tests.

The patient underwent thoracentesis, pericardial window, and intubation. He was prescribed medications including tacrolimus, vancomycin, and zosyn.

The patient's diagnosis includes pericardial effusion, bilateral pleural effusions, and acute renal failure. His procedures included thoracentesis, pericardial window, and intubation. ||endoftext||

Blood Cultures routine and mycolytic NGTD at time of D/C

CXR:  In comparison with study of ___, there is no change or 
evidence of 
acute cardiopulmonary disease. Specifically, no focal pneumonia 
or 
interstitial prominence to suggest PCP. 

U/S liver: 
1. Thickened gallbladder wall with no gallstones. Thick-walled 
bile ducts 
with no biliary dilatation. The appearance of these structures 
is consistent 
with HIV choliangiopathy. 
2. Focal fat seen within the liver.  
3. Mild splenomegaly. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M w/ AIDS off HAART for 15 months presents w/ malaise, 
anemia.
.
#HIV: Pt. has had poor reactions to ARV Tx in the past (stopped 
taking because of nausea w/ ritonavir), pt. restarted on ARV w/ 
attention to this. Pt. did well w/ no N/V after taking ritonavir 
at HS. Blood cultures were drawn for bacteria, mycobacteria and 
fungi and were no growth to date on day of D/C. Continued 
dapsone ppx, but considered switching to atovaquone because of 
hemolytic anemia, Hct remained stable so we kept pt. on dapsone.

.
#Abdominal pain: Pt. has Hx of bowel wall ulcer, this seems 
probable as his tenderness is extremely localized, has not been 
progressive. Likely he does not have acute bacterial issue as he 
is non septic and this has been present for a long time. He has 
been scoped before w/ conflicting path results (negative CMV Cx 
but a few inclusions),consider CMV colitis, Consider HSV 
colitis, Consider parasitic ___. Dr. ___ 
performed the endoscopy felt that the ulcer looked like it was 
from CMV and so pt. was empirically started on IV gancyclovir 
and then transitioned to PO valgancyclovir after 2 days. The 
abdominal pain seemed to improve slightly day to day. Pt. had 
elevated alk phos, GGT, Tbili so liver U/S was performed and wet 
read was consistent w/ HIV cholangiopathy.
.
#Anemia: Appears to be hemolytic as haptoglobin was decreased to 
<20 and retic count is elevated. Elevated retic count (not 
appropriately elevated given low Hbg) suggests that there is a 
lack of production. He recieved 2 units of PRBCs and his Hct 
increased to above 25 and remained stable after transfusion, on 
day of d/c was 24.9. Likely that he is no longer hemolyzing, but 
unknown whether his marrow is responding at time of d/c. There 
was significant concern that the lack of marrow response 
represented a marrow infiltrative process so a BMB was obtained. 
Results of BMB were pending at D/C.
.
#Fever: Likely OI as pt. has no other focal signs of infection. 
Could be drug fever as pt. recently started on gancyclovir and 
ARV's, the fevers did not appear until the night after the 
gancyclovir was started and continued to wax and wane and he had 
a temperature to 100.8 the night before d/c. CXR, UA, Ucx, Blood 
Cx X3 sets routine Negative so far. Pt. to f/u w/ Dr. ___ 
results of BMB and mycolytic blood cultures.
.
#Fatigue: likely ___ anemia, but may also be due to chronic OI 
and/or HIV wasting syndrome as pt. appeared quite cachectic. 
Nutrition was consulted and recommended ensure supplementation, 
but pt. did not like ensure and made this clear to nutrition, 
ensure was seen unopened on pt.s tray every morning.
.
#Diarrhea: Likely ___ OI, differential is quite wide: crypto, 
giardia, ___, CMV, C. diff. All previous wkup 
was negative in ___.  Likely etiology is an OI which will be 
treated by increasing his CD4 count. Repeat stool studies were 
negative for o/p, ___, crypto, giardia, cyclospora.
.
#Hyponatremia: Possibly secondary to diarrhea with free water 
replacement or SIADH from chronic pain. Most likelly from 
diarrhea. Urine lytes, Cr, Osm inconclusive for SIADH vs. volume 
depletion. FeNa was 1.6. Pt. remained asymptomatic and recieved 
no specific treatment.
.
#Elevated alk phos: Likely bile duct source as GGT also 
elevated. Pt. also complaining of RUQ pain and tenderness, has 
previous history of U/S which showed cholelithiasis. Liver U/S 
did not show stones in duct, wet read was consistent with HIV 
cholangiopathy.

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 55-year-old male with a chief complaint of fatigue. He has a history of AIDS, diagnosed 15 months prior, and has been off antiretroviral therapy (ARV) for 15 months. He presents with anemia, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, which has been present for a year. He has a history of depression, situational depression, and has experienced weight loss. His physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor, hard white plaques on the sides of his tongue, and multiple umbilicated papules on his face. His laboratory results show anemia, elevated liver enzymes, and hyponatremia. He was started on IV gancyclovir and then transitioned to PO valgancyclovir for suspected CMV colitis. He received 2 units of PRBCs and his Hct increased to above 25. He was also started on dapsone prophylaxis. His discharge medications include dapsone 100mg QD and valgancyclovir. ||endoftext||

Discharge Instructions:
* You were admitted to the hospital for lung surgery and you've 
recovered well. You are now ready for discharge. 

* Continue to use your incentive spirometer 10 times an hour 
while awake.

* Check your incisions daily and report any increased redness or 
drainage.   Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining.

* Your chest tube dressing may be removed in 48 hours.  If it 
starts to drain, cover it with a clean dry dressing and change 
it  as needed to keep site clean and dry.

 * You may need pain medication once you are home but you can 
wean it over the next week as the discomfort resolves.  Make 
sure that you have regular bowel movements while on narcotic 
pain medications as they are constipating which can cause more 
problems.  Use a stool softener or gentle laxative to stay 
regular.

* No driving while taking narcotic pain medication.

* Take Tylenol  ___ mg every 6 hours .  

* Continue to stay well hydrated and eat well to heal your 
incisions

* Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat 
dry
 * No tub bathing, swimming or hot tubs until incision healed
 * No lotions or creams to incision site

* Walk ___ times a day and gradually increase your activity as 
you can tolerate.

 -Fevers > 101 or chills
 -Increased shortness of breath, chest pain or any other 
symptoms that concern you.

 

** If pathology specimens were sent at the time of surgery, the 
reports will be reviewed with you in detail at your follow up 
appointment. This will give both you and your doctor time to 
understand the pathology, its implications and discuss options 
going forward.**

___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 74-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital for surgical resection of a left lower lobe lung nodule. He presented with symptoms of shortness of breath and fatigue. His past medical history includes hyperlipidemia, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, gout, and obesity. He also has a history of cholecystectomy, bilateral hip replacement, and fractured skull. The patient has allergies to Celebrex and has a family history of lung cancer and CAD.

The patient underwent a left VATS and wedge resection of the left lower lobe lung nodule and mediastinal lymph node sampling. He tolerated the procedure well and was discharged to home with a diagnosis of left lower lobe lung nodule. His medications at discharge include acetaminophen, docusate sodium, milk of magnesia, oxyCODONE, levemir, novolog, allopurinol, aspirin, atorvastatin, benazepril, dorzolamide, gemfibrozil, hydrochlorothiazide, ibuprofen, latanoprost, metFORMIN, and tamsulosin.

The patient was advised to continue using his incentive spirometer, check his incisions daily, and report any increased redness or drainage. He was also instructed to remove his chest tube dressing in 48 hours and to wean his pain medication over the next week as the discomfort resolves. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 79-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with chest pain. He has a history of coronary artery disease, chronic stable angina, moderate aortic stenosis, bladder cancer, chronic kidney disease, and renal cell carcinoma. He has also had a history of intolerance to beta blockers due to symptomatic bradycardia. 

The patient was diagnosed with non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and underwent cardiac catheterization, which showed effective revascularization. However, due to the complexity of possible percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), he was medically managed instead. 

During his hospital stay, the patient developed acute kidney injury (AKI) due to postrenal ureteral stenosis, which was treated with a ureteral stent. He also had anemia, which was managed with blood transfusions. 

The patient was discharged on medications including aspirin, rosuvastatin, metoprolol, IMDUR, and ranolazine. He will also need to keep a ureteral stent in place for several weeks and follow up with his doctor in clinic. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Vascular Surgery Service for 
evaluation and treatment.  On ___, the patient underwent left 
carotid endarterectomy, which went well without complication 
(reader referred to the Operative Note for details). After a 
brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the 
floor NPO, on IV fluids, with a foley catheter, and oxycodone 
for pain control.  The patient was hemodynamically stable.

Neuro: The patient received oxycodone and tylenol with good 
effect and adequate pain control.  

CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. An artertial 
line was initially placed for close blood pressure monitoring. 
He was continued on all home medications including beta-blocker. 
Home ace-inhibitor was restarted POD1.

Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization.

GI/GU/FEN: Post-operatively, the patient was made NPO with IV 
fluids. Diet was advanced when appropriate, which was well 
tolerated.  Patient's intake and output were closely monitored, 
and IV fluid was adjusted when necessary.  Electrolytes were 
routinely followed, and repleted when necessary. Foley catheter 
was removed at midnight POD0 and the patient voided. Following 
foley catheter placement, hematuria was noted. It cleared over 
the postoperative course. Urology recommended the patient be 
seen by his outpatient urologist given his history of bladder 
cancer. This was commnunicated to the patient and his wife and 
daughter directly.

ID: The patient's white blood count and fever curves were 
closely watched for signs of infection.   

Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined 
routinely; no transfusions were required. INR was checked POD1 
after coumadin was held POD0. It was restarted on his home 
dosing regimen POD1. Communication with his PCP who manages his 
coumadin as an outpatient was made prior to discharge and 
followup INR check and coumadin dosing was established. 

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay; was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left carotid stenosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
WHAT TO EXPECT:

 

1. Surgical Incision:

·     It is normal to have some swelling and feel a firm ridge 
along the incision

·     Your incision may be slightly red and raised, it may feel 
irritated from the staples

2. You may have a sore throat and/or mild hoarseness

·     Try warm tea, throat lozenges or cool/cold beverages 

3. You may have a mild headache, especially on the side of your 
surgery

·     Try ibuprofen, acetaminophen, or your discharge pain 
medication

·     If headache worsens, is associated with visual changes or 
lasts longer than 2 hours- call vascular surgeons office

4. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 

·     You should get up out of bed every day and gradually 
increase your activity each day 

·     You may walk and you may go up and down stairs 

·     Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do 
too much right away!

5. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 

·     You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 

·     Eat small frequent meals

·     It is important to eat nutritious food options (high 
fiber, lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) 
to maintain your strength and assist in wound healing

·     To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

 

MEDICATION:

·     Take all of your medications as prescribed in your 
discharge 

ACTIVITIES:

 

·     No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer 
taking pain medications

·     No excessive head turning, lifting, pushing or pulling 
(greater than 5 lbs) until your post op visit

·     You may shower (no direct spray on incision, let the soapy 
water run over incision, rinse and pat dry)

·     Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area

 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

He has undergone several surgeries, including CABG x 3, AAA repair, AICD implant, and afib ablation.

Discharge Instructions:
Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
You may wash your hair only after sutures and/or staples have 
been removed. If your wound closure uses dissolvable sutures, 
you must keep that area dry for 10 days. 
You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home, unless you have been instructed not to.

___

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a ___ year old woman with PMH of left femoral to ___ 
bypass (___) for a non-healing second toe amputation site and 
___ toe ulcer. During admission with Podiatry for a third toe 
amputation in ___, ultrasound demonstrated that the left SFA 
and the bypass graft were occluded, but since her second toe amp 
site had healed and ___ toe ulcer improved it was decided that 
redo bypass would not be attempted at that time. Upon returning 
to clinic on ___, the patient was found to have a new left 
second toe ulceration as well as a left first hallux blister 
with drainage, in addition to her non-healing ___ toe ulcer, and 
that pain from these wounds was limiting her ambulation. It was 
decided she would ultimately require a revision of her bypass 
graft after a bilateral lower extremity angiogram. 

The patient presented to ___ on ___ for a bilateral lower 
extremity angiogram. Procedure was uncomplicated, and 
demonstrated occlusion of the left SFA, bypass graft, and 
popliteal artery. It also demonstrated occlusion of the right 
SFA and popliteal artery. The patient went to PACU 
post-procedure in good condition, and after a brief, uneventful 
stay was transported to the floor. She was admitted to the 
Vascular Surgery service overnight for monitoring. 

On the morning of POD 1, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled. Her groin access site was soft, with no evidence of 
bleeding or hematoma. She had dopplerable DP and ___ pulses in 
her right foot, and a dopplerable ___ pulse in her left foot. No 
DP pulse could be obtained on her left foot, which was unchanged 
from immediately post-procedure. The patient was discharged home 
without services. The patient unfortunately eloped from the 
hospital as her discharge papers were being completed, so she 
did not receive formal discharge teaching with nursing. Her 
nurse was notified the patient was eloping, and the patient 
allowed her nurse to remove her ___ in the hallway. The patient 
will return to the hospital on ___ for a 
planned readmission for left re-do left femoral to posterior 
tibial bypass.

___

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Peripheral vascular disease 
Toe ulcers

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___. You were admitted to the hospital after a 
peripheral angiogram. To do the test, a small puncture was made 
in one of your arteries. The puncture site heals on its own: 
there are no stitches to remove. You tolerated the procedure 
well and are now ready to be discharged from the hospital. You 
will return to the hospital on ___ for a 
bypass procedure on your leg. Please follow the recommendations 
below to ensure a speedy and uneventful recovery.

Peripheral Angiography

Puncture Site Care
For one week:
 Do not take a tub bath, go swimming or use a Jacuzzi or hot 
tub.
 Use only mild soap and water to gently clean the area around 
the puncture site. 
 Gently pat the puncture site dry after showering. 
 Do not use powders, lotions, or ointments in the area of the 
puncture site. 

You may remove the bandage and shower the day after the 
procedure.  You may leave the bandage off. 
You may have a small bruise around the puncture site.  This is 
normal and will go away one-two weeks. 

Activity 
For the first 48 hours: 
 Do not drive for 48 hours after the procedure
For the first week:
 Do not lift, push , pull or carry anything heavier than 10 
pounds
 Do not do any exercises or activity that causes you to hold 
your breath or bear down with abdominal muscles.   Take care not 
to put strain on your abdominal muscles when coughing, sneezing, 
or moving your bowels.

After one week:
 You may go back to all your regular activities, including 
sexual activity.  We suggest you begin your exercise program at 
half of your usual routine for the first few days.   You may 
then gradually work back to your full routine.

Medications:
Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home. If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

For  Problems or Questions:
Call ___ in an emergency such as:
 Sudden, brisk bleeding or swelling at the groin puncture site 
that does not stop after applying pressure for ___ minutes
 Bleeding that is associated with nausea, weakness, or 
fainting.

Call the vascular surgery office (___) right away if 
you have any of the following. (Please note that someone is 
available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week)
 Swelling, bleeding, drainage, or discomfort at the puncture 
site that is new or increasing since discharge from the hospital
 Any change in sensation or temperature in your legs
 Fever of 101 or greater
 Any questions or concerns about recovery from your angiogram 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

She has a history of left femoral to posterior tibial bypass graft completed in the past, and has been experiencing toe pain and difficulty with ambulation. She was admitted to the hospital for monitoring and was discharged home without services.

The patient's medications at admission included acetaminophen, lisinopril, gabapentin, mirtazapine, rivaroxaban, atorvastatin, oxyCODONE, and omeprazole. Her medications at discharge included acetaminophen, aspirin, atorvastatin, gabapentin, mirtazapine, omeprazole, and oxyCODONE, with lisinopril and rivaroxaban held until her planned readmission.

The patient's discharge diagnosis was peripheral vascular disease and toe ulcers, and her discharge condition was clear and coherent, with a level of consciousness of alert and interactive, and activity status of ambulatory with assistance or aid. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 51-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital due to intolerance to solid foods and a gastric mass at the gastroesophageal junction. A CT scan showed a large gastric tumor extending to the esophagus with hepatic metastasis. He underwent an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with esophageal stent placement and biopsies were taken. The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his doctor and oncologist. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 52-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with bilateral foot ulcers. He has a history of uncontrolled diabetes type 1 and was brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend due to his inability to seek medical attention due to insurance issues. The patient's presenting symptoms included bilateral foot infections and swelling. He was found to have infected ulcers on both feet, with one ulcer on the left foot requiring incision and drainage. The patient underwent debridement of the right ulcer and excision of the left sesamoids with wound closure. He was started on Lantus and a humalog sliding scale for his diabetes, and was also prescribed antibiotics for his foot infections. The patient was advised to be non-weightbearing on the left foot and full weightbearing on the right foot. He was seen by a podiatrist and cleared for home, with follow-up appointments scheduled. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to pre-op/Emergency Department on ___ 
. Pt was evaluated by anaesthesia/ Upon arrival to ED.  Given 
findings, the patient was taken to the operating room for 
ex-lap,washouts,flap advancement w/ surgimend and wound VAC 
placement. There were no adverse events in the operating room; 
please see the operative note for details.  Pt was extubated, 
taken to the PACU until stable, then transferred to the TSICU 
for observation.

On POD1, patient has been persistently tachycardic up to 130's, 
however urine output has been adequate. NG tube was removed. 
Over night, he has agitated and delirious that required 1 dose 
of IV Haldol. Patient started on broad spectrum IV antibiotics 
to treat abdominal sepsis and pneumonia and IV fluconazole 
prophylactically. 

POD2, he has multiple loose bowel movement which was positive 
for C.diff, IV flagyl and PR vancomycin has been started. He 
also stayed delirious during the day. He has been taken to the 
OR again for washout/VAC changes and went back to the TSICU and 
this time he kept intubated and was HD stable over the night. 

POD3, Patient was extubated but remained delirious. POD4, his 
over all delirium issues has been improved, CT abdomen/Pelvis 
done which was negative for any perforation or fluid 
collections, he has taken back to the OR for wash out/VAC 
changes. 

POD5, his heart rate went high, up to 133 with irregular rhythm, 
multiple 5mg metoprolol doses have been given that managed the 
heart rate perfectly, IV 5mg metoprolol was started q6h standing 
dose daily that stopped completely a few days later. 

On ___, he has taken back to the OR for another wash out 
and VAC changes and then transferred to the regular floor after. 


During stay on regular floor the hospital course has been 
described systematically as follow:   

Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented on the floor; pain was 
managed perfectly with IV pain medicine that transitioned to 
oral once tolerating a diet.

CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Metoprolol has 
been stopped and heart rate remain stable.

Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged.

GI/GU/FEN: Initially he was NPO and on TPN. The diet was 
advanced sequentially to a Regular diet, which was well 
tolerated, subsequently TPN has been stopped. Patient's intake 
and output were closely monitored

ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched of which he 
was afebrile through out hospitalization. Patient switched to PO 
Flagyl and kept on C.Diff treatment for 15 days after discharge 
with PO Vancomycin as well.

HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs 
of bleeding, of which there were none.

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and ___ 
dyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Enter Cutaneous fistula 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you here at ___ 
___. You were admitted to our hospital 
after undergoing ex-laparotomy, washouts, flap advancement with 
surgimend closure on ___. You have recovered from surgery 
and are now ready to be discharged home. Please follow the 
recommendations below to ensure a speedy and uneventful 
recovery.  

ACTIVITY: 
- Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency. 
- You may climb stairs.  
- You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit. 
- Don't lift more than 10 lbs for 6 weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap. 
- You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. 
- You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming. 

HOW YOU MAY FEEL:  
- You may feel weak or "washed out" for 6 weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you. 
- You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
You might feel somewhat depressed. 
- You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing. 
- All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon. 

YOUR BOWELS: 
- Constipation is a common side effect of medicine such as 
Percocet or codeine. If needed, you may take a stool softener 
(such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk 
of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription. 
- If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon. 
- After some operations, diarrhea can occur. If you get 
diarrhea, don't take anti-diarrhea medicines. Drink plenty of 
fluids and see if it goes away. If it does not go away, or is 
severe and you feel ill, please call your surgeon. 

PAIN MANAGEMENT: 
- It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness".  
- Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon. 

-You will receive a prescription from your surgeon for pain 
medicine to take by mouth. It is important to take this medicine 
as directed.  
- Do not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take 
more medicine at one time than prescribed. 
- Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe. 
- Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay. 
- If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine. 
- Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you 
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises. 
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon: 
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours 
- pain that is getting worse over time 
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101 
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain 

MEDICATIONS: 
- Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just 
as you did before, unless you have been told differently. 
- If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not 
to take, please call your surgeon. 

VAC instruction:
1. While wet-to-dry dressings are in place, please change ___ 
times a day or as needed for increased soiling.
2. While VAC is in place, please clean around the VAC site and 
monitor for air leaks of the VAC
3. A written record of the daily output from the VAC drain 
should be brought to every follow-up appointment. Your VAC drain 
will be removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers 
off to an acceptable amount and the wound is no longer 
concerning for ongoing infection
4. You may shower daily with assistance as needed.
5. Okay to shower, but no baths until after directed by your 
surgeon
 
Followup Instructions:
___
target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 59-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with abdominal sepsis. He had a history of asymptomatic large cecal mass detected on screening colonoscopy, which was complicated by a leak that required an ex-laparotomy with washouts and vacuum placement. He was discharged home but returned with high-grade fever, pain, and foul-smelling abdominal wound discharges. 

The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, clavicle fracture, gout, hyperlipidemia, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and asthma. He also has a history of knee surgery, inguinal hernia repair, umbilical hernia repair with mesh, and colonoscopy showing a large cecal mass.

The patient's allergies include shellfish-derived and peanut. He was diagnosed with enterocutaneous fistula and was treated with broad-spectrum IV antibiotics, IV fluconazole prophylactically, and IV metronidazole. He also received oral medications including acetaminophen, albuterol, allopurinol, metronidazole, oxydone, and vancomycin oral liquid.

The patient's discharge medications include acetaminophen, albuterol inhaler, allopurinol, metronidazole, oxydone, and vancomycin oral liquid. He was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his primary care physician and to take his medications as directed. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
PATIENT SUMMARY
===============
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with a past medical history
of rheumatoid arthritis on chronic prednisone, ESRD on ___ HD,
COPD on 2L home O2, recent episode of ESBL E. Coli bacteremia
___, completed treatment with Zosyn for 14 day course) who 
presented to ___ with 3 days of atraumatic right hip pain 
concerning for septic arthritis, likely seeded by her recurrence 
of her E. coli bacteremia. She was transferred to ___, treated 
with IV antibiotics, seen by ID, orthopedics, had a R hip MRI, 
and discharged on meropenem for 6 weeks with OPAT follow up.

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
#ESBL E Coli bacteremia
Blood cultures positive from ___ and ED for GNRs. His 
cultures grew in recurrent ESBL E. Coli from ___, for which 
she already completed a course of zosyn x14d. TTE negative for 
vegetation. The source of the ESBL E Coli is unknown but we 
considered GI vs GU, given her history of rectal prolapse per 
her report (she had seen a colorectal surgeon at ___). 
Colorectal surgery saw her during this admission and firmly 
believed her ectropion was not an infectious source. The E Coli 
was sensitive to meropenem. ID was consulted and she was treated 
with IV meropenem for 6 week course. Her ___ blood culture was 
positive for gram-positive cocci in clusters, but this was 
speciated to coag negative staph and was likely a contaminant. 

#Leukocytosis: Initially elevated to ___ iso bacteremia as well 
chronic elevation from steroid use. Downtrending on discharge to 
baseline with treatment of bacteremia as above. Discharge WBC: 
16.8. 

#Septic Joint
Initially concerning for septic arthritis vs. trochanteric 
bursitis.
Atraumatic hip pain. Joint aspirate with 22K WBCs and Hct 22,
negative culture. However she had already received two days of 
antibiotics at the time of aspiration. She was seen by ortho, 
who thought her pain was likely trochanteric bursitis. GNRs 
would also be an atypical cause of septic arthritis, but the hip 
could have been seeded during her recent bacteremia. Rheum and 
ID both agreed with the diagnosis of a likely septic joint and 
recommend wash out, which was deferred by orthopedics. An MRI R 
hip was obtained notable for small effusion with no evidence of 
a septic joint. Rheumatology was concerned that she may not 
improve with antibiotics alone given the severity of her RA, 
however, the decision was made to treat the patient 
conservatively with IV antibiotics. Patient seemed to improve 
clinically with antibiotics with improved mobility at the joint 
so a wash-out was deferred in agreeance with all consulting 
services. She had a PICC line placed on ___ for continued 
antibiotics. 

#Incidental Uterine Mass
#Cervical stenosis
Incidentally found mass seen on her MRI of her R hip. She had a 
follow up pelvic US which showed a likely fibroid vs. polyp. The 
ultrasound also revealed a fluid filled uterine cavity 
concerning for cervical stenosis. The patient was asymptomatic. 
She will need outpatient gynecology follow-up. 

#ESRD on HD 
#Hyperkalemia
Initially became fluid overloaded and hyperkalemic in the 
setting of missing HD. Transferred to the ICU for 2 days until 
stabilized with emergent HD and returned to the floor. Her 
hyperkalemia was treated with insulin/Calcium. Discharge K 5.8 
after which she received HD. On MWF HD. Access: LUE AVF. 

#Macrocytic Anemia
Most likely secondary to ESRD. MCV 101-102. Folate normal. B12
low-normal 389. Recommend serum or urine MMA as outpatient to 
assess for B12 deficiency as a low normal B12 may still be 
deficient at the tissue level.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
===============
#Hypertension. Remained hypertensive to 180s, but asymptomatic.
Her home regimen was continued as below: 
On HD days: Hydral 25 BID, labetalol 300 BID
On non-HD days: Hydral 25 TID, labetalol 300 TID, amlodipine 10
On all days: Lisinopril 10
Her lisinopril was increased to 20 mg po daily in light of 
continued high blood pressures. 

#Rheumatoid arthritis 
Initially give 10 mg prednisone po daily and titrated down to 
7.5 mg as per rheumatology recs. 

#COPD on 2L home O2 
There is some concern that her respiratory disease is actually
due to ILD in the setting of her RA. Could consider PFTs as an
outpatient. She received O2 and her home nebulizers

#Hypothyroidism 
She was continued on levothyroxine 125 mcg daily. 

#Anxiety/depression 
She was continued on her home pregabalin, clonazepam, sertraline 
and trazodone.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 78-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of hip pain. She has a past medical history of rheumatoid arthritis, chronic heart failure, COPD, and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD). She also has a history of ESBL E. Coli bacteremia and has undergone two knee replacements. 

The patient was initially transferred to the floor, but was later transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to worsening respiratory distress and hypoxia. She was diagnosed with septic arthritis of the right hip and underwent arthrocentesis. 

The patient's medications at discharge include vancomycin, zosyn, and prednisone. She was also prescribed calcium gluconate and insulin/dextrose. 

The patient's physical examination revealed a tender right hip with pain on movement and limited range of motion. Her laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and pro-B-type natriuretic peptide. Her chest X-ray revealed diffuse interstitial opacities and irregularity of the left second and third lateral ribs, suggestive of fractures. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 44-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital due to elevated bilirubin levels. She had a history of multiple injuries, including a head-on motor vehicle crash, and was previously discharged to a skilled nursing facility (SNF) with a hematocrit of 27. However, she was readmitted due to a decrease in her hematocrit to 21 and was found to have a large intrahepatic biloma without significant ductal dilation. She underwent an ERCP with sphincterotomy and placement of a biliary pigtail catheter, and was also found to have a grade IV liver laceration.

The patient's past medical history includes bipolar disorder, depression, anxiety, substance abuse, and an eating disorder. She has no known allergies to drugs. Her physical exam revealed jaundice, thinness, and mild tenderness in the abdomen.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes, including ALT and AST, as well as anemia and thrombocytopenia. Her radiology report showed a significantly enlarging intrahepatic fluid collection at the site of a previously seen complex liver laceration, compatible with an evolving hematoma.

The patient was discharged to an extended care facility with a diagnosis of biloma and a secondary diagnosis of grade IV liver laceration. Her medications at discharge included nicotine patches, heparin, olanzapine, ciprofloxacin, metronidazole, oxycodone, colace, and dulcolax. ||endoftext||

The patient is a ___ year old gentleman with a history of AVR and 
aortic aneurysm repair, L CFA-axillary bypass graft ___ and R

groin wound dehiscence and S. anginosus and MSSA bacteremia with

VASCULAR: Right groin wound was packed, and patient was started 
on vancomycin, Cipro, and Flagyl and admitted to the vascular 
surgery service. Admission blood cultures grew strep anginosus 
and wound swab was polymicrobial including MSSA and e Coli. CT 
angiogram was concerning for infection at the site of bypass 
graft anastamosis with the femoral artery. ID was consulted, who 
recommended transition to Zosyn. Pt was then pre-oped and 
consented for surgery for infected right femoral axillary 
bypass. Coumadin was stopped in preperation of surgery. He was 
on a heparin drip for his mechanical valve.

1. Widely patent right axillary to femoral bypass graft, with 
minimal soft 
tissue density and small locules of air surrounding the distal 
portion of the 
bypass graft at its femoral artery anastomotic site. Although, 
no drainable 
fluid collections or abscesses are seen, this would be 
concerning for 
infection in the presence of clinical symptoms. 
  
2. Stable appearance of the ascending thoracic aortic graft and 
widely patent 
left axillary to femoral bypass graft. Normal appearance of the 
abdominal 
aorta and its major visceral branches. 
  
3. Unchanged appearance of an isodense right lower pole renal 
lesion and 
multiple indeterminate left renal lesions since the earlier 
study. These can 
be further evaluated by renal CTA protocol if this has not 
evaluated before. 

He was taken to the OR after developing several small bleeds 
from his operative site concerning for herald bleeds from a 
ruptured aneurysm. In the OR on ___ he was found to have fresh 
clotted blood at his femoral graft site with concern for a 
disrupted femoral anastomosis. He was found to have inflammatory 
changes in his retroperitoneum and a large inflammatory phlegmon 
at his rectus. The distal portion of his axillofemoral graft was 
detached and a saphenous vein graft was placed. 

___ - Exploration of right groin, control of the external iliac 
artery via a retroperitoneal exposure, excision of distal 
portion of the axillary-femoral bypass,
and vein patch repair of the femoral artery with saphenous vein 
patch.

Patient remained intubated on return from OR

Due to his massive bleeding and transfusion requirements, he 
developed abdominal compartment syndrome overnight and was taken 
back to the OR on ___ for exploration of retroperitoneal space, 
washout of retroperitoneal space and intra abdominal cavity, 
packing of the retroperitoneum with Ioban closure of the

no abnormalities and LFTs trended downward. Systolic blood

On ___ patient was extubated. Patient passed bedside swallow 
eval and was transition to oral nutrition. 

On ___ patient was transferred from the CVICU to the VICU.

In the VICU to floor non incidental, The rest of the Hospital 
course will by systems:

Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient narcotics IV with good 
effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral intake, 
the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications.

vital signs were routinely monitored. Pt also has Mechanical 
Valve was on IV heparin with transition tocoumadin on DC

Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.

GI: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. His diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. He was also started on a bowel regimen 
to encourage bowel movement. Pt did have trouble with nutrion, 
started on dronabinol  2.5 mg PO BID. Pt also had loose stools - 
neg C Diff x 3, d/c'ed IV flagyl per ID

GU: Foley was removed when apprpriate. Intake and output were 
closely monitored. Pt did have acute on chronic renal failure. 
On ___ patient had decreased urine output in setting of 
increased bladder pressure (27 mmHg) and abdominal distension, 
which improved with albumin administration, 1 u pRBCs, and 
muscle paralysis

ID: ID consult, Was originally on IV vanco . PO cipro / PO 
flagyl. ID transitioned to IV Zosyn - to be on a total of 6 
weeks, then PO supression therapy for life. Name of ___ 
to be determined. The patient's temperature was closely watched 
for signs of infection. 

He waa dmitted on ___ with a wound dehiscence and fever. ___ 
blood cultures drawn ___ grew S. anginosus as well as MSSA on 
___ and ___. A wound swab of the right groin site has grown 
MSSA as well as mixed flora. A CT Torso on ___ showed "a widely 
patent right axillary to femoral bypass graft, with minimal soft 
tissue density and small locules of air surrounding the distal 
portion of the bypass graft at its femoral artery anastomotic 
site." A TEE was performed showed "a well-seated bi-leaflet 
mechanical aortic valve prosthesis with normal leaflet motion 
and gradients. No discrete vegetations." 

The patient was treated with piperacillin-tazobactam for 
coverage of S. anginosus and MSSA BSI as well as a polymicrobial 
wound infection. 

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during 
this stay, and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible. 

On day of discharge, pt's BUN/creat =65/2.6, thought to be 
likely due to dehydration. IVF bolus was given with maintenance 
IVF to continue at rehab until creatinine trends down. PO fluids 
also encouraged. Lasix was discontinued and ___ should not be 
restarted until creatinine at baseline. VAC was also 
discontinued and  should continue on wet to dry BID until follow 
up. Foley was reinserted for urinary retention of approx 600 cc 
urine. Please attempt voiding trial in a day or so. 

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, 
voiding with foley, and pain was well controlled.

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery
Lower Extremity Surgery Discharge Instructions

What to expect when you go home:
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!

2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on:
Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated

3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
Eat small frequent meals
It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

What activities you can and cannot do:
No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
You should get up every day, get dressed and walk
You should gradually increase your activity
You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
Take all the medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
Take one full strength (325mg) enteric coated aspirin daily, 
unless otherwise directed 

What to report to office:
Redness that extends away from your incision
A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication
A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg
Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours
Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

||startoftext|| The patient is a 69-year-old male who was admitted with a right groin infection. He has a history of multiple medical problems, including a previous stroke, ascending aortic aneurysm, and severe hypertension. He was treated with antibiotics and instructed to follow up with vascular surgery, but his wound continued to worsen and he was readmitted to the hospital. 

The patient underwent several surgical procedures, including exploration of the right groin, control of the external iliac artery, and excision of the distal portion of the axillary-femoral bypass. He also underwent abdominal washout, packing removal, and temporary abdominal closure. 

The patient's diagnosis was a right groin infection, and he was found to have a polymicrobial infection including Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus anginosus, and Escherichia coli. He was prescribed antibiotics, including ceftriaxone, clindamycin, and gentamicin. 

The patient's medications at discharge included ceftriaxone, clindamycin, and gentamicin. He also had an allergy to oxycodone. ||endoftext||

History of Present Illness:
___ with PMH CAD, DM with CKD, Afib, HLP presents for the second

Of note, pt was recently seen here ___ with the complaint of 
shortness of breath after dialysis.  She was diagnosed with

discharged to rehab.

Since that time, the patient notes that she initially felt 
better but would still get short of breath with minimal 
exertion.  She states that when she gets up to the bathroom from 
her bed, she feels acutely short of breath.  This symptom is 
associated with a burning sensation in her substernal region 
that radiates directly upward towards her throat.  This morning 
she was walking into the ___ clinic when she began to feel 
those symptoms.  As she was recently hospitalized with similar 
symptoms in ___, the Renal doctors ___ with 
___ and removed 3L.  Her symptoms persisted and she 
was then sent to the ___ ED.

In the ED, the patient was still having symptoms.  An EKG showed 
slight <1mm ST depressions in the lateral leads.  She was given 
ASA 325, and a SL nitroglycerin relieved her chest discomfort.  
Labs were notable for a troponin level of 0.08, and a d-dimer 
was positive.  Subsequent CTA was negative for PE or aortic 
dissection.   She was then transferred up to the Cardiology

of breath, nausea, diaphoresis etc.

stools or red stools. She denies recent fevers, chills or 
rigors. She denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the 
other review of systems were negative.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with PMH of CAD, DM and ESRD presents with complaint of 
exertional dyspnea and chest discomfort.
  
# CORONARIES:
- Pt's story of exertional symptoms and atypical chest pain 
occur with roughly the same amount of exertion, relieved by 
nitroglycerin, and never at rest
- With PMH CAD, this presentation was concerning for stable 
angina
- initially treated with medical therapy with ASA, statin, and 
agressive afterload reduction
- PMIBI results concerning for multiterritorial perfusion 
defects
- Main concern regarding the results of her PMIBI was the 
possibility of left main disease, which would require a high 
risk cath
- This has been verified with the presence of high grade 
proximal LAD and LCx disease (left main equivalent) on Coronary 
CTA
- After a risk/benefit discussion with patient and family the 
decision was made for cardiac catheterization
  - Cath results failed to reveal any significant left main 
disease, or any worsening CAD from prior study in ___
- Pt was not placed on Plavix ___ concern regarding her 
anemia/thrombocytopenia and potential fall risk at home
.

euvolemic but with evidence of elevated LVEDP to 32 during cath
- communicated to the Nephrology team that pt should be dialyzed 
as aggressively as possible to optimize fluid status, as volume 
overload could contribute to her symptoms of DOE
- dc'ed home lasix as not likely to be of any benefit, pt has 
very little UOP ___ ESRD
.

- currently SBP 110's-150, will control to goal <140
- Continued home meds amlodipine, clonidine and lisinopril at 
current doses, increased imdur to 60mg daily
- if further titration is needed in the outpatient setting PO 
hydralazine would be a good option
.
# Skin Lesions

treated symptomatically with sarna lotion with subjective 
improvement per patient
- On ___, pt found to have R hand swelling and multiple areas 
of painless skin sloughing
- Dermatology consult was obtained, placed pt on regimen of 
steroid cream for her face, bactroban for the hand lesion which 
was thought to be skin sloughing from an infiltrated IV
- RUE US negative for DVT
- skin creams were continued as an outpatient regimen
.

___ prior untreated VRE
- ___, Ucx with pan sensitive E coli and other G+ flora, 
continued tx with cipro to complete 10d course.  Repeat culture 
with GNR

She has a past medical history of CAD, DM with CKD, Afib, and HLP. She was recently hospitalized for volume overload and underwent ultrafiltration and diuresis. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which showed significant atherosclerotic disease in the left main coronary artery and left anterior descending artery. She was diagnosed with mitral regurgitation and had a left ventricular ejection fraction of unknown percentage.

The patient's medications at discharge include ASA 325 and SL nitroglycerin. She has a history of allergies to Motrin. Her skin examination showed multiple areas of shallow ulceration and apparent desquamation on the dorsum of her right hand.

The patient's review of systems was negative for prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. She denied recent fevers, chills, or rigors. ||endoftext||

text:
age: 64. gender: M.  
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left sided weakness and incoordination
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
1. Endobronchial biopsy of right and left lung nodules

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ right-handed man with a history of
prostate CA s/p radiation, hyperlipidemia, cervical spine
disease, and longstanding tobacco use who presents with left
sided weakness and incoordination over the last 10 days. He
reports that he had "the flu" about 6 weeks ago with URI 
symptoms
and muscle aches. This resolved, but then about 2 weeks ago he
began to have muscle aches again that felt very similar. These
started in his left quadriceps and then spread over the next
several days to involve his bilateral quadriceps, calves, and
triceps as well. He saw his PCP ___ ___ for his annual physical
and then again on ___ due to the persistent myalgias. At that
point he had also begun to experience intermittent vertigo as
well. This was only present with movement such as turning his
head or standing up to walk and resolved completely at rest. He
describes it as a brief sensation of spinning or movement 
lasting
seconds. CK and ESR were checked due to the myalgias and were
negative. His vertigo was felt to be most likely peripheral.
Basic labs were all normal and he was advised to monitor his
symptoms. 

However over the next week his vertigo persisted, still only
brought on by movement, and he also began to notice weakness in
his left arm and leg. He initially attributed this to the muscle
aches, which ultimately resolved on the right but have still
persisted a little in his left quad and triceps. However over 
the
last week he has also noticed that it is more difficult to
control his left arm and leg. He says they feel weak but also
clumsy, and his arm "flops around" when he tries to use it. His
wife says he also veers toward the left when he walks, and his
left leg has "given out" on him a couple of times. He has fallen
twice in the last week, once when getting out of the car and 
then
again yesterday when he was trying to help his wife make up the
bed. Both times his left leg just seemed to buckle and he fell 
to
the ground, sustaining some scrapes but no significant injuries.
Last night he was playing cards with his friends, which he has
done for ___ years, and realized that he couldn't hold the cards
or shuffle with his left hand. At this point he became 
concerned,
as he says one of his other friends in the group had a stroke a
few years ago with very similar symptoms. He therefore went back

- NON-CONTRAST HEAD CT (___): Findings concerning for multiple

- CTA HEAD/NECK (___):  
1. Three distinct heterogeneously-enhancing parenchymal lesions, 
with cystic necrosis, within the superior cerebellar vermis, and 
the left frontal and parietal lobe, worrisome for metastatic 
disease. No intraparenchymal hemorrhage. 
2. Mild effacement of the left ambient cistern. 
3. 2.7 cm soft tissue mass within the azygos lobe with an 
associated 3.2 cm necrotic precarinal lymph node which may 
represent primary bronchogenic neoplasm with metastatic 
lymphadenopathy. 
4. Patent vasculature. No aneurysm, dissection, or stenosis. 

- MRI BRAIN W/WO GAD (___): 
1. Hemorrhagic metastases in the left superior frontal and left 
medial 
occipital regions, which may be leptomeningeal or superficial 
cortical, 
without significant mass effect. Punctate left superior frontal 
cortical 
metastasis adjacent to the larger left frontal metastasis. 
2. Hemorrhagic metastases in the left superior cerebellar vermis 
and left 
cerebellar hemisphere. The dominant metastasis in the left 
cerebellar vermis effaces the left ambient cistern with 
deformation of the left inferior colliculus. It also partially 
effaces the fourth ventricle without obstructive hydrocephalus. 
3. 4 mm enhancing lesion in the superior right aspect of the 
occipital bone, corresponding to a lytic lesion with erosion of 
the outer table on the prior CT, indicating an osseous 
metastasis. 
  
COMMENT: The appearance of the intracranial and calvarial 
lesions is more suggestive of metastatic disease from the right 
apical pulmonary mass seen on the preceding CTA, than from 
prostate cancer, but tissue diagnosis is needed. 

CT ___ W CONTRAST (___):  
1. Multiple enlarged low-attenuation mediastinal lymph nodes and 
right hilar lymph node. A 1.4 cm subpleural nodule in the right 
upper lobe. Adjacent to/contiguous with the necrotic right upper 
paratracheal lymph node. Multiple pulmonary nodules identified 
measuring up to 5 mm. Findings are suspicious of pulmonary and 
nodal metastases. The mediastinal lymph nodes are amenable for 
biopsy via bronchoscopy. 
2. A 1.5 cm and 1.6 cm hypodense lesions in segment 2 and 4B 
nonspecific but suspicious for hepatic metastasis, especially 
segment 4B lesion. 
3. 3.5 cm solid lesion identified posterior to the left psoas 
muscle, 
suspicious for metastasis. This lesion is amenable for biopsy 
under CT 
guidance, if necessary. 
4. Enlarged necrotic lymph nodes at the left external iliac and 
left common iliac chain, suspicious for nodal metastases. 
5. Cholelithiasis. Small hiatal hernia. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo RH M with a history of prostate CA s/p radiation, 
hyperlipidemia, cervical spine disease, and tobacco use who 
presents with left sided weakness and incoordination over the 
last 10 days. In the ED, head CT showed 3 lesions with central 
hemorrhage/necrosis and vasogenic edema in the left frontal 
lobe, left parietal lobe, and most notably in the left 
cerebellar vermis coming close to impinging on the ___ 
ventricle, with no hydrocephalus. CTA head/neck incidentally 
revealed a mass in the right upper lung with adjacent necrotic 
lymph nodes. The findings were highly concerning for metastatic 
cancer. 

# HOSPITAL COURSE: He was admitted to the Neurology service for 
further workup. MRI brain confirmed presence of hemorrhagic 
metastases in the left frontal and parietal lobes and left 
cerebellar hemisphere with small amount of vasogenic edema. CT 
torso revealed multiple lesions concerning for metastatic cancer 
-- enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes, 1.4cm RUL nodule and 
multiple other pulmonary nodules, 2 liver lesions, solid lesion 
posterior to the left psoas, and enlarged necrotic left iliac 
lymph nodes. Given his smoking history and distribution of the 
lesions, findings were highly suspicious for metastatic lung 
cancer. 

The next day an endobronchial biopsy of the right lung and LNs 
was obtained by Interventional Pulmonology (results pending on 
discharge). Hematology-Oncology, Neuro-Oncology, Neurosurgery 
and Radiation Oncology services consulted for workup and 
planning. Given the size of the cerebellar mass and its close 
proximity to the ___ ventricle, it was felt that patient would 
need whole brain radiation (fractionated radiotherapy to the 
area would cause too much swelling and thus hydrocephalus, and 
surgical resection would be unsafe given his age and 
comorbidities). After much debate, it was decided that he needed 
EVD placed before beginning whole brain XRT since risk for 
subsequent edema and hydrocephalus was still high. This will be 
performed one week after discharge, on ___ -- 
patient will be called beforehand with time and name of 
neurosurgeon doing the procedure. Following EVD placement, he 
will see Radiation Oncology (Dr. ___ in clinic to begin 
planning for whole-brain radiation. They anticipate beginning 
XRT one week after surgery in order to allow superficial wound 
healing. 

Patient was started on Dexamethasone 4mg qAM (with GI 
prophylaxis) in the hospital for additional for additional 
protection against vasogenic edema. He was also given oxycodone 
on discharge for left hip pain caused by metastases to the area, 
which cause him significant discomfort. 

At the time of discharge, results of the lung biopsy are still 
pending. Once they return, Heme-Onc will coordinate follow up 
and planning for systemic therapy in the appropriate clinic 
(most likely Thoracic Oncology, given high suspicion that this 
is lung cancer). 

Patient was seen by Social Work in the hospital to address 
coping with his new diagnosis and for assistance obtaining 
long-term disability and transportation to future appointments 
at ___. 

====================
TRANSITIONS OF CARE:
- Studies pending = lung biopsy from ___ (to be followed up by 
Heme Onc)
- Needs to be called by Neurosurgery and Rad Onc departments to 
schedule EVD placement and XRT planning in next week

Aspirin 81mg - only takes ___ per week due to easy bleeding

Tablet Refills:*2

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Masses in brain, lungs, liver and inguinal lymph nodes 
concerning for metastatic cancer 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Neuro exam = dysmetria on left FNF, incoordination of fine 
finger movements on left, mildly wide based gait. 

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital for new clumsiness and 
weakness on the left side of your body. An MRI of your brain 
showed 3 masses concerning for metastatic cancer, one of which 
was in an area called the CEREBELLUM and carries a high risk for 
causing brain cancer (HYDROCEPHALUS). A subsequent CT scan of 
your torso showed masses in your lymph nodes, lungs and liver 
also concerning for cancer. A lung biopsy was performed, results 
pending. 

The next step in your care will be to start whole brain 
radiation. Before this, you will need a ventriculo-peritoneal 
(VP) shunt. This will be done on ___. You will 
be called by the Neurosurgery apartment with the name of the 
surgeon who will perform the operation and the time of surgery. 

Approximately 3 days after shunt placement, you should attend 
your follow-up appointment with Radiation Oncology. They will 
coordination your radiation plan, as well as your follow-up 
appointments with Neuro-Oncology (___). You will be 
called by them to schedule this appointment in the next few 
days.

You are scheduled for an outpatient with Medical Oncology (Dr. 
___ on ___ to discuss the results of your lung 
biopsy, which should have returned by them. See below for more 
info. They will plan your systemic therapy (chemotherapy and/or 
radiation) once the lung biopsy results have returned. 

We made the following changes to your medications: 
1. STARTED Dexamethasone (Decadron) 4mg by mouth in AM -- this 
is to treat swelling of the brain due to cancer. 
2. STARTED Famotidine 20mg twice daily -- this is to prevent 
acid reflux caused by Decadron. 
3. STARTED Oxycodone 2.5-5mg every 6 hrs as needed for pain -- 
side effects include nausea and constipation. Can take over the 
counter laxative as needed.
4. STARTED Ondansetron (Zofran) 4mg every 8 hrs as needed for 
nausea -- if experienced as side effect of oxycodone.

He had been experiencing symptoms of dizziness and exertional dyspnea over the past few months. His past medical history includes aortic stenosis, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic bronchitis, polymyalgia rheumatica, prostate cancer, gout, and osteoarthritis.

The patient underwent a left heart catheterization, coronary angiogram, and left ventriculogram, which showed severe aortic valve stenosis and mild aortic regurgitation. He also had complex atheroma in the descending thoracic aorta. The patient underwent aortic valve replacement and coronary artery bypass grafting, and his post-operative course was uneventful.

The patient was discharged on day 5 with medications including alendronate, Symbicort, colchicine, ipratropium-albuterol, metoprolol succinate, prednisone, simvastatin, tiotropium bromide, sulfacetamide sodium, aspirin, and cyanocobalamin. Brief Hospital Course:
A/P: ___ year old man with h/o AML s/p allo cord transplant 
complicated by chronic GVHD of the joints who now presents with 
worsening joint pain.  

# GVHD with joint pain: Chronic joint pain and recent 
exacerbation likely due to a combination of GVHD and change in 
narcotics regimen (as patient decreased oxycotin dosage to qhs 
from BID). Uric acid was up to 10.7, but the distribution and 
appearance of joints are not classic for gout. There is no 
swelling, erythema, or decreased range of motion to suggest 
infectious arthritis. CRP 20.3/ESR 55 suggestive of a 
inflammatory process. Efforts were made to improve control of 
his GVHD. In the recent weeks prior to admission Mr ___ 
was switched from Tacrolimus to Cellcept for ongoing nausea and 
vomitting. Mr ___ revealed that he had stoped taking 
plaquinil prior to admission because of his ongoing nausea as 
well. Therefore his plaquinil was discontinued during this 
admission. His predisone was increased from 15mg to 20mg daily 
and he was continued on his home dose of cellcept. He was 
restarted on narcotic regimen of oxycotin 10mg BID and oxycodone 
5mg prn (which was rarely needed). On this regimen his pain and 
energy level improved. He was able to ambulate without 
assistance. He was discharged on the increased predinose dose 
and his home cellcept dose. He was also given OxyContin 10mg BID 
as well as MSIR for breakthrough pain (secondary to oxycodone 
shortage). Further titration of the medications may be necessary 
as an outpatient.
.
# AML: S/p allo cord transplant, now ___ on admission.  The 
transplant was complicated by GVHD as explained above.
.
# Hypotension: On ___ Mr ___ for hypotension 
accompanied by feeling of lightheadness. It did not occur with 
changing position. VS otherwise stable. His blood pressure  
improved with IVF. He was also briefly started on cefepime for 
fear of an underlying infection, however this was quickly stoped 
as he stabilized. The hypotension was in the setting of 
increased use of oxycodone and a one time use of MSIV. The 
hypotension was attributed to sedation from narcotics, his dose 
was decreased without further episodes of hypotension.
.
# Ingrown toenails:  The patient has a history of ___ ingrown 
toenails. He had pain bilaterally in the second toes. There was 
also a small 1 mm area of black discoloration, however 
peripheral pulses were normal, the feet were without other signs 
of ischemia. ABIs were obtained with normal vascular flow in the 
extremities.  Podiatry was consulted and removed the ___ ingrown 
toenails. There was also a small amount of pus on the right toe. 
The patient was treated with bacitracin. He was also started on 
a course of Keflex for the small infection.
.
# Constipation: Bowel regimen implemented with Colace, Senna, 
and Miralex.
.
# GERD: Mr ___ was increased to BID given his 
symptoms of GERD daily despite daily dosing. Further evaluation 
of the GERD should be considered if he continues to have 
symptoms as an outpatient.
.
# Nausea: Patient was experiencing significant nausea / 
vomitting prior to admission.  He did not experience this during 
the admission. The improvement could be secondary to recently 
stoping Tacrolimus or discontinuing Plaquenil. It could also be 
secondary to improved pain control or increased ___ dosing.  
He was discharged with zofran for nausea control.
.
# Diabetes: Continued on home dose of Lantus and ISS
.
# HTN: continued on Carvedilol and lisinopril. Episodic 
hypotension as above
.
# Peripheral neuropathy: Continued gabapentin
.
# H/o Recent BOOP / Aspergillus: Continued on Voriconazole
.
# CKD:  Baseline Cr 1.4 to 2.1 in the past. Cr remained 2.0 to 
2.2 during this admission.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for increased joint pain, 
fatigue, and Nausea / vomitting. Your plaquenil was stoped and 
your prednisone was increased from 15 to 20mg daily. You were 
maintained on oxycontin BID with oxycodone for pain control. You 
pain, fatigue, and nausea all improved on this regimen. You toes 
were examed by podiatry and your second toe, toenails were 
clipped. You were treated with Keflex (antibiotic) for the minor 
infection at the site of the ingrown toenail. Evaluation for 
vascular disease in your legs was normal.
.
There was some concern for infection with an episode of 
hypotension however an infectious work up was negative and your 
hypotension is felt to be from a high dose of narcotics received 
at that time. 
.
The prednisone has worked well, however is not ideal for control 
of your GVHD in the long term. Further long term management will 
need to be discussed with Dr ___.
.
The following changes were made to your medication regimen:
Keflex was added for your toe infection.
plaquenil was discontinued
Prednisone was increased from 15mg to 20mg daily
Oxycontin was increased back to 10mg twice a day
Unforetunately oxycodone is currently in short supply, instead 
you can use Immediate release morphine (MSIR) for breakthrough 
pain
___ was increased to twice daily
Colace and senna were added for constipation
Bacitracin-Polymyxin B ointment to you toe
zofran replaces compazine for nausea
.
Follow up with your doctors as detailed below.
.
Please call your doctor or go to the emergency room if you 
develop fevers, chills, nightsweats, increased pain, fatigue, 
nausea or vomitting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, toe pain or pus 
production, sore throat, shortness of breath, cough, chest pain, 
or any other worrisome symptom.

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 52-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with worsening joint pain. He has a history of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and has undergone a myeloablative double cord blood transplant. He has been experiencing chronic joint pain since his transplant, which has worsened over the past two weeks. The patient has been taking oxycodone for pain control, but has recently decreased his dosage due to nausea and vomiting. He has also been experiencing fever, fatigue, and swelling in his joints.

The patient's past medical history includes a diagnosis of AML, sarcoidosis, and chronic GVHD. He has undergone several treatments for his AML, including induction therapy, consolidation therapy, and relapse treatment. He has also received Rituxan for his chronic GVHD.

The patient's physical examination revealed a middle-aged, Cushingoid, overweight man with bilateral 2+ pitting edema to his knees. His joints were tender to palpation, and he had ecchymoses on his abdomen. His laboratory results showed an elevated CRP level, indicating an inflammatory process.

The patient's diagnosis is chronic GVHD with joint pain, likely due to a combination of GVHD and changes in his narcotics regimen. His treatment plan includes increasing his prednisone dosage and discontinuing his plaquinil medication. ||endoftext||
